PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOURS OF MEETING, GOVERNMENT BUSINESS AND ADJOURNMENT OF THE HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered-
(1) the House shall meet for the remaining sittings this week on:
Thursday, 16 October, at 9 a.m.
Friday, 17 October, at 9 a.m.;
(2) government business shall take precedence over general business for the next sitting, and
(3) standing order 48a (adjournment of the House), as amended by sessional order, be suspended for this sitting and the next sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we going to sit all night again?

—No, it is not the intention that the House should sit late into the evening. We are taking the opportunity of providing additional hours as early as we possibly can by sitting from 9 a.m. on Thursday and Friday. I realise that this does put extra pressure on the Clerks and the people involved in the administration of the House. It is necessary for us to give Government Business priority to make sure that the program we have laid down for this three-week sitting is completed. That will give back benchers on both sides of the House the opportunity of debating not only the appropriations that are before us today but also other measures which will come before us today and tomorrow so that we can complete the business that is set down for this week, clearing the way for us again to set a full program for the third week of this sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not an unusual move; it is a move that is quite often made by government. I think it does give people the opportunity to plan their speakers a lot more efficiently than they would otherwise have done. Sometimes it appears that there are only one or two people on the Opposition benches who are interested in speaking and they want to dominate the whole proceedings of the House and not give their colleagues the opportunity of speaking on some of the important Bills. I think in this way the Government helps all those members on the Opposition back benches who might have been squeezed out of the various debates by virtue of the domination of one or two of their members who seem to want to jump to their feet and speak on every issue that comes before the Parliament. In this way people on both sides of the House can see the timetable set down by the Government and can fit their program into the sitting hours which have been made available. We are making more hours available now for Government Business. This should allow the program we have laid down for the remainder of this week and next week to be completed as we anticipated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite obvious that the Government is in trouble. We know that the polls are not running too well for it; we know that it cannot comprehend the degree to which it is necessary that there be an adequate opportunity--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —They are a good lot of school kids; they come from Tamworth. Apart from anything else, I think the Government needs to understand that there is a real problem in the community because this Government is not prepared to come into this Parliament and answer to the real concerns in the community about where the economy is going and where the Government's management is going. This motion will do three things: Firstly, it will require us to get up early in the morning. For all of us in the bush that is just a customary habit. Indeed, I think it would be a good idea--

SPEECH.PARA: Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting if one has a look at the attendance in the House at the moment. My colleagues from the National Party of Australia are all here. They are used to getting up early in the morning. All the bush members of our coalition partner are here, but where are the members of the Labor Party? Most of them are still in the cot, and I can understand it. They had a pretty good old night last night. They were in there wining and dining with the Prime Minister of India. It is not often that this Labor Government is prepared to give a feed to the members of this place, and I do not doubt that some members of the Australian Labor Party are feeling pretty poorly today, having seen their behaviour around the Parliament last night. I felt quite ashamed. I have no doubt that after a couple of hours in bed--
—Order! The right honourable member will not cast aspersions on other members of the House.

—I am sorry, Madam Speaker, I thought I was just factually reporting the state of their health. Nonetheless, it is important that we recognise that the first part of this motion provides that there will be an early start, at 9 a.m., on the two final sitting days of this week. We do not fundamentally object to that but the other two parts of the motion are far more consequential. The second part provides that Government Business shall take precedence over General Business for the next sitting. General Business Thursday No. 12 is a motion by the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), regarding Medicare and the health care system. I do not think that there is any more serious and substantive area of disarray as far as Government policy is concerned. The honourable member's notice urges the House to recall the Government's promise to provide a fair, equitable and efficient health care system. What an appalling state of affairs we have with Medicare in its present state of disarray. We know that every doctor and every patient are concerned; we know that the people are concerned. I think it important that there be a debate on that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not like the fact that such a debate would take place over the lunch hour as that denies people the proper opportunity to attend parliamentary committee meetings. That is another of the practices that have developed. More and more this Government has designed proceedings so that parliamentary committees meet while the Parliament is in session. We do not agree with that. We think it would be far better if there were reasonable meal breaks so that parliamentary committees could meet then instead of having to sit in the way that the Labor Government has made almost obligatory. This second part of the motion means that the debate on Medicare will be suspended. Government Business is to take precedence over General Business. I do not think that proper. It is necessary that we consider the motion on Medicare. The honourable member for Barker deserves to be given his chance. I should add that this is only General Business Thursday No. 12. We have on the Notice Paper up to General Business Thursday No. 22. We need to debate those motions but that is unlikely to occur before this Parliament ends. Apart from those, there are a number of other General Business motions. There are 104 General Business motions on the Notice Paper, from both sides of the House, covering a wide array of matters, and it is unlikely that any of those motions will be debated. So much for the contention of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) that this motion is intended to give more time for the business of private members. There are matters of concern to members of this House contained in these General Business notices and it is likely that none of them will be debated. What is the Minister doing? He is just going to suspend General Business today. The second part of the motion frankly does not meet with our concurrence.

The third part is also very important; that is, that standing order 48a, relating to the adjournment of the House, as amended by sessional order, be suspended. That means that the Minister will again try to take up the adjournment debate. Members of this place have too few opportunities to talk on matters that affect them and the adjournment debate is a sacred part of the rights and opportunities of private members to debate in this chamber. I do not regard it as acceptable that apparently not only for this sitting but also for the next sitting there will be no adjournment debate.

Honourable members need to take note that the real nature of this Government's action is to accelerate the consideration of the Appropriation Bills. The Appropriation Bills debate is an important one but it is not the acceleration of consideration that is important; it is the fact that this is a step being taken by the Government to wind up the Parliament prematurely. That is really what that is all about. This Government wants to run to cover again. It is not prepared to give us the normal sitting periods; it is not prepared to allow proper debating opportunities for matters that members wish to raise, be that debate on General Business or on the adjournment. If we are to rise early, one can only conjecture that it is either because the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) yet again wants to get outside of this Parliament, to where he feels he is not likely to be exposed to all of the traumas that flow from the ridiculous policies that he has implemented or because--

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be an early election.

—Perhaps it is because of an early election, as my colleague suggests. Whatever it is, there is no reason for the sittings to be terminated early. There is every reason for us to sit according to the schedule originally announced by the Leader of the House. It is rather interesting that the Government is taking this step, not because it wants to give honourable members an opportunity to consider issues, not because there is any urgent necessity to consider legislation, but simply because it wants to run for cover.

SPEECH.PARA: As with the major economic statement in the middle of this year, it is interesting that the Australian Labor Party is not prepared to have its policies exposed to the proper scrutiny of the Parliament. Government members try to make statements during Question Time instead of exposing their policies to debate as they should. The Government is prepared to have the Parliament rise so that its members can hide away in their little coveys somewhere in Canberra instead of exposing their policies in the Parliament and allowing a proper debate. On that basis the Opposition does not accept the motion moved by the Leader of the House. We suggest that it would be far better for the Government to recognise its obligations to the people of Australia and to allow for full and proper debating opportunities in the Parliament on all the serious and significant issues before the people of Australia.

At a time when the economy is in a mess, when the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has very nearly received the wooden spoon award from the magazine that gave him an accolade a little while ago, it is more appropriate for this Parliament to sit than for it to accelerate debate on significant issues. I suggest to the Leader of the House that he should think again. The Opposition opposes the motion and suggests to the Minister that the Parliament should sit according to its normal sitting schedule and not be cut short as he suggests in this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion by the Government is as indicative of the inability of the Government and of the Leader of the House (Mr Young) to run the affairs of this House as it is of the inability of the Government to run the affairs of the nation. It is outrageous that the Government should introduce a motion stating that Government Business should take precedence. It is another attack on the rights of private members, of back benchers on both sides of the House, to participate in debates of the Parliament. Participation in the adjournment debate is one of the most valued rights that private members on both sides of the House have to raise matters on behalf of constituents. Here we see that right being taken away by this Government. Madam Speaker, it is another example of the growth of the power of the Executive which you, as Speaker and as a champion of the rights of all members of this House, ought to be concerned about.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion is an example of the diminished role of private members in the Parliament. Here we have another example of the Government's riding roughshod not only over its own back bench but also over the Parliament itself. It is an example of the Parliament tragically becoming more and more a rubber stamp of government and of its becoming less relevant. It is another nail in the coffin of parliamentary democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down and stop wasting our time.

—Government members, such as the honourable member for Melbourne, who ought to be in his proper seat, ought to support the right of private members to have an opportunity to speak. I repeat that this is another nail in the coffin of parliamentary democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Young's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) in the knowledge that economic decisions depend largely upon value judgments of the alternative outcomes of proposals. In other words, the thrust of a particular economic argument depends upon the political and philosophical perspective of the advocate. Obviously people can draw from this the conclusion that the Opposition and the Government will have different perspectives. In respect of the Appropriation Bills, the above argument recognises that additional spending on Social Security and Community Services and associated departments can be achieved only when expenditure is forgone in another area. While my personal inclination is to consider expenditure in the areas under discussion to be paramount, the Government had other overriding circumstances to take into consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: With the dramatic collapse in world commodity prices for the things Australia produces, our national income has been slashed by over $6 billion per year. Obviously, this situation demanded urgent action and drastic solutions on the part of the Government, and it is in this context that the framing of the Budget as a whole must be viewed. The decision to float the Australian dollar rendered our currency and our economic and industrial performance as a nation more vulnerable to the judgments of the financiers of the rest of the world. Unfortunately for Australia, until recently at least, their decisions to buy or sell our dollar seem to have had very little to do with economic realities or an objective evaluation of the fundamentals of the Australian economy. Too often they appear to have succumbed to panic and reacted to rumour and gossip, allowing their judgment to be swayed by personal or collective prejudices and penchants for particular areas of economic policy. I refer interested members, if there are any present, to an article in the Business Review Weekly earlier this year in which the practices of local and external economic gurus were outlined. In this article the author, Alan Deans, claims:
. . . some gurus rely more on instinct or hunch than information from sources in official circles.

So much for economic logic. Most Australians recognise that in the prevailing economic circumstances there is a need to reduce our expenditure as a country. In this context, the call by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for people to `pull in their belts' was understood and reasonably well received across the nation. But we cannot overlook the reality that there are people in Australia who effectively have no belt to pull in and who are relying on government and community assistance for their very survival. That assistance will remain intact in these appropriations, although it will not be extended as far as the Government might wish. I recently attended the launch of a Christmas appeal for poor families in my electorate and bordering areas in the northern suburbs of Perth. The appeal was launched by Bishop Challen and hosted by the local Anglicare organisation. Many churches in Australia, the Anglican Church included, are acutely aware of the poverty which exists in the community, as they have taken on the task of distributing emergency relief and food aid to those in need. Their efforts have supplemented the activities of government and welfare organisations to a large degree and have served to extend the support net available to the needy. The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission has used its resources to research issues such as the availability and adequacy of financial support for families and I commend its members on the quality of the paper recently produced on this subject, a copy of which was forwarded to members of parliament for their information.

In the context of research into the social security system and the adequacy of current income support provisions as related to the taxation system, I congratulate the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) for establishing the social security review in December last year. To date several background papers have been received which provide a further valuable insight into areas such as assistance for families with children. It is proposed that the review will take about two years and at the end of that time some very valuable information will be available. Sadly, despite the Minister's undoubted commitment to assisting the poor and because of the economic difficulties confronting the country, the poverty trap changes have been deferred until July 1987. Also, the normal six-monthly indexation of pensions and benefits has been delayed by six weeks in this Budget. As poverty trap alleviation is crucial to people endeavouring to survive on and supplement a pension, the delay of this measure causes me the greatest concern. These people are already living at the margin and require the stimulus and assistance that the poverty trap proposal promised in terms of their ability to earn additional income without the crushing barrier of marginal tax rates-in excess of 100 per cent in some cases. However, I am certain that the Government will maintain a watchful eye on economic circumstances with a view to improving the position of pensioners, and others in need, as soon as possible.

When discussing welfare, social security and community services, it is important to stress that during the term of this Government there have been significant increases in the real value of pensions and benefits, as well as large gains in the assistance provided for children in low income families. For instance, even in this Budget-which is recognised as difficult-some bouquets have been received from groups such as the Australian Council of Social Service which has welcomed `the increased and well-targeted expenditure in the Community Services portfolio'. The measures taken to preserve Medicare in the Health Department appropriations have also been applauded.

I note that the Budget strategy is already working to Australia's advantage in key sectors of the economy, even though it was never intended as a `quick fix' measure. The Government has forecast growth through productive investment and reconstruction of the economy to promote exports, and it seems that the export thrust has now begun and that Australian businesses are finally grasping the opportunity which has been presented to them by Australia's improved international competitiveness. Hopefully, the improvement in our trading position and a return to currency stability will soon be reflected in a recommitment by the Government to the provision of the necessary support for the poor and needy in our community.

I commend the Minister for Social Security particularly for his sincere endeavours on behalf of his portfolio constituents and regret that the Budget strategy in the welfare area has exposed him at earlier points in this debate to the hollow rhetoric and meaningless posturing of Opposition members, many of whom have no real or lasting commitment to the beneficiaries of welfare in this country and who would prefer to see the abolition of our social security system altogether. I commend the Bill to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Because we are in Committee in debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) our time is very limited. Therefore, there is very little opportunity to reply to things said by speakers on the other side, but one comment by the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) I cannot allow to pass. I acknowledge that the honourable member has a very sincere interest in pensioners and social security beneficiaries, but bland statements about the Government's progress in this area cannot be allowed to pass when they fly in the face of facts. I am sure that the honourable member for Cowan, along with me, has received a document from the Women's Electoral Lobby headed `Women in the 1986-87 Budget' which shows that the fall in family allowances under the Hawke Government from 1983 to the estimated level in 1987 has been 17 per cent. So I cannot let the honourable member say, without some sort of response, that this Government has been making progress in real terms in areas of need. It has made progress in some areas of need, but certainly not all. I hope I get time to say a little more about this later.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcomed the statement from the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) on the elimination of poverty traps. It contains several really excellent and pertinent proposals. It is not merely regrettable that the proposals are not being introduced; it is a tragedy that they are not being introduced at this stage.

When I spoke on the appropriations for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and paid particular attention to the position of the Office of the Status of Women under those appropriations and the very clear lack of effect that the Office has had on Budget matters affecting women, I made the statement that no document had been circulated this year, in contrast with last year, on the effect of the Budget on women. At the time the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling) was in the chair and she shook her head at me as I said that, so I took the trouble to go and ferret out the document afterwards. The reason I had made the mistake was that the document was not volunteered to members, nor was there the plethora of Press releases that there was last year. The document was contained on a supplementary list of Budget documents and reports, not the main list, so it took a little finding. I want to quote from that report, because it is particularly relevant to the appropriations we are looking at. The appropriation on which I will be concentrating is that for the Department of Social Security. The report gives a good outline of the importance of social security measures to women and, as a corollary, families in this community. The report states:
The Department's--
that is, the Department of Social Security-

expenditure on women is higher than any other port- folio-roughly $9,900m in 1986-87 or about 61 per cent of total expenditure by the Department on pensions, benefits and allowances. There are a number of reasons for this, including:

Special provisions for women based on traditional social expectations, e.g. earlier age pension eligibility age, and a separate payment for widows; the larger representation of women among the aged population due to their longer life expectancy; the larger representation of women among sole parents; the generally lower income levels of women reflecting work-force skills and opportunities; and women's traditional child rearing responsibilities which means, in most cases, it is the mothers of children who receive family allowances.

The bulk of the Department's income support payments (77 per cent) are received by women. Women account for 69 per cent of pensioners, 28 per cent of beneficiaries, 98 per cent of family allowance recipients and 99 per cent of family income supplement recipients.
That underlines the fact that women receiving social welfare are very much at the poverty level. Women make up 99 per cent of family income supplement recipients. The report continues:
Social Security expenditure on income support payments to women will represent about 61 per cent of total income support expenditure in 1986-87.

While family allowances for those under 16 are paid to everyone with children, regardless of their income, pensions and benefits are generally income tested. The majority of women receiving pensions or benefits, however, have little income other than their pension and are not affected by these income tests.

The report I have referred to in the women's budget program contains a table headed `Impact of Social Security Income Maintenance Payments on Women 1986-87' which outlines the effect very graphically. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. One aspect that I referred to in my earlier speech on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was measures that were to be taken in relation to recipients of widow's pensions and supporting parent's benefits. Budget Paper No. 1 outlines one particular matter which I have referred to already and which has received absolutely no publicity. I strongly suspect that those who will be affected by this are oblivious of the fact that it will have an effect on them. Whilst age pensioners are aware of the effect of this Budget on their pensions and so on, the simple fact is that widows and supporting parents are not people who are organised into groups to take note of the fine print of things such as Budget Paper No. 1. I believe that this statement has passed them by. Budget Paper No. 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has decided to improve the administration of supporting parent's benefit and widow's pension by more regular reporting, to ensure continuing eligibility, and counselling which will assist the recipients to find work and thus reduce outlays. From October 1986 recipients will be required to report to the Department of Social Security on their circumstances each month during their first three months on benefit and quarterly thereafter.

I underline those points. Women who have just been bereaved, women who have just gone through the trauma of marital breakup-in all cases with young dependent children or they would not be qualifying for these payments-must be fronting up to bureaucrats and telling them why they are not in employment when they are in a traumatised state. I will have more to say about that in the future, but I think that can only be described as disgusting.

The effect of the Budget is also outlined in a document provided by the Parliamentary Library, which would have come into the possession of all honourable members and senators recently, called `Supporting Parent's Benefit' which is a Legislative Research Service background paper. My time is running out but I want to quote from this document because it outlines exactly how women who are on supporting parent's benefits are affected and how this so-called crackdown is likely to work. In a section headed `Effect on Employment of Single Parents', the document states:

. . . single parents, as a group, tend to be particularly disadvantaged in terms of access to employment by virtue of the fact that the overwhelming majority are female. In 1982, 39 per cent of female single parents and 84 per cent of male single parents were in paid employment.

As women, female single parents face a sex-segregated and generally low-paying labour market. A recent survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics showed that female sole parents who worked earned on average only 76 per cent of the income of male sole parents who worked.

It has also been observed that female sole parents are less likely to have access to the Commonwealth-assisted training schemes which have been instituted in response to high unemployment rates, since these have tended to concentrate on youth.
Another major obstacle faced by potential female sole parent entrants to the paid workforce is the lack of affordable child care.

Hence, it appears that the access of sole parents, particularly females, to paid employment is severely restricted. This reduces the viability of workforce participation as an alternative to welfare support for sole parents.

Indeed, it should also be noted that present conditions gravitate against sole parents participating in the workforce even to supplement the SPB. Factors discussed above contribute to this situation, as do two others of particular significance.

Firstly, the taxation treatment of extra income earned by SPB recipients is a significant factor. A Treasury paper presented to the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) in 1984 noted that a supporting parent employed in a job paying $230 a week faced an effective marginal tax rate of 70c in the dollar. Moreover, there is a sharp cut-off for extra concessions such as Rent Assistance.

Secondly, by virtue of their classification, SPB beneficiaries tend to be rendered dependent and marginalised in relation to labour force participation. They are not defined officially as unemployed, but as being outside the labour market . . . This has important repercussions in terms of recruitment for training, re-training and job-creation programs.

These factors, together with the non-indexation of the additional pension payable for dependent children, the Mother's/Guardian's Allowance, and Family Allowances has caught SPB recipients in a severe poverty trap.

The sole parent's long-term dependence upon the SPB or other Department of Social Security pensions and benefits is likely to erode job skills, make job qualifications obsolete and reduce employability. Under these conditions, it is even more likely that the sole parent will be unable to escape the poverty trap.
I underline the points made in that document to point out that this measure which the Government has introduced for reporting on employability is likely to be an absolute failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), who spoke for the Opposition on Appropriation Bill (No. 1), had what in our view were some sensible points to make. However, I am afraid that her voice is a rather lone one in the Opposition. Her concern for matters involving women and social equity would not be rejected by many on this side, but unfortunately the voice that tends to ring louder for the Opposition is that of Katharine West. When the honourable member makes such a speech-I think there is some recognition on this side of the chamber that it contained some valid points-she has to recognise that the louder voices, the thumping voices, are from the New Right and Katharine West.
—Give me time.

—We would be happy to give the honourable member time and see the Opposition become a more moderate and sensible force in Australian politics; we would welcome that. At this stage the Opposition is being led off to the right by those extremists. Honourable members opposite are the ones who have to account for the role that Katharine West and others play.
