SPEECH.PARA: My colleague the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) began very sensibly in setting the focus for discussion on our social policy by talking about the decline in commodity prices. If we look at the commodity price movements, which tend to frame the possibilities in terms of budgetary strategy, we see that they have been quite dramatic and have quite a significant effect on the options in relation to the Budget. I will choose but two or three to give an illustration of what my colleague the honourable member for Cowan said very sensibly. If we look at wheat prices between 1980-81 and 1985-86, we see that they fell from $US181.90 a tonne to $US133 a tonne, which is down 27 per cent. That is one commodity price which has had a quite significant impact. If we look at the price of lead between December 1981 and August 1986, the London Metals Exchange lead price fell--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. We are going through Appropriation Bill (No. 1) department by department. I wonder what commodity prices have to do with the Department of Community Services, the Department of Social Security, the Department of Health or the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The connection escapes me. I wonder whether the honourable member for Stirling should not be asked to make his comments relevant.
—My recollection was that the honourable member for Stirling said that he was using that to illustrate the effect the economy has on welfare payments. There is no point of order.

—The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is a good bloke; he is a Subiaco supporter. We need to set the scene on this, and the issue is that the decline in commodity prices has left us with much less income to distribute and we have had to make some sensible decisions. In that context, we have a housing policy, a health policy, a wages policy, a youth policy and a social security policy; they all fit together. We have not had from the Opposition the emergence of policies of that kind. I think the Australian community recognises that, and it will recognise in the next year that the Opposition does not have a comprehensive policy. What we have is a lot of shrieking from the New Right, but there are no really substantive propositions coming from the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say something else about the impact of commodity prices. It has reduced the total income of Australia, which has meant that this Government has had to make some tough decisions. I commend the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) because I believe he has fought very well to maintain a sensible and humane social security policy. I know the honourable member for Cowan shares that view. (Quorum formed) I was saying that members of the Opposition did not have any policies. It is a clear indication that they do not that, whenever one gets up in this place and talks about their absence of policies, they call for quorums or run about the place. They really do not have a policy. They do not have a policy on wages, youth, employment, housing or health. At the moment they are being steered by the New Right. That will not lead them anywhere with the electorate because the electorate recognises very accurately that they have to have substantial policies and policies which have been thought through. I will quote a letter from a constituent of mine which I think puts in place the hopeless, selfish nature of the Opposition. It states:

When contacted previously I was married to a wonderful man. We have seven children. Our concerns were inflation, education. All that changed 3 weeks ago . . . 3 weeks ago my husband collapsed and died. No cause of death has been found. He was 36 years old. Now I find myself a widow with 7 children. The eldest is 12 years old and the youngest is 20 months. I am 35 years of age.
Apart from the shock and grief I find myself trying to cope with the drop in my self esteem. I'm a pensioner! A widow! I feel frightened.

When we take that statement and put it alongside the shrieking of the New Right in the Australian community who talk about cutting pensions and reducing unemployment benefit to $1 a day; when we look at the members of the Opposition, shattered as they are, but absolutely hopeless in terms of their consciousness and humanity, and juxtapose that against the case I have just cited of a woman of 35 years of age with seven children who is now a widow; and when we look at the welfare bashing that goes on on behalf of the Opposition, is it any wonder that people in the Australian community feel that the Opposition is a discredited bunch? It is our very clear view that what we ought to be saying in this place is that policies are needed. This Government does have policies and members of the Opposition do not have policies. What they are doing is listening increasingly to the shrieking of the New Right about what they might do in terms of cutting back on welfare in this country.

The honourable member for Moncrieff talked about the difficulties of having people work tested. We are sensibly reacting to the fact that there has been abuse of the welfare system. I ask members of the Opposition: Where will they stand on the identity card? Where will members in the National Party seats stand on the question of the ID card? Our view is that we ought to be managing the social security system properly. There ought not to be abuse of the social security system. I think one of the most important things one can do in terms of people's welfare is give them a job. In the first three years of the Hawke Government we created some 670,000 jobs. That was something that members of the Opposition were incapable of doing; they reduced employment when they were in government. We have also given people housing. Our record on public housing and private housing has been outstanding. When the Opposition left office new commencements were at the lowest level for 20 years, at 105,000. In our first year we raised it to 135,000. So we have given people jobs and we have given people housing, but,what is more, we have given them a sense of purpose and they recognise that. I am sure that people on this side of the chamber are pleased to commend the Government's budgetary stategy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the more imaginative connivances of this Government is to be found at pages 119 and 121 of Budget Paper No. 1. To put it in its proper setting, one has to recall the posturing of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) when he set out in 1983-and he has developed it ever since-his grand plan for developing health care in Australia. His so-called successes and outright failures are adequately recorded and, of course, they need not be reiterated today.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the particular matter I want to canvass is at best consistent in its inconsistency and at worst confirmation that the uncontrolled cost explosion of Medicare knows no bounds. We all know that the Medicare levy has been increased by 25 per cent in this Budget. Equally we know that the increased levy does not cover the additional cost of Medicare despite the Government's repeated promises that it would. Most with an ounce of sense would also realise that future cost containment is necessary by reducing the refunds for the costs of all or some services, by appropriating additional amounts from general revenue, by further increasing the levy or perhaps, as is most likely, by a combination of all three. Let no one overlook the fact that a combination of those three alternatives has already been adopted in successive measures and Budgets to get the Government over some of the hurdles of its Medicare folly. More of the same is assured in the future if the present queue of 100,000 Australians awaiting surgery in public hospitals is to be held at that number, leaving aside any chance that it might one day be reduced while the Hawke Government holds the reins.

As I have mentioned, the ultimate incongruity is to be found at pages 119 and 121 of Budget Paper No. 1. Remember the total disregard, bordering on disdain, the Minister for Health reserved for the services of private health funds when he sought to sell the efficacy of Medicare? Remember how Medicare Private was set up to play merry hell with the private funds? It now seems that the Minister has few qualms about saddling the voluntary health funds with the product of his incompetence. In league with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), the Minister for Health now has no compunction about assigning the cost of treating veterans and war widows to the voluntary funds. It is now to be required that the cost of war-caused illnesses and disabilities treated in hospitals be met by private funds and their clients if those veterans or war widows have been prudent or self-sufficient enough to have taken out and maintained private cover. This is an unprecedented departure from the long-held commitment of successive governments to meet the perceived obligations of most decent Australians to those servicemen, their widows and service women who suffered from war-caused illnesses or disabilities and who need hospital treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been betrayed.

—They have been betrayed indeed. Those ex-service men and women and war widows who have been prudent and conscientious enough to insure against hospital treatment for other than causes arising our of war service are to become a burden-a burden not on all taxpayers, as previously, but on the private health insurers. This is because the cost of hospital treatment for veterans and war widows for war-caused ailments must become the responsibility of the private funds for the first time in living memory.
—The Government is welshing on its obligation.

—It is welshing in the grand tradition of the socialist Left. That cost is not one built into the subscriptions or rates presently struck by the voluntary funds; it is a cost which must be recovered in both the long term interests of insured veterans and war widows as well as all other private insurers alike. It is a burden which prudent and fair-minded veterans, who undoubtedly have such qualities because they have insured against other than war caused treatment, would not in a million light years have sought to impose on families and individuals who also insure privately. Such motives would be completely out of step with the selflessness of most veterans and war widows. Most of them will readily understand that, given their war service and accepting that they are not all that young any more, they are likely to need more hospital treatment than people in a more representative age group. Veterans and war widows will understand that the extra premium to be paid by all private insurers will be fairly hefty. Some $7m to $9m is involved. The Government must also be aware of that. Despite that, it has set out to get the bad risks out of the public and into the private sector, on the slightest pretext, despite our debt of honour to all veterans and war widows, regardless of their private arrangements. It is a cynical approach; it is typical of the repeated assaults on the entitlements of veterans and other pensioners of a government that continues to indulge itself by financing ratbag and radical groups, the existence of which arguably is possible only because of the contributions made by those who are now being chiselled by this Government. As if to compound the insult to veterans and war widows, the Minister wants the private funds to assume responsibility for costs traditionally part of the debt of honour that we have to all those veterans.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not all there is to it. Veterans are to be penalised simply because they are privately insured, as all private insurers are to be penalised because premiums must be consequentially increased. Veterans and war widows will not get even the privilege of choice of doctor for hospital treatment of their war-caused illnesses and disabilities. That is available, of course, to private insurers but not to veterans who take out private insurance. Their fellow insureds will of course get that benefit; it will not apply to veterans or war widows.

The sad truth is that the provisions on pages 119 and 121 of Budget Paper No. 1 demonstrate the unconscionable removal of an entitlement to receive rehabilitation hospital treatment at a cost to the revenue. It is an increase in the thickness of the wedge the Hawke Government is driving into the entitlements of our older citizens in general and war widows and veterans in particular. The measure slots in very nicely, of course, with the Government's not so long term doctrinaire commitment to nationalising health care in Australia. It penalises subscribers to private health funds, including veterans and war widows who may have only limited repatriation entitlements and have to maintain private cover for non-repatriation services, for non-war caused illnesses and ailments.

So it is that we see this Government subcontracting out those responsibilities which it was elected to carry out. We see again further evidence of the mentality which caused the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to break his promise not to take money out of pensioners' cheques. It is that sort of mentality which prevails today. The aged and retirees are the target for the cost cutting measures being adopted by this Government. There are more areas which could be tackled with equity than retirees and pensioners, and above all the entitlements of veterans and war widows, which are the areas this Government has set out to attack and is in fact attacking. This is just another example of the policy of this Government and the reasons why we deplore the direction it is taking, particularly in relation to the benefits of veterans and war widows.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87, I wish if I have time to speak on each of the departments being considered. Firstly, I want to talk about the Department of Community Services. In the last few days in the electorate of Gilmore there has been a great deal of concern over certain aspects of the management and administration of the Department. I refer in particular to the increase in nursing home costs, particularly in the coastal area of the electorate of Gilmore. To give an example of the way that nursing home charges have risen, I will use some information I obtained from one of my constituents. It shows that from August 1986 nursing home fees rose from $204 per fortnight to $229.60 per fortnight. In a letter to families and patients dated 2 October 1986, the administrator of the nursing home concerned advised that the Department of Community Services had notified the home of a rise of $5.10 per day effective from 1 October 1986. This brings the fortnightly charge for a bed in a nursing home to about $306.10 per fortnight. The charge has risen from $204 per fortnight in August to $306 per fortnight in October. That represents a 50 per cent increase in just two months. This is causing severe hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: One of my constituents, who receives a fortnightly pension of $227, will be required as from 3 October to pay $301 per fortnight to be in that nursing home. She has limited savings for her funeral which she will now have to draw upon in order to make up the shortfall between the pension and the nursing home charge. Another of my constituents receives a pension of $217.50 per fortnight. He has savings of $337. Under the new schedule of fees he will have to pay $301 per fortnight. This gentleman is a 64-year-old spastic cerebral palsy victim. That is the sort of hardship and distress being caused, particularly in my electorate, as a result of the Government's authorisation of the increase in nursing home accommodation fees.

It is very important that we make clear to the Government, through the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes), that it has to increase the subsidy for nursing home accommodation equal to the amount that it costs each patient as a result of these latest increases. There is no way in the world that, with the present rate of fees and charges authorised by the Government, patients can afford to be in nursing homes. It is important and indeed vital that the Government increase the subsidies to nursing homes so that the patients in them can afford to live reasonably.

While I am speaking of nursing homes, I mention that the people of Culburra, which is on the coast in the electorate of Gilmore, have recently and very gratefully received funding for hostel accommodation in that area. The reason for that hostel accommodation funding is the tremendous number of aged persons living in the Culburra district. The growth of the district is quite rapid-some 17 per cent per annum-and it generally attracts a lot of older people. Quite obviously, if there is a need for hostel accommodation and retirement unit accommodation today, very shortly there will be a need for nursing home accommodation. I put on record the fact that there is an urgent need for the Government to allocate funding so that nursing home accommodation can be built in Culburra. It is a geographically isolated area and, unless we do something now to accommodate the aged population, we will have a tremendous problem in the future. At Culburra also a very very good community health committee has been operating and has raised hundreds of thousands of dollars to try to build retirement accommodation. It has a wonderful track record and is certainly a worthy recipient of funding for nursing home accommodation.

I now want to speak about the Department of Social Security. I am pleased that the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is in the House. A great deal of concern is being expressed by my constituents about the delay of some six weeks in the rise in the pension rate. The rise should have taken place on 1 November, in a couple of weeks time, but it will now be delayed until the middle of December. This may not seem to be a very big thing in the minds of most people, but I assure the House that for those who are dependent on the pension it means a lot. It means $83 to a pensioner couple and $53 to a single pensioner. That is a lot of money if all one has to live on is the pension and one is trying to make one's accounts balance each week, particularly when the cost of many things that pensioners have to pay for is increasing at a rate greater than the consumer price index. One has only to look at the way food prices have increased in supermarkets to understand just how the delay in this rise will affect and indeed upset many of the people in the electorate of Gilmore.

At the last election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave a promise that he would increase the pension rate to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Government has not been able to live up to that promise. In fact, in September 1982 the pension was equivalent to 23.5 per cent of average weekly earnings. In March 1986 the pension was equivalent to 23.2 per cent of average weekly earnings. So, despite the promise of the Government to increase the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, the pension has actually fallen as a percentage of average weekly earnings. I am afraid that, unless this Government is prepared to live up to that promise, it will pay the price very dearly at the polls. This issue is certainly causing distress among the many pensioner organisations with which I have frequent communication. This is a disgrace. The Government is engaging in a very mean thing. Sure, it will save a few million dollars, but it could save a lot of money by being a bit more diligent about the way it spends its money in other departments.

I read in the Budget Papers that the Commission for the Future received an increase of about 50 per cent in funding. I noticed in the media the other day that Charles Perkins from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs will have a biography written about him by the Department, at great expense to the taxpayers. The honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has pointed out that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet has granted $5,000 to the National Network of Young Lesbians and Homosexual Men. I happened to see on 60 minutes the other night that Australia is the only government that can afford to send a group of people over to Brussels to represent the prostitutes of this country. We are the only country that can afford to pay for a delegation to go there. Yet we seem not to be able to pay the normal indexed pension rises that this Government should be committed to make. I suggest to the Government and to the Minister while he is in the House that, if they want to live up to the expectations of their supporters and of the pensioner community in Australia, the Minister really ought to say to his colleagues: `Let us axe these hare-brained funding schemes for homosexuals, lesbians, prostitutes, biographies of Charles Perkins and the 50 per cent increase in funding for the Commission for the Future; let us keep our priorities right and give the funding to the people who justly deserve it'.

In regard to people who justly deserve assistance from the Government, there is no greater need than by those who receive veterans' affairs benefits. Over the last 12 months there has been tremendous concern about the way that this Government is running veterans' affairs. If it had not been for people such as the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) and people in my electorate such as Fred Goodfellow and Neil Gage, who have been bringing the point home to the Government, to me and to the rest of the community about the way this Government is treating in a very shabby fashion the veteran and ex-service community, the situation would be far worse than it currently is. It is a disgrace that one of the most recent attempts has been to reduce permanently a war widow's benefit if she earns additional income, even after the additional income source dries up. This Government tried to do that. Fortunately, people within the Australian Labor Party, people from outside the Labor Party and members of the Opposition have been able to keep pressure on the Government not to implement that disgraceful act.

Another thing that the Government has done recently is to palm off to the private health funds the cost of medical and hospital treatment of veterans who are in private health schemes. That is just dishonest. We have a long-standing commitment to our veterans to provide them with health care. The Government has to be prepared to increase the subsidies for nursing homes, to change the priorities for funding and give our pensioners first priority and to live up to our debt to the veteran community to ensure that they are treated in the way that they ought to be treated; that is, with respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1983 the then Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, stood in the Sydney Opera House and made a policy speech on behalf of the Australian Labor Party in which, amongst other things, he made this commitment:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government will not take money out of the pensioners' cheques.

That solemn promise now lies in tatters as, 3 1/2 years down the track, the Hawke socialist Government has waged a bitter war against the grandparents of Australia, has acted contrary to the interests of every pensioner and pensioner dependant in the country and has betrayed over 600,000 Australian veterans and their dependants-those persons having been responsible for serving this country in time of war and defending the freedoms upon which our Australian democracy depends. I cannot believe that the Australian Labor Party has so consistently, deliberately and cruelly maltreated the pensioners of Australia. What I do know is that the pensioners of Australia have woken up to a Prime Minister and a Treasurer who have shown that they are quite prepared, whenever the mood takes them, to act to the disadvantage of the pensioners of this country.

Almost as soon as this Hawke socialist Government was elected to power it moved to impose an income and assets means test on the pensioners, something which was never mentioned in the election campaign speech of the current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). The Government failed to raise the tax threshold of pensioners, as indeed it was due to be raised in accordance with the movements of the consumer price index. The Government has since consistently moved step by step to squeeze the last drop of blood out of the pensioners of Australia. So today in 1986 many pensioners who all their lives have voted for the Australian Labor Party are saying: `Never again'. Many of them are telling me that, for the first time in their lives-and some of them are octogenarians-they will be voting for the Liberal Party of Australia at the next Federal election. The mood in the pensioner community is very strong indeed. My colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who is present in the chamber, has recently been appointed chairman of the Opposition's task force on the elderly, and he will be speaking later in this debate. I cannot, with 20 years experience in Parliament, State and Federal, bring to mind an occasion on which a government has become so hated by people who are normally regarded as its traditional supporters.

In the short time available to me today I want to speak about the proposed disgraceful, unprincipled and shameful action of the Hawke socialist government in seeking to defer the pension increases which are due to every pensioner and beneficiary in Australia on 1 November this year. I speak about that in general terms and, without pre-empting the debate which will undoubtedly take place, I just want to make some observations about the gross impropriety and, I will contend, illegality of what is being sought to be done to Australia's 1 1/2 million pensioners. I believe that the pensioners of Australia should fight this very unprincipled and disgraceful action by the Prime Minister and his Government to defer their pension increases from 1 November with every possible means at their disposal, including even a challenge in the High Court of Australia. I believe that the pensioners of Australia might well find some assistance for their cause if they take the trouble to have a look at the decision of the then Mr Justice Stephen in the High Court of Australia case of Green v. Daniels, which they will find reported in 51 Australian Law Journal Reports at page 463.

That case arose in Tasmania when Karen Christine Green, by her next friend Patricia Ann Truman, brought an action in the High Court of Australia against Mr L. J. Daniels, who was then the Director-General of Social Security. Karen Green was a school leaver. She left school, sought employment and made an application for the unemployment benefit. At that time the Government of the day made a decision that the unemployment benefit would commence to be paid, and the entitlement would arise, only at the end of the school holidays. Karen Green argued that she did not think that was fair because she did not intend just to have school holidays; she was seeking employment in the work force. As I said, she commenced an action by her next friend, Patricia Ann Truman. It was a famous case and, as a matter of interest, His Honour the judge, Mr Justice Stephen, is now, of course, Australia's Governor-General. That case was heard in Melbourne on 4 March, 7 March and 9 March and on 15 April 1977. In the course of the argument, counsel for the Commonwealth argued, amongst other things, that Miss Karen Green had no right to come before the Court seeking relief in the form of declarations which she had sought. I read specifically from the judgment of the Court the passage that appears on page 469. I will read it in full, shortly after which time will unfortunately force me to conclude my remarks. In that judgment reference is made to a then recent High Court case, that of National Insurance Co. of New Zealand Ltd v. Espagne, which was reported in 1961 in 105 Commonwealth Law Reports at page 569. His Honour said:

These authorities were said by the defendants to support, and by the plaintiff to deny, the view that unemployment benefit is no more than a gratuity, to payment of which the plaintiff can have no rights enforceable at law. Equally, say the defendants, the plaintiff has no enforceable rights in relation to the manner in which the Director-General dealt with her claim to unemployment benefit under s. 107.
His Honour Mr Justice Stephen went on to say:

In part, the defendants' submissions were in answer to claims to relief made on behalf of the plaintiff and which went far beyond such declarations as I have foreshadowed. To the extent, however, that they are put as a ground for denying her any right to such declarations they must, I think, be rejected. Her direct personal interest in due compliance by the Director-General with the requirements of s. 107 (c) is clear; upon it depends her eligibility for, and her prospect of obtaining payment of, unemployment benefits. She has what Megarry J. found wanting in Thorne Rural District Council v. Bunting, [1972] Ch. 470, at p. 477, a substantial interest recognized by the law; and if in fact she lacks a cause of action in the strict sense of that term that will not debar her from declaratory relief.
The authority of Rediffusion (Hong Kong) Ltd v. Attorney-General (Hong Kong), (1970) Appeal Cases 1136 at page 1167, is then cited. His Honour went on to say:

The power to give declaratory relief is, as Viscount Radcliffe observed in Ibeneweka v. Egbuna, [1964] 1 W.L.R. 219, at p. 224, conferred in wide and general terms; it is not excluded by the availability of an alternative remedy by way of certiorari.
He then referred to the Pyx case, which I will come back to in a moment, mentioning Lord Goddard's judgment at page 290, saying:
No different considerations should apply when mandamus might lie-see generally Zamir.

This case is interesting, because in the Karen Green case the present Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) argued very strongly that Karen Green had a right to an unemployment benefit-that it was a right, not a gratuity. I say to this Parliament today and to the people of Australia that the 1 1/2 million Australian pensioners have a right to their increase due on 1 November 1986. That right has been accruing for the past six months. It is a vested right; it is a legal entitlement; and, to quote Sir Ninian Stephen, it is `a substantial interest recognised by the law'. These people have been waiting for their increases for the last six months, and I believe that they are being most unjustly treated by a government which is so unprincipled as to take action to force the deferment of their increases due on 1 November. It is a mean, miserable and miserly act in the six weeks leading up to Christmas to take $83 from a married pensioner couple and $53 from a single pensioner. It is the sort of mean and despicable act we have come to expect from this rotten and discredited Government. I invite pensioners to fight this Government tooth and nail, and in particular to look at the Karen Green case to see whether or not there is a similarity, whether there is a locus standi available to the pensioners to drag into the High Court of Australia this discredited Prime Minister, this discredited Treasurer and this discredited Minister for Social Security and make them defend their unprincipled, wicked and thoroughly disgraceful action against pensioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was most interested in the remarks of my learned colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who has always shown a genuine desire, both politically and legally, to help pensioners. His remarks about the Karen Green case should be given close scrutiny. For about 11 years now in this Parliament, I have talked about the plight of the elderly. In my small way I have always tried to be apolitical; I have always tried to put forward the views of the elderly in the hope that changes may be made to help them. We are undergoing a revolution and it is happening before our very eyes. Governments of all persuasions have not taken up the challenge. If one looks at the statistics-it is sometimes difficult to determine whether they are right or wrong-it can be seen that Australia is heading for a zero population level. In the next 10 to 12 years I believe that about 10 to 13 per cent of our total population will be over 75 years of age.

SPEECH.PARA: Those members who are worth their salt and go round their communities and look at the problems of the elderly find that many are experiencing difficulties. There are many things that we should be able to do. Regrettably, some of the most able people in lobby groups for the elderly are dying and lobbying is unable to continue. Sometimes it is the sophisticated lobbies that have all the catch-cries to attract all the goodies, and it is to be regretted that the elderly do not get those goodies. It is up to governments to become more involved. I mentioned to the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, that Australia should have a ministry for the elderly. This will be a massive problem. I continue to ask for such steps to be taken, but governments are governments and have only a certain amount of manpower and finance to direct to their ministries. We all understand that. I have suggested to our present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that we as an opposition should set up a committee or task force to examine the problems of the elderly. If we can bring down good recommendations and if we get back into government, as I hope we will, we may be able to initiate some of those programs. If they are good understandings and good programs, the Government of the day may be able to introduce some of those initiatives.

I cannot believe some of the things I read of late. I refer, for example, to some of the events in Victoria. I am sure that the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) will agree with me that we are unaware of some things that are happening before our eyes. We know that nursing homes generally are being supervised by the Department of Health and by other Commonwealth departments. We know that such homes have to reach a certain standard but, as to some of the other houses, we found it quite horrific to think that some elderly people could be treated in that way. They were treated worse than animals by some of the people who ran those halfway houses, as they are termed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You went there.

—I had a look, but I will not mention that matter in this debate. There will be plenty of time for me to talk about the problems of the elderly, which I shall be doing in due course. It is regrettable that in our society some people have money and some have none. We talk about the socialist dogma that aims at distributing wealth so that everybody will have X number of dollars, but things just do not work that way. Because of their circumstances and other problems some elderly people who reach the age of retirement do not have very much money. That may occur as a result of a number of circumstances, including breakdown of marriage, sickness or many other causes. When they reach that stage they are vulnerable, and they are the people about whom I am particularly worried. We need to seek out those people and help them to the best of our ability. I refer to lonely people, those who cannot get into nursing homes, those who have no children to look after them, those who are sometimes neglected by their children. Many elderly people who need help and assistance die before they can be aided.

SPEECH.PARA: Governments of all persuasions need to become involved with the problems of the elderly. They need to make certain that they dip their hands into some of the dirt in the arena and ensure that they can do something to help. We have an army of unemployed people. Opposition members have spoken of these matters many times. We believe that the energies of unemployed people should be harnessed. I am not referring to dole bludgers-indeed I never use that word-but I stress that it would be most rewarding if the unemployed could be harnessed and used to help the elderly. We hear condemnation of single mothers with little babies. Would it not be good if some of those single mothers could be harnessed to help elderly people? People grow old only when they do not have somebody to look after them, when their minds are inactive and when they have nobody to care for them. Sometimes elderly people become old because they are put in places with other old people, but it would be a great step forward if young people could be integrated with the old. For example, it would be wonderful if a single mother with her baby could look after an elderly person. I am sure that some of the energies of unemployed men also could be harnessed-they would have to be the right type, of course-to help elderly people. I get constant calls from elderly people who live in their own houses. Regrettably, most are women, because men die a lot earlier. Many women who are left behind are most vulnerable. Some cannot drive motor cars, some cannot paint, some cannot do anything at all. Would it not be great if we could harness this great pool of unemployed people, who would be only too keen to help the elderly? Would it not be good if this were not such a selfish world and if we could all help in such circumstances? If that were to happen, this would be a better world to live in. There are many things that can be done.

Regrettably, I must turn to one political point. Most members will recall the great controversy about the half-yearly indexation of pensions. I heard somebody on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation recently saying that it was the Australian Labor Party which introduced half-yearly indexation. That is not true. We introduced such indexation and said that we would make it quarterly. Unfortunately, because of lack of finance, it was introduced half-yearly. Do honourable members recall the continued bombardment the then Government received when Mr Fraser said that we would discontinue the half-yearly indexation of pensions because we could not afford it? Do honourable members remember the political gibes we had to endure? I endured a great deal of it. I copped a lot of controversy from the Labor side as well as from my own side on that decision. People who are on fixed incomes find it difficult to survive. They see the petrol costs rising, costs in the home increasing and so on. An elderly person who can no longer earn money is often in strife.

Honourable members will remember the consternation at the time, but now the Labor Party, because of constraints, has decided to hold back payment of the half-yearly indexation until Christmas. Labor members will cop the blast from Australian pensioners because some can ill afford to hold off that little bit longer to pay their rent, to pay for their food and other items. Labor members, having preached one thing and then changed their minds, will get themselves into a very difficult position. I support the remarks of the honourable member for Denison which, as usual, were put so eloquently. Certainly, at the next election Labor members will feel the wrath of the pensioners, because Labor has not honoured its obligations to pensioners and has not ensured that the pensioners have been supported all the way. It has come up with nothing but baddies instead of goodies for the pensioners of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on social security and community services issues, the alarming issue of the increasing number of people, particularly the young, who are seeking emergency accommodation and food vouchers from government and voluntary welfare agencies, should be raised. Time does not allow me to reflect on or to discuss many of the social and economic factors contributing to this alarming situation. My electorate of Mallee has not escaped these problems. I refer particularly to the position in Mildura which, because of its superb climate and the opportunity for seasonal work, has much the same attraction as the Gold Coast in Queensland. Many young people who are unemployed or who have left home make their way to the Sunraysia district and stay, placing intolerable burdens on welfare support groups and limited government and voluntary financial resources.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer particularly to Emmaus House, an emergency accommodation centre which has assisted 13,259 people in the last 12 months, including the homeless, deserted wives, the unemployed and itinerants. Of those assisted, 68.7 per cent received meals only while 31.3 per cent received both accommodation and meals. While the Government has contributed in part to the establishment of this centre and to the welfare funds, it is only through the dedicated and overworked staff and volunteers and the support of caring and concerned people that the plight of the homeless can be alleviated. Sadly, this agency has now had to take a decision to return welfare funds to the Federal Government and stop providing some of its own aid. This decision has resulted from a decision by the Commonwealth Department of Community Services which issued a letter in which it is stated:

The Minister has recently approved guidelines which state that food vouchers should not be endorsed in any way which restricts the client's freedom of choice (eg `No Alcohol' `No Cigarettes', `No Pet Food'). Only in exceptional circumstances and with the express approval of the Commonwealth Department of Community Services will such practices be sanctioned.

Individuals in some agencies would doubtless like to take things further and to stipulate what they consider to be suitable food or grocery items. Clients seeking emergency relief are in a difficult financial situation as it is without having further undignified limitations placed upon them.
Where agencies feel unable to distribute funds without such limitations, it is open to them to withdraw from the program and allow others to participate.

While understanding and respecting a view that welfare clients should have the right to buy their own choice of food items, surely it is an abuse of public and private funds and a contribution to further social problems if alcohol and cigarettes are allowed to be purchased. I have had a large number of letters from my constituency about this issue and I quote from two. The first says:

As well as being a taxpayer who supports these less fortunate people in their times of need, I willingly give my time through the Uniting Church, to distribute the food vouchers. I will withdraw my support and time if the Government persists with the view that the food vouchers can be spent however the recipient wishes and not on food alone.
The second letter says:

If the vouchers can be used for alcohol and tobacco, then that is what they will be used for. Many of these people can't help themselves. They are so addicted to these drugs that they will choose more drugs instead of food.
They need food and the community is willing to give them food-not easy access to the drugs that have caused their downfall.

This requirement by the Department of Community Services must be removed. We are spending $100m on a drug awareness campaign, millions of dollars on road safety programs and rehabilitation programs for alcohol-related difficulties. It must be the ultimate in double standards that the Commonwealth Department of Community Services is assisting people to buy items that are the two major killers in Australia.

In 1983, 3,198 people died as a result of alcohol-related diseases and accidents and 16,620 died from tobacco-related diseases. There are about 500,000 people who are regarded as alcoholics and at least 1.5 million who suffer to some degree from the effects of alcohol. Admissions to the Mildura Base Hospital with a diagnosis specifying alcohol abuse total about 550 people per year-or 6.5 per cent of all admissions for any average year. I have written to the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) on this issue and he has responded by reiterating and confirming the guidelines issued by his Department.

Welfare workers and donors to this valuable work are dissatisfied because the physical and financial capacity of the excellent program and institution of Emmaus House is being affected. Of course an individual's dignity should be maintained, but surely a food voucher given by the Government or the public should not be so negotiable that a $20 voucher can be used totally for alcohol or cigarettes or even sold for cash in the street to achieve the same results if a food outlet attempts to restrict purchases to food. I believe that it is necessary for an agency to be able to stipulate that no cigarettes or alcohol may be purchased with the vouchers. That is not putting a person down, but is simply providing a safeguard to ensure that emergency relief is used for what is intended-to give clients assistance in necessitous circumstances. In no way can the provision of cigarettes or alcohol be a necessitous circumstance.

Where are the rights of the people who distribute and contribute to emergency relief? Where are the rights of the taxpayer? I believe that such a policy only makes the work so much harder for those who are trying to help and to get people off the destructive welfare roundabout. I simply ask the Minister to look at this issue and consider where an individual's dignity is if he is left to lie in a bus shelter or park at night or to die of malnutrition caused by alcohol. We do have rights, but we also have responsibilities. I believe that the Minister should change the guidelines on this particular issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I crave just one minute of the House's time because it concerns me that a Labor Treasurer should come along and have us believe that he and his colleagues have some kind of monopoly on concern for the needy. This Treasurer (Mr Keating) proudly proclaimed in his Budget Speech that a significant part of the $500m in social security cutbacks, achieved in these appropriations, was to be achieved by deferring six-monthly indexation increases for pensioners. These appropriations reflect not just the broken promises of this Government to pensioners about improvements in benefits; they also reveal the moral blindness, or insensitivity even, in times of economic recession, of spreading sacrifices across all sections of the community, irrespective of the capacity to cope.

SPEECH.PARA: Because the Government has not had the courage to adopt a tougher wages policy, because it has not tackled the Public Service in time and beyond superficialities, and because it will not cut programs already undertaken in the States, it has had to turn to pensioners to make these savings. I believe these appropriations are very unfair and it must embarrass the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) to go before meetings such as that with the Committee for Economic Development of Australia in September, as he did, and admit that his success in making savings has been in the area of benefits to pensioners, veterans and families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members who have contributed to the debate. I will be very brief and refer only to one or two comments that were made on a range of issues. I particularly wish to pick up the concern raised by the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) about the new procedures for interviews of class A widows and supporting parents. The honourable member made the point that there was something inhumane about widows having to report to the Department of Social Security soon after the deaths of their husbands. I make it clear that de jure widows will not have to make a statement about their circumstances until six months after the grant. Nevertheless, they will be required to come to the Department, or to regional offices of the Department, for an interview after three months. That is necessary so that the Department is sure that people have been made fully aware of their rights with respect to the social security system. It is sometimes the case that people within pension beneficiary populations simply are not aware of what is open and available to them, not only through the Department of Social Security but also through other government departments. The purpose of that interview after three months is to ensure that widows are aware of their rights. It is only after six months that they are required to provide a statement of their circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally people on both sides of the chamber would welcome the measures with respect to reporting requirements for supporting parent beneficiaries as a whole. It is important that people have the opportunity to receive from the Department on a regular basis advice and counselling on information that may be relevant to them. It is important also that the Department is in a position to verify the circumstances of a group of people whose circumstances often change.

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) referred to veterans and war widows and suggested that they would be denied choice of doctor. There is no compulsion on veterans' affairs beneficiaries to take out private health insurance. However, where they have chosen to take insurance, the benefit may be assigned to the Department where the treatment has been arranged through the Department. The measures that operate within that area are not designed to deny people choice of doctor or to impose additional costs on people.

I refer finally to the usual emotional remarks made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) and the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck), who made various references to the Government's attitude to the aged and pensioner populations. In the 1978-79 Budget the previous Government announced the elimination of biannual indexation and proposed annual indexation, and there was no indexation increase in May 1979. The present Government has made in this Budget a number of savings, one of which is the deferment for six weeks of the indexation increases in November this year and in May next year. That decision involves a significant saving. The Government is aware that that decision will be uncomfortable for a number of people; nevertheless, it is a decision which flowed from the very tight economic circumstances in which the Government found itself in relation to framing this year's Budget.

With respect to the level of pensions as compared with average weekly earnings, since we have been in Government there has been a significant increase in the percentage, which was around 23 per cent when we came into government and currently stands at 24 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Government retains its commitment to achieving 25 per cent of average weekly earnings and in the next 12 months we would expect to see some movement towards that objective of 25 per cent.

In terms of the debate which has taken place on the appropriations, it is quite clear that this year's Budget is a very tight Budget. Both sides of the House recognise that this Budget had to be tough and that if we were to have a tight, tough Budget, we had to make expenditure restraints, particularly in areas such as social security and health, which take a very high proportion of Commonwealth expenditure. The measures taken in this Budget have been chosen with some sensitivity. For the most part the measures are designed to ensure the integrity of the social security system and are welcomed by people on both sides of the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address remarks to the appropriations for both the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Special Minister of State. At the outset I wish to make some comments in regard to a controversy, of which honourable members will be aware, in relation to the showing of an anti-drug film-produced by the Department of Foreign Affairs, incidentally-proposed to be shown on Qantas Airways Ltd flights. Some time ago I took the opportunity of travelling from Sydney to Melbourne to view the original film and I was able to make some suggestions in terms of what I believe to be improving the efficacy of that anti-drug film. Honourable members will be aware that the film is designed to warn mainly young Australians travelling abroad of the very great dangers of harsh drug laws in a range of countries, most particularly countries in our immediate neighbourhood.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past I have had the unfortunate duty to travel to a number of gaols around the world to interview Australian prisoners in them. Of course, this issue is not confined to Australians, because the gaols throughout Asia, for example, have a lot of Australians in them as well as people from all over the world. It is a sad fact that in some of these countries it is possible to be detained for extremely lengthy periods for what in Australia would constitute relatively minor drug offences. For example, I met in Indonesia a young Australian who had been apprehended in possession of two grams of marihuana. That subsequently resulted in him initially being a given a gaol sentence of seven years with hard labour. The Indonesian prosecution had called for that sentence to reviewed and was seeking an increase in the sentence to some 10 years. Of course, this is in sharp contrast to the types of laws applying in most countries similar to our own. It is probably not exaggerating to say that in Australia possession of 2 grams of marihuana would simply not be worth the police proceeding with and there is a general move towards relaxation of laws in this regard.

It was with some sadness that I noted the response of Qantas to the suggestion that this film be shown on board its outward bound flights. Its argument is that the film is inconsistent with what its passengers would desire. When we have not only potential gaol sentences of the order that I have indicated but also in some countries, death penalties applying to the possession of a whole range of drugs, including what we would nominate as relatively harmless drugs, I think it is incumbent upon Qantas to address not only the commercial aspects but also the responsibilities it has as Australia's national carrier.

One of the surprising things that I found in talking to people who have been incarcerated is that, whilst obviously we will have some real villains in terms of the drug trade, the overwhelming number of people caught up in this environment are people who have been caught in possession of very minor amounts of relatively harmless drugs. By and large, they are simply unaware that these small amounts of drugs can lead to this result. They are certainly aware, particularly since the execution of Barlow and Chambers in Malaysia, that hard drugs such as heroin attract a death penalty. My concern is that they are yet to understand that these minor offences can also lead to very serious results. I place on record my disappointment with Qantas. I will be approaching the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris) and asking for his intervention in trying to ensure that Qantas adopts the responsible attitude that this Government and, I think most members of this chamber, believe that it should adopt. (Quorum formed)
I am disappointed that the Opposition seeks to interrupt a speech, particularly when that speech is related to a very serious drug problem amongst young Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not care.

—I do not think the Opposition cares and I am very disappointed with that. In any event, I will move from that issue and address a few remarks to a more parochial one. I will have to take off my statesmanlike mantle and become a local politician for one or two moments. Honourable members will be aware that, unfortunately, on 3 September 1986 an air ambulance crashed in my electorate with the loss of some six lives. I raise this issue because I have argued for a long time that a disused quarry in my electorate is an appropriate site for an international garden festival. This disused quarry is currently owned by the Boral company. It has a contractual relationship with Whelan the Wrecker Pty Ltd, which wished to use the quarry as a hard refuse dump. I have sought and obtained the intervention of the Department of Aviation in the planning process to ensure that the argument is put that it ought not to be used for this purpose. I have done this because of the demonstrable danger presented by carrion birds attracted to such a tip to the quite intense air traffic emanating from both Tullamarine and Essendon airports.
—It is one of the best tips I have ever seen.

—I agree with the Minister. He has taken a great interest in this issue and we are hoping to work together to achieve the results that I have referred to. In the context of the aircraft crash, one of my constituents advised me that, because the wind was blowing in a particular direction, the air ambulance took off from Essendon Airport consistent with that weather pattern. Had that air ambulance taken off from any one of the other three options available to it, and having regard to the distance that the aircraft covered before crashing, it is likely that it would have landed on the Pascoe Vale State Primary School, the Essendon High School or the Essendon Grammar School.
—Or my house.

—Yes. Obviously, living in my electorate right under the flight paths, this is a matter of some concern to me also. I do not treat this matter lightly. It is a very important issue. The Essendon Airport role review study by the Department of Aviation is approaching finalisation, and a number of other issues have been addressed by members of this chamber in terms of noise pollution and so on. I simply place on record my view that, unless the Essendon Airport role review study seriously addresses as a possible option the closure of the Essendon Airport, I will be seeking intervention to ensure that that is properly investigated.
