SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inevitably in this debate, I am concerned about the efficient expenditure of government funds, or taxpayers' funds, as they should be more appropriately termed. In relation to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet there are three areas where I fear that that expenditure is being conducted in a manner which is not in the best interests of the Australian taxpayer but which perhaps in some respects is in the best interests of the present Government. Those three areas relate to youth affairs, women's affairs and official establishments, which are inhabited primarily by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: This year there is an appropriation of $5.7m for youth affairs. There is no doubt that youth issues in Australia need to be addressed by the community and there is probably some role for the Government in addressing them. In the towns of Mount Barker and Murray Bridge in my electorate there are very real problems for young people and I, as local member of parliament for that district, would like to feel that, at the very least, I was able to do something to address those problems. Unfortunately, when it comes to the Federal Government's youth programs, under its so-called Priority One plan, we can see little more than a substantial wastage of taxpayers money on what is little more than a cynical, vote-grabbing, attention-seeking promotion. Until 23 April this year-these are the latest figures I have available-the Federal Government spent $2.2m not on helping young people, not on developing programs to help those people get access to work or build their confidence or improve their training, but on nothing more than promotion of the fact that the Government apparently had a Priority One program.

When one looks at the way that money was spent it really is extremely unattractive, bearing in mind that it is taxpayers' money. Nearly $600,000 was spent on Press advertisements; nearly $12,000 on television commercials; $160,000 on cinema commercials; $243,000 on billboard posters; $85,000 on pamphlets; $3,000 on T-shirts and sweatshirts; $24,000 on yet other promotional material; $1m on something called a phone-in; $46,000 plus $815 in expenses on the salary of Mr Steedman, who is a former member of this House and who is supposed to be drawing up this empty Priority One program; $55,000 on an address to the nation by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to tell everybody he had a Priority One program; and $32,000 on advertisements which said that the Prime Minister would speak on local radio stations hither and thither to tell people that Priority One existed.

I would have thought everybody in Australia would be disgusted to learn that over $2m had been wasted on all that promotion, yet practically nothing had been done in a constructive sense for young people under Priority One. After all, we were told that under Priority One 10,000 new traineeships would be created by June 1986. The reality is that by that time only 2,000 had been created, of which only 58 were in the private sector. So the youth affairs vote has already proved to be a very substantial waste of money and a deliberate effort by the Government to promote its own political programs and nothing more.

That also applies to a number of other programs coming under the appropriations of the Prime Minister's Department. Let us take the Office of the Status of Women. I do not have any objection to having some sort of office within the bureaucracy to look at women's issues, although it has to be said that the existence of this office is really little more than a symbolic gesture. It is interesting to note how totally unco-ordinated the Government's so-called women's programs are. There is the Office of the Status of Women in the Prime Minister's Department; recently it set up some sort of affirmative action agency; and it has in the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations a women's bureau. I would have again thought that it would be sensible if the Government were to co-ordinate its women's policies under one agency rather than spread them amongst three and therefore run the risk of having not only an unco-ordinated program but also an expensive one.

Some of the programs of the Office of the Status of Women, I must say, have been particularly unscientific and I suspect once more that they are directed towards vote winning rather than very much else. The Government said it wanted to find out the attitudes and concerns of women in Australia. It should have followed the lead of its `what women think' opinion poll survey, which was carried out by Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls Pty Ltd, of course-the firm that does the polling for the Australian Labor Party. It received $70,000 for that poll. Lo and behold, soon after that poll the Government came out with something called the National Agenda for Women, which involves printing hundreds of thousands of pamphlets and sending them all over Australia in order to assess the attitudes of women. If the Government were serious about finding out what women in Australia think-there is nothing wrong with finding that out-it would use its mates at the ANOP to do it. That is the way the Labor Party finds out information in general for its own advantage and that of the Government as well. It did not do that; it chose instead some wasteful national agenda program, the advantage being that it would gain much more publicity throughout the community so that the Government would be seen to be doing more in the community to help women, and not genuinely trying to get information on women's attitudes. In other words, that program is little more than a waste of money.

I point to one other waste of money or inappropriate expenditure of money by the Office of the Status of Women. That is the $5,000 grant it gave to the Movement for the Ordination of Women in the Anglican Church. I would most certainly not involve myself as a member of parliament in that extremely delicate doctrinal and theological debate within one of the major churches of Australia. The Government, however, is in breach of the spirit, if not the letter, of the Australian Constitution. If one read the constitutional debates-I can clearly establish that some members opposite have not-one would see that the spirit of the Constitution is to separate the church from the state. The Government has done the reverse through this grant to the movement for the ordination of women. A government has involved itself for the first time in Australia's history in a doctrinal and theological issue which should ultimately be a matter of conscience, not a matter for the long-suffering taxpayers' pockets.

In the last two or three minutes left to me I want to refer to expenditure on official establishments, which particularly relates to expenditure on the Lodge and Kirribilli House. The appropriation this year is for one and a quarter million dollars which, I note, represents an increase of 12 per cent. Any pensioner or any other social security beneficiary in the community who has been hit hard by so-called cuts will note, I suspect, that there has been a 12 per cent increase in spending on the Lodge and Kirribilli House. Much of that expenditure has, at the very least, been entirely inappropriate at a time when we are told by the Prime Minister that we are in a virtual state of war. A quarter of a million dollars was spent just last year on redecorating the Lodge so that it looks as though it was decorated in 1927-two years before the great crash. About $50,000 a room was spent on redecorating the Lodge, which is about as much as the average Australian would pay for a family home. Between $80,000 and $90,000 was spent just on soft furnishings. The total renovations bill, for soft furnishings, curtains and so on, was about $103,000. All I am saying about that is that it is in pretty bad taste when the Government is calling for restraint. As far as the Lodge is concerned, I ask just one question which I am sure the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) will be able to answer easily. This matter came up before the Senate Estimates Committee. Why is it that the expenditure on the Lodge's telephone account this financial year will be double that of last year?

I note that half a million dollars is being spent on renovations at Kirribilli House as well. This never seems to end. Kirribilli House is supposed to be a residence not of the Prime Minister but for guests of the Commonwealth. The Prime Minister has not only taken it over but also, according to an officer of his Department before the Senate Estimates Committee, had instructed, as urgent and essential, the expenditure of half a million dollars on renovations to Kirribilli House-renovations which were first recommended in 1979 by the Official Establishments Trust. The Prime Minister instructed that these were urgent and essential when he was telling Australians that they should be tightening their belts as this was a time of great economic restraint.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the Special Minister of State.
—Moscow Mick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —The poor old Tasmanian tiger has to wait again.
—That is all right. We are still surviving despite rigged boundaries.

—I know; the honourable member is doing very well. I thought I should answer some of the things that have been raised in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986 relating to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Special Minister of State. Firstly, I do not think any substantive answer is required to the question posed by the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). Unfortunately, he lacks a little understanding of what official establishments are about. I take it from the contribution he made that he thinks they ought to be demolished, that we really should not have them, and that we should not spend the money keeping them in order so that they can be used, as they are used extensively by anybody who is in government, to entertain people who visit us as official guests, whether it be at the Lodge or at Kirribilli House. Compared with official establishments in most other countries that the honourable member or I or any other member of parliament has visited, in many ways they are quite modest; they are not built to any grand scheme and they do not provide the facilities which one would expect of a nation such as Australia. That may be a problem for us in the years to come.

SPEECH.PARA: We had an open day at the new Parliament House on Sunday. Over 20,000 people from around New South Wales came by bus to have a look at it. I am sure many would have been critics before they arrived, but not many were critics after they left. I think most people in Australia will be very proud of the new national Parliament and what it represents. It will be there for a long time. Many generations of Australians will serve in it. It is the same with the Lodge and Kirribilli. Each administration has a duty to make sure they are kept in proper order. The longer these things are put off, the more they cost. I suspect the honourable member for Mayo thinks we should cut all our grants to the Literature Board and the Arts Council of Australia, that when times are tough we should not have ballet or opera, or books being written-we should save all that money-and then numbskulls such as the honourable member for Mayo could have all their mates, such as Andrew Hay, putting their policies forward. That is not the way this Government operates. Even at a time of restraint we are still servicing a nation and we still have a responsibility to see that these things are done.

When this debate started some attention was paid to the responsibilities of the Special Minister of State regarding the National Crime Authority and the Australian Federal Police. I would like to respond to some of the comments that were made. The honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) suggested in his contribution that perhaps I was politicising the National Crime Authority. I do not think that there is any evidence at all that would suggest or give any basis to a claim that, since the National Crime Authority has been established, I or anybody else associated with the National Crime Authority have been attempting to politicise its operations. It has been an extremely successful unit which has been established to combat organised crime in this country. It involves the participation of the national Government and all State governments on the intergovernmental committee. I am continually asked about whether matters will be raised with the National Crime Authority or whether they are under investigation by the National Crime Authority. The answers that I give always come from the National Crime Authority. I do not personally pass on matters that I think ought to be investigated; it is always a question of matters being raised by other agencies. So there was no substantive point in the contribution made by the honourable member for North Sydney.

The other thing that ought to be said about the National Crime Authority-this is of enormous importance when one talks about the resources that have been given over by this Government in the fight against organised crime in this country-is that approximately $13m will be spent on it. When that is added to the other moneys which have been made available to the Australian Federal Police, honourable members can see our contribution in just over three years has been vastly superior to the contribution in terms of views and resources that was given by the former Fraser Government. The National Crime Authority plays an important role in the fight against organised crime. People observing the success it is having and the organisational co-operation we are getting from all the law enforcement agencies and from government all around Australia can see that the impact of the National Crime Authority is really going to be worth while.

The honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) raised a question he has raised in the House before about overtime worked by the Australian Federal Police and about a very small amount of crack, as it is termed-a new drug-that has been found in Australia. He suggested that the police did not work all the overtime required to detect this drug and therefore the drug was lost. I take it that he was suggesting that the seizure was not concluded. That is not true; the seizure was concluded. It was not a large shipment; it was a very small amount that came through the mail. In terms of overtime of the Australian Federal Police, as I have said in the Parliament before, it is true that, because of a number of events that have taken place in the eastern region, on a pro rata basis it was, and is still, as I understand it, ahead of its spending on overtime this year. That is not true of the total AFP force which, on a pro rata basis, is slightly behind in its spending allocation for 1986-87; nevertheless, it is true of the eastern region.

The honourable member also suggested that perhaps the fact that some of the AFP cars interstate did not have blue lights indicated an inadequacy. I do not know whether he was suggesting that cars being used by the police for surveillance purposes should have blue lights on top so that everyone can see them. I can assure him that I am not a court of appeal for decisions made by the Commissioner of Police. They are decisions quite properly and rightly made by the Commissioner of Police. People do not appeal to me on the decisions he is making. That is not a relationship that could be sustained at all. If the Commissioner of Police and his senior officers have decided on a certain policy in these areas the police force will have to abide by it until the people who are held responsible for making these decisions decide otherwise.

A lot of other issues have been raised about the powers of the police and the way they should be operating in Australia. The honourable member for Gilmore seemed to think that a simple method available to the Parliament to improve the situation would be to allow admission of illegally obtained evidence and to grant all sorts of extra powers to the police. I am not too sure that people trained in the law would agree with all the views he expressed about how simple it is to do these things. Nevertheless, they are matters that can be discussed and debated in the Parliament and by people outside the Parliament who have a very strong view on some of these questions.

In terms of the administration of our law enforcement agencies at a Federal level, I would say without any hesitation at all that they are in better shape now than possibly they have ever been. This is not all due to this Government, but is certainly due in very large measure to the resources we have put in and to the recognition of and exposure given to organised crime in this country by a series of royal commissions which have laid the scenario for deciding the areas to which our Federal Police ought to be giving top priority. We set down new objectives for the police in 1985. We have given them resources within the context of the total expenditure of this Government. Funding for the police can never be unlimited, just as it can never be unlimited for any area of government activity. In the three years since we have been in office there has been a 21 per cent increase in the manpower of the Australian Federal Police. We have now established and consolidated the role of the National Crime Authority. We are getting complete co-operation from all the State law enforcement agencies. We have in place a very strong, very good and certainly very beneficial number of intelligence liaison officers from the Australian Federal Police spread in a number of countries around the world. We are giving a great deal of assistance, through both expertise and money, to the Narcotics Board in Thailand to assist it in its fight against drugs. I think the things we are doing in a positive sense far outstrip some of the minor criticisms that have been made during this debate.

As I said, the honourable member for Mayo did not raise anything in my area, but what he did raise in terms of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet was very minor. He was critical of the fact that we are trying to attack the problems that affect youth affairs and the Office of the Status of Women from the Prime Minister's Department. These are areas of considerable concern to this Government. I do not think that any previous government has given such enormous consideration and thought to the problems of women in this country. Our legislation on affirmative action and the statements on the impact on women of Budgets from year to year are considerable documents and ones which are sought eagerly by people who are active in women's affairs around this country. We do not apologise in any way for the role we have played in those matters. Also, we have tackled some of the massive problems that we have been confronted with on youth affairs in this country. As honourable members would know, they are not easily solved problems. One does not have to be a parliamentarian to understand the massive problems confronting young people in this country. One of the great inadequacies of the system of payments to youth we inherited was that no doubt young people were leaving school before they had completed their education because there was a certain attraction to the economic advantage that came from being eligible for the unemployment benefits if they were not entitled to any allowance in the education system. This Government has tried to tackle that problem by making young people focus on the importance of completing their education.

We all know that one of the reasons our youth unemployment figures stand in contrast with the figures of many other countries is the dropout rate from our educational institutions-a rate of which we should all be ashamed. Turning that around in the short term is a massive task but attacking it by making allowances available through secondary schools and colleges will make more young people focus on the necessity, and give them the financial ability, to complete their education. That is an important role for Australia as we go into the twenty-first century. If we had continued with the old policies all we would have seen is more and more young people drop out of school, we would have had a totally inadequate work force to deal with the problems we will be confronted with, we would have had a massive number of unemployed and we would have had a disillusioned army of young people for generations to come, and once that situation had become consolidated it would have been almost impossible to do anything about it.

So, yes, we have placed great emphasis on women and on youth. They are two areas about which the Australian community expects us to be concerned. The Prime Minister's Department has played a primary role; it has been in the vanguard of the promotion of these policies. We still have a long way to go. During Parliament's week off a fortnight ago I visited nine high schools in Port Adelaide and spoke to 1,400 students. They had a lot of questions about the way they have been served by parliamentarians in this country, and they did not necessarily mean just Labor parliamentarians. They do not think they have been well served by governments over the first few years and they have a lot of questions they want answered. In some ways we are trying to give them the answers, particularly answers which will keep them in education. As the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) has pointed out over the years, that is one of the ways in which we can enable them to fulfil some of the ambitions they have for when they enter the work force or give them entry into the work force, at least, because they will have extra educational skills. In those areas this Government makes no apology at all. I do say, of course, that we have a long way to go in Australia to fulfil some of the ambitions young people have.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble is that you blew it last night at dinner and you are trying to get yourself off the hook. You are a third-rate performer.
—Order! The honourable member for Melbourne knows that interjections are out of order, and he is not in his correct place in the chamber, to start with.

So far has the Hawke Government retreated from the eminently balanced and sensible statement made by the Foreign Minister in May 1984 that we now have the ridiculous position of the Hawke Government taking a more hostile attitude towards the strategic defence initiative than just about any of the major Western powers. I think that is a position which is against the interests of the Australian people. It is certainly a position which is against the interests of the Western alliance and it is a position which has been exposed as quite ridiculous by the outcome of the meeting between Mr Gorbachev and President Reagan.

SPEECH.PARA: I would warmly exhort the Prime Minister to read what the honourable member for Oxley, the Foreign Minister, had to say about the strategic defence initiative on 29 May 1984. He cannot escape it. There is nothing quite like the ringing declaration being quoted back at one. In another context we remember ringing declarations about there not being a capital gains tax and about not changing this or that, but we are not talking about that at the moment. We are talking about the fact that in May of last year the Foreign Minister was willing to say that the strategic defence initiative had a highly moral purpose. I think he was right then; he is still right and the present stance being taken by the Prime Minister and the Government is completely wrong.

It is very important that the people who oppose President Reagan's strategic defence initiative not be allowed to fix the blame for the breakdown of the Reykjavik summit on the support of that program by the Reagan Administration. The reality is that the Soviet Union and its leader went to the negotiating table in Geneva partly because of the insistence of President Reagan on developing the strategic defence initiative. I put it to the Committee, first, that, if the Reagan Administration had not taken that attitude, there would not have been any super-power talks in the first place, let alone the discussion that took place in Iceland last week. Secondly, I put it to the Committee that the Soviet Union went to that meeting in Reykjavik fully aware that the strategic defence initiative was non-negotiable. It was made perfectly clear by the Reagan Administration from the very word go that, if the Soviet Union imagined that in response to the offers put on the table the United States would be prepared to bargain away the strategic defence initiative, that simply was not on. All along, the President and his Administration have made it perfectly clear that they will not deviate from that position.

There is a strange paradox from those who oppose the concept of a strategic defence initiative. On the one hand, they argue that the basis for their opposition is that it is scientifically implausible; in other words they say that they are against it because it can never be made to work and therefore it should not be contemplated. That is one leg of their argument. But, on the other hand, they argue that the conduct of the research is immensely destabilising.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not consistent.

—Of course they are not consistent. The very fact that the Soviet Union chose to invoke the strategic defence initiative as a reason for not consumating an arms agreement at the Iceland summit underlines the inconsistency of those who oppose the initiative. On the one hand, they say that it is scientifically implausible and therefore a totally ridiculous proposition and, on the other hand, the Soviets and others invoke it as a reason for not going ahead with an arms limitation agreement. The reality is that strategic research has been taken very seriously by the Soviet Union. It has been conducting strategic research for a period of up to 20 years. It is very strange that people in governments around the world argue that there is something wrong or something immoral about the United States conducting strategic research when over the last 15 to 20 years the Soviet Union has been conducting the same amount of research.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs was right when he said in May 1984 that the concept behind the strategic defence initiative is a highly moral one. Ultimately, if the strategic defence initiative proved plausible and successful, it would provide a defensive non-nuclear alternative to the existing balance of terror based on offensive nuclear weapons. I quote the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs in May 1984 when he said that the goal of the strategic defence initiative is:
. . . to seek to replace the doctrine of assured destruction, based on attack with a morally much more acceptable concept of assured defence.

The words of the Foreign Minister on that occasion were right. They are still right. I could not put it better. I just repeat the request that I made to the Prime Minister on behalf of the Opposition that, particularly in light of the circumstances of the breakdown of the summit at Iceland, the Government reconsider its absurd position of hostility and opposition to the development of the strategic defence initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In looking at the estimates for the Department of the Treasury, I take the opportunity to draw attention to the extraordinary reversion, in the behaviour of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to his pre-banana republic mode. Honourable members will recall when it first appeared that the economy was running into trouble and when the Treasurer's economic strategy was beginning to show some signs of wear and tear. This became evident more than a year ago and indeed was mentioned in part of the Budget Papers of last year but was somewhat hidden. It became very evident with the September balance of payments figures and then the really dreadful October figures. When the inflation figures for the September quarter were very bad-more than 7 per cent-and when a 3.8 per cent wage increase was announced in October and there was a big plunge in the dollar, it was very clear to everyone except the Treasurer that the Australian economy was running into substantial trouble. However, the Treasurer continued to tell the Australian people and the financial markets of the world that everything in the Australian garden was lovely. He said that the economy was right on track. I have dozens of quotations from the Treasurer, and also the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who was limping along behind him with his statements over that period, which show that he was misleading the Australian public and the world financial markets about the true state of the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: This continued right up to 9 May this year, when the Treasurer made a statement to the Economic Planning Advisory Council, which is the key economic advisory body to this Government, saying that everything was all right and the domestic economy was so strong that it would be able to deal with some acknowledged external difficulties. That was a very confident statement made by the Treasurer on 9 May this year. Then, on 13 May, only a few days later, the balance of payments figures for April came out and they showed a deficit on the current account of $1.5 billion. It was the biggest deficit since the previous October, when the figure reached $1.6 billion. It hit the Treasurer between the eyes. On the following day, he went on the John Laws radio program and, in a state of panic, informed the Australian public for the first time that the country was heading towards the status of a banana republic. Right up to this time the Hawke Government and all its Ministers were telling everyone that everything was perfectly all right, that the economic strategy laid down at the National Economic Summit in April 1983 was perfectly correct and that there was no need to worry about anything. Then suddenly, on 14 May, there was total panic and a total change of message.

All sorts of things started to happen. The Prime Minister decided that there would be an address to the nation. He asked for supreme sacrifices, declaring that the state of the economy was akin to the country being in a state of war. Unfortunately, that call did not fall on very receptive ears in the Waterside Workers Federation because it closed down the docks for a week about a week after the Prime Minister had called for effort and sacrifice. I merely give this example to show that, from exhibiting total confidence in the face of a deteriorating economic situation, which had been known for months and months, the Government went to a state of total panic. It rang all the alarm bells, but it did not do anything. It did not stop the wage case or have a mini-Budget to cut expenditures or anything like that, but it created a great sense of alarm.

The award was published as Mr Keating was lecturing in the United States on the shortcomings of its economic policy at the International Monetary Fund Conference in Washington.

If we want the true state of the economy we have only to look at the figures. The current account deficit for the September quarter was up 19 per cent on last year and, worse still, the merchandise trade deficit for the quarter was up by 79 per cent. Total overseas debt will reach $100 billion by the end of the financial year, absorbing 40c of each export dollar in debt servicing costs. Inflation, at 8.4 per cent, is over four times that of our major trading partners. Interest rates of 19 per cent or more are still being charged to businesses and farms. The accord has collapsed and no new wages policy is in sight. Investment is at a standstill because of the loss of confidence arising from high taxes, high inflation and high interest rates. The Treasurer's gambling analogy of the slot machine is singularly appropriate. He began his treasurership gambling Australia's future on world commodity markets and he lost. Now he reverts to his earlier mode of excessive optimism and he will not get away with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating the estimates of the Department of Finance and the Department of the Treasury I wish to address my remarks to the Budget strategy that these departments have helped to formulate. This Budget, more than any other, sets the parameters for a new direction in the Australian economy. Australia has experienced a dramatic decline in both its terms of trade and its balance of payments. The most important aspect of this Budget is the responsible way in which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been able to reduce the Budget deficit. This reduction has been brought about by sharing the burden equitably. The reaction within my electorate has been the most positive since our election in March 1983. Nothing illustrates this more than the fact that the Opposition in the days and weeks following the Budget has abandoned any pretext of an alternative economic strategy. For the first time in Australian political history we have an Opposition with no alternative economic, wages or fiscal policies. Its only panacea for economic recovery is some vague reference to freeing up the labour market.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been outlined in the Treasurer's Budget Speech, Australia's industrial system is now the most flexible in its history. Under the accord, the trade union movement has shown unprecedented wage restraint. The Government, the unions and business are working together and it is only the Opposition and the lunatics of the New Right who are advocating confrontation. Even that most strident critic of all things federal, the Premier of Queensland, Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen, has been noticeable for his silence on the Budget brought down by the Treasurer. Perhaps he is the most disappointed political leader in Australia, since he was to base his re-election strategy on attacking the Federal Budget. It is now appropriate that the people of Queensland will be able to show all Australia that they expect State governments to adopt rational economic policies. I certainly hope that they will do this when the election is held on 1 November.

The problems facing us in redressing the balance of payments are not without their difficulties. It is to the Government's credit that it has tackled these problems in the Budget. Australian industry must become more competitive if it is to survive in today's world trading environment. The devaluation associated with the floating of the Australian dollar has given Australian industry its most competitive environment for decades. There are now new markets available for Australian companies prepared to have a go. As a member of the country task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), it is with pleasure that I report to the chamber that the task force has seen at first hand Australia gearing up. The difficulty is to do this quickly after the disastrous policies of the Fraser-Howard Government destroyed much of the manufacturing base in the induced recession of 1982.

Australia's traditional export industries have suffered massive downturns in the price that the world is prepared to pay for its products. Examples were outlined by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech, but it is worth reiterating some of those once more: The price of wheat has fallen from $US181.90 a tonne in 1980-81 to $US103 per tonne. The price of sugar has fallen from $US390 a tonne in 1981 to $US122 per tonne. The price of barley has fallen from $US148.27 a tonne in 1982 to $US71.77 per tonne. The price of coal has fallen from $US54.85 a tonne in 1981-82 to $US38.72 per tonne. The price of iron ore has fallen from $US21.90 a tonne in 1982 to $US16.10 per tonne. So the story goes on across a whole range of exports. (Quorum formed) I thank my colleagues for their undivided attention. I am sure that they will stay in the chamber now and listen to a fine speech. I was saying, before I was interrupted by the unnecessary calling of a quorum, that the coalition while in government, with the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) as its Treasurer, refused to float the Australian dollar on the advice of that well-known member of the New Right, Mr John Stone, the former head of the Treasury. It is no wonder that his term as head of the Federal Treasury is now referred to as the stone age.

The Government could have adopted easier options in this Budget and increased taxation across the board as well as abandoning the promised tax cuts. It rejected these approaches outright. It has cut real spending growth to zero and the deficit has been dramatically brought back to the levels of the late 1950s and early 1960s. This Budget is therefore anti-inflationary as it will not be calling on the nation's savings to fund its programs. These measures should ensure that, in the medium to long term, interest rates will be reduced. This will be achieved whilst maintaining stable currency so that Australia can plan for the future.

There has been a body of opinion about that there are alternatives to the current economic strategy. I totally reject these alternatives. The first option proposed is that the Government should do nothing but, unfortunately, that would fix nothing. The consequences of this option would be that our export income would stay low, the value of the Australian dollar would steadily fall and inflation would rise. The economy would collapse into deep recession, forcing many more Australians on to dole queues. This would mean obviously that Australians would import less and our trade problems would be solved. This method was used to a large degree by the Fraser-Howard Government in 1982, but it was compounded by artificially maintaining a high level for the Australian dollar. The worst problem of this option is that it would do nothing to reorganise our economy so that in future we would be less of a hostage to world commodity prices.

The second option is to unfloat the Australian dollar and introduce further barriers against imports. The problem with this option is that our export prices would still be low and the trade imbalance would still exist because we could not expect our trading partners to continue to import Australian goods whilst we excluded their products. Furthermore, instead of our exchange rate moving to make allowances for this problem, the adjustment would show up either in massive government borrowings overseas or in a massive outflow of capital inducing a credit squeeze. Such a credit squeeze would bring about crippling high interest rates and a collapse of the economy, with no end in sight of the fundamental problems of our trade imbalance.

None of these options present Australia with any fundamental changes that will bring about long term prosperity. If this nation is to have steady economic growth, as opposed to the booms and busts during the long dark years of Liberal rule, the integrity of the Treasurer's Budget must be maintained. The Federal Budget, however, is only one part of the economic management of Australia. Each of the State governments also needs to play a role in the economic development of our nation. Unfortunately, in my State of Queensland, we have an incompetent Government, increasingly scandal-ridden, led by an aging Premier who is out of touch with reality.

It is important in this debate to indicate how much mismanagement of the Queensland economy is dragging down economic growth nationwide. Queensland has the highest unemployment rate of any State in Australia at 9.4 per cent. It has the lowest average weekly male earnings at $396-some 7 per cent below the Australian average. It has the lowest rate of job vacancies of any State at 0.5 per cent. Queensland has the second highest rate of industrial disputation of any State. It has the second lowest number of overtime hours per employee. I cite these facts to illustrate that the National Party Government of Queensland is seriously hindering the economic development of this nation. Economic surveys have shown that the financial sector in Queensland has been unable to grow because of its low education standard, particularly relating to computer technology. Contrary to the Queensland Government's constant argument-- The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN (Mr Mountford)-Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The estimates for the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance and the Advance to the Minister for Finance are merely Budget strategies in their figuring and in their appropriations. The problem is that those targets have to be met. Looking back at the history of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in office, everybody should be concerned. Last year the Treasurer created an expectation of a tough Budget. He actually leaked to the Press that there would be a $5,500m deficit. Whilst the Press had gone into raptures about the fact that there might be a $5,500m deficit, the Treasurer announced in his Budget Speech that there would be a $4,900m deficit. The Press was overly enraptured because that target had been met or that expectation had been given to the people of Australia. The media have been known to be gullible before and they are not very quick to correct a situation later. Whilst they said that the reduction of the Budget deficit to $4,900m was a marvellous achievement and a tremendous result, we found at the end of that financial year that what turned out to be merely a guesstimate ended up as a deficit of close to $6,500m if we took into account the extra money that came from the Reserve Bank of Australia. So the Treasurer is not a great Treasurer. He might be considered a brilliant fiction writer. He is certainly not an economic guru but perhaps he could be classed as a disciple of deception. Where was the media criticism? Where was the closer analysis from the Press?
—Order! I ask the honourable member to withdraw that statement.
—Which one?
—`A disciple of deception'.

—`A disciple of deception'? I withdraw. Where was the media criticism when the Budget overran to such a degree? Surely a closer analysis was justified at that time. This year we have had dreamtime revisited. We had the leak to the Press that this Budget was going to be tough and that the Treasurer was going to achieve a $4,000m deficit. Then we had the Budget announcement that the deficit would be $3,500m and the Press once more went into raptures. All I can say is that if the Treasurer could not reach his target last year I do not think he has reset his sights this year and the target will be missed again. I might say to the Treasurer that that is not a furphy either.

SPEECH.PARA: I noticed that there was mention in the Budget Papers of the fringe benefits tax and an item dealing with the payment of the tax. We find that the Government, has mentioned these figures in the Budget Papers in an attempt to demonstrate that it is paying a fringe benefits tax, which, of course, is farcical and makes a bad joke of trying to demonstrate to the private sector that there is an equitable approach. The Budget Papers state that this revenue comes from `on-Budget, Budget dependent authorities'. This farce is continued when we read the last sentence, which is the important one, of item 8E1 on page 248 of Budget Paper No. 1. It states:

Thus some additions to administrative expenditure appropriations have been allowed where the amounts of FBT involved are substantial or where the FBT relates to the performance of essential activities of Government which are demonstrably non-discretionary to the agencies concerned such as certain costs associated with overseas service (including the Antarctic).

This means that the fringe benefits tax which the Government cannot collect from itself and which does not exist, except on paper, will not even be pretended to be collected in the Antarctic. I wish to deal further with the fringe benefits tax because it is an item which is referred to in the Budget Papers. When the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) was speaking he broached a number of matters regarding the Queensland Government. He tried, in his debate, to find something for which he could praise his own Government but he nearly ran out of time and utilised his remaining moments to attack his home State of Queensland. At least I will give him praise in one area. He and Senator Black, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) and the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), were all reported in an article in the Sunday Mail of 5 October as having criticised the fringe benefits tax. They criticised the fringe benefits tax because of the pressure that was being placed on their candidates in the Queensland election campaign and they decided that they must try to win some points for their State colleagues. The honourable member for Capricornia was not able to handle the question of the fringe benefits tax. He was asked by Herbert Grover, the Financial Services Manager for the Queensland Graingrowers Association: `What is the reason for imposing the tax on the employer?' The honourable member for Capricornia's answer was recorded verbatim by the Press reporter at that stage because the reporter was quite aware that the honourable member is the type of person who tries to justify a statement or to say that he did not say exactly what was reported. This is what Mr Wright said in answer to that question.

What the Government decided for political reasons, and I will not walk away from that because we saw what happened when John Howard tried to do it in the mining industry for political reasons to ensure it would go through, it was decided to place it on the employer. For efficiency reasons when you consider that you have got far less employers to deal with than you have employees, that because of the political aspects of getting it through it was the decision that was made.
At least the honourable member for Capricornia was prepared to admit that the fringe benefits tax was being imposed on employers for political reasons.

I turn now to other items in the Budget about which most people should be concerned. Because of the Treasurer's history of announcing targets that are difficult to reach, everybody in Australia should be concerned, as we are discussing expenditures which may have to be altered in a mini-Budget early next year if the current directions continue. The economic growth forecasts for 1985-86 are significantly lower than they have been. The figures for December 1985 and March and June 1986 show that for those three successive quarters there has been a negative real gross domestic product growth.

It is accepted world wide that if a country has three successive periods such as these it has a recession. If we have a recession we will have problems with this Budget, as we did last year. As I said, the Treasurer will be off target. He should align his sights a little better because he is always way off target. Also we notice that there are expected wage rises, higher government charges and added consumption taxes. They will all contribute to maintaining our inflation rate at an uncomfortably high level of around 8 per cent. I say to you, Mr Deputy Chairman, that there are more losers than winners as a result of this Budget. I believe the Treasurer will have great difficulty in meeting the targets he has tried to set in these appropriations in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before calling the honourable member for Bowman, I remind honourable members taking part in this debate that we are dealing with the estimates for three departments. The debate therefore should not range into a Budget debate, which unfortunately the last three speakers have tended to do.

—Order! We have gone through them. We are now discussing the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Finance and the Advance to the Minister for Finance.

—That is correct. We have finished debating the estimates for those other departments. I referred to those two departments, Mr Deputy Chairman, because I took note of what you said about honourable members straying slightly from the appropriations of the departments that are currently before the Committee. I was reminded of the speech that was made shortly before the luncheon adjournment by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who at that stage should have been addressing his remarks to the appropriations of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Department of the Special Minister of State. I know the Chairman of Committees at the time was very tolerant and understanding towards him and gave him a fair amount of latitude. SPEECH.PARA: I want to refer briefly to the remarks made by the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Conquest) in criticism of the very fine contribution that was made by my colleague the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall). He criticised the honourable member for Rankin for spending part of his speech criticising his own State of Queensland. I do not know whether the honourable member for Hinkler did not hear my colleague correctly or whether he wished to misinterpret what the honourable member for Rankin said. I remind him and other members that the words of criticism from the honourable member for Rankin were directed at the National Party Government in Queensland. It was in sympathy for those unfortunate people in Queensland that he made the remarks. It certainly was not in criticism of the people of Queensland or the State. I feel compelled to refer to some of those things briefly, as they certainly would come under the area of the estimates we are currently considering.

Queensland has fared very well from this Government. It has received the second highest increase, some 7.5 per cent, of all States in the general purpose assistance payments that have come from this Government. Because of Queensland's commodity base, it has felt particularly hard the impact of Australian's terms of trade decline. That increase in the payment to the State certainly was warranted. In that way the Budget took into account the problems of Queensland and gave it that level of special assistance. An amount of $5.8m was allocated to Queensland from Commonwealth payments to the States for rural adjustment in the 1986-87 Budget. This represents an increase in real terms of some 25.7 per cent on the 1984-85 payment. The sugar industry in Queensland again fared remarkably well from the payments to the States in this Budget. It will receive some $21.9m as part of a three-year State-Federal government program for assisting the sugar industry. Under that program, which commences with the 1986-87 Budget, the Commonwealth is committed to provide up to $100m to the sugar industry, and the majority of those involved in the sugar industry are in Queensland.

Honourable members, including I am sure even those in the National Party of Australia, will recognise that after many months of reluctance the Queensland Government was dragged almost screaming to the barriers as far as the provision of assistance to the sugar industry was concerned. My colleague the honourable member for Rankin made another remark about the strange silence that befell the Queensland Premier after this Budget was announced. No doubt he was expecting that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would deal very harshly with Queensland in the Budget and that he would ensure that the Queensland National Party Government would be given that long-awaited base on which to mount its State election campaign, directed mainly at the criticism of this Government and this Budget. Sadly, the opportunity was not to be given to the Queensland Premier. That is perhaps the reason for his grave concern about this Budget and his silence following it.

One of the other reasons that one well may suggest for the Queensland Premier's strange silence in relation to the Budget is the fact that he has his hands fairly full at the moment. That is not because he is dealing with this Government; it is not because he is dealing with this Treasurer in his joint responsibility as Treasurer and Premier of Queensland; it is because he is forced by the media attention that has been given to it to face up to the widespread corruption problem with which he has had to cope for a long time and which he has kept somewhat under wraps. I refer to the corruption problem that exists in the ranks of his own State ministry. (Quorum formed)

As was suggested by one of my colleagues, the raw nerve of members of the Opposition was touched and it was necessary for them to call for a quorum. Unfortunately, I will not have the time to detail the corruption that exists in the Queensland Government that I had just very briefly mentioned. I can promise honourable members that I will allow that matter to wait for another occasion. I give them the assurance that I think there will be every chance that I will have that opportunity before the end of next week. The Queensland Premier, in his joint responsibilities as Premier and Treasurer, has an appalling record--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for Higgins.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted at the reception that I have received from Government members opposite. I point out to them that the estimates in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 that we are discussing-the estimates for the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance-should be, but are not, reflecting policies that are setting a proper climate for investment in Australia today. It is only through investment and profits from investment that we get growth and jobs. The appropriations should be creating a climate of confidence for investment. They should be reflecting policies of low inflation and they should bring about low interest rates and low taxation. But, of course, they are doing the exact opposite-they are lacking in confidence. Instead of a climate for business investment we have a climate of uncertainty. At a time of change in world trading and financial patterns it was never more important that we have in place in Australia today economic, financial and monetary policies that create the climate of confidence for investment to which I have referred. Why are Australian entrepreneurs and investors investing overseas? This is a vote of no confidence by those people in the investment climate created by the estimates that we are discussing under Appropriation Bill (No. 1) at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Why do the Brierleys, the Bonds, the Elliotts and the Holmes a Courts invest overseas? It is because there is no incentive for them to invest in Australia, as a result of the policies of this Government. It is more profitable to invest overseas. The more the Australian financial and business scene is screwed the less investment there will be. Honourable members opposite do not understand that. I welcome Australian companies investing overseas. I know Sir Peter Abeles's companies are doing it and Mr Rupert Murdoch's companies are doing it. I welcome this because ultimately the rewards of those investments will come home to Australia if we have policies in place which reward risk taking.

It is all very well for those opposite and the trade union movement, which is their parent-they are prisoners-to call for investment. Trade union leaders today are calling for investment. They seem to think that one gets investment by government order or government decree. What those on the other side of this House do not understand is that it is only by creating a climate of confidence for investment and ensuring a profit and a reasonable return on that investment after that profit that we will get jobs and growth. Then the Brierleys and the Bonds will invest in Australia and overseas investors will bring money to Australia.

A senior banker said to me in Hong Kong last week that Australian firms are flocking to Hong Kong to invest because of the unfavourable investment climate in Australia. Why is that so? It is because we have increases in company tax in Australia to record high levels when the rest of the free world-for example, the United States of America-is going the other way. This Government brings in a capital gains tax that taxes wealth and the creation of capital rather than the other way around, rather than encouraging its creation. Then we have the fringe benefits tax. All of these measures are a discouragement and a disincentive to investment in Australia today.

We need a climate for investment. We need an investment-first strategy. Honourable members opposite ought to realise that if we have an investment first strategy there will be growth and jobs and we will have a prosperous and dynamic economy. But they do not understand that. While the country is in economic crisis they bring in a Budget-the Appropriation Bills reflect this-that will make the matter worse, and Australia will go further and further down the economic drain. We need an investment-first strategy which realises that greatly increased productive and profitable investment is essential for growth in jobs and to reduce unemployment in this country. To do this we need to increase investment, because by doing that we create jobs and raise employment levels.

I would like to educate honourable members opposite and refer them to a booklet that ought to be compulsory reading for them. It is an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development publication called `Profits for employment'. I would like to refer to some of the factors in it.

—The Chair is quite aware of the comments made by the honourable member for Higgins. I do not think a withdrawal is in order, but I again ask the honourable member for Higgins to come back to debating the estimates for the two departments and the Advance to the Minister for Finance. This is not a Budget debate.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Chairman. I am sorry that the honourable member opposite had to take a point of order and that he did not want to learn something from what I had to say to him. I point out that I listened as he conducted his speech on the Queensland election campaign and did not take any point of order on him, and his comments were totally irrelevant. I have studied Appropriation Bill (No. 1). I know what the points of order are. I have got the estimates in front of me. They ought to reflect policies that are an investment-first strategy for Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely I am permitted to speak about taxation. What we need is less personal taxation and business taxation. What do we do? In the measures in the Appropriation Bill we have ever higher taxation. I will quote from his little book entitled `Profits for Employment' because it does relate to the debate and to the Appropriation Bill. Honourable members opposite might learn something from this. It states:
Tax reduction decreases immediately and significantly the cost of capital, stimulating investment.
In other words, tax reductions decrease costs. But these Appropriation Bills involve tax increases. The booklet continues:

Furthermore, demand is increased as investment rises. Increased demand will in turn stimulate more investment. In this way, a tax reduction starts a self-sustaining growth process whose final effect is several times the original impulse.
That is what the Estimates, the Appropriation Bills and the Government's tax measures ought to reflect in relation to expenditure, but they do not. They do the exact opposite.

The other matter that I draw to the attention of honourable members opposite in relation to profits, and hence taxes, is interest rates. Interest rates, which are a direct result of the policies and expenditures espoused in this legislation, affect the cost of capital and therefore of investment. Lower interest rates stimulate spending. As a result of these measures before the Committee, Australia has very high interest rates. If one can buy a bank bill for 17 or 20 per cent, who will undertake productive capital investment in Australia? Nobody. That is why Australian investors are flocking overseas at present. That is why we have a climate of uncertainty and a climate of instability, and that is why we have a dollar that is worth US64c today and will be worth US60c tomorrow. There needs to be a climate of certainty. Who will invest when the dollar's value is unstable? The unstable value of the dollar is a result of the failure of Government policies and is a vote of the international investment community on the ability of the Government to manage the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Treasury appropriations, particularly as they relate to the Australian Taxation Office. The focus of my remarks, however, will be allocations of Government funds which do not appear in the Budget Papers but which nevertheless represent a significant call on the public purse on the expenditure of taxpayers' money. I refer, of course, to taxation expenditures. Governments provide assistance, encouragement or relief to industry and individuals through various special provisions in the tax system. These indirect expenditures generally take the form of special exemptions, deductions, rebates, credits, exclusions, preferential rates or deferrals. They could be called business welfare measures. In offering these forms of tax relief to industry or individuals, governments forgo tax revenue and are thus making an indirect expenditure through the tax system.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to stress that these concessions have the effect of reducing or delaying collection of taxation revenue and are thus as much a call on the tax system as are the direct outlays that appear in the Budget Papers. There are, however, two striking differences between the direct outlays that appear in the Budget Papers and taxation expenditures. Firstly, taxation expenditures are rarely calculated and, secondly, direct expenditure is, by and large, directed to those who have an established and identifiable need for the things governments provide such as children needing education, sick people needing hospitals, pensioners needing financial support, migrants needing to learn English and the like. Taxation expenditures have, in recent years, become more oriented towards assistance to industries and producers of goods. They include investment allowances, depreciation allowances and concessions on superannuation or petroleum exploration. Of course, in some wages I have oversimplified the divisions between the two types of government expenditure and there are examples of both types of assistance to be found in both types of government expenditure. Nevertheless, the bulk of tax expenditures are those which are designed to aid industry and they do not appear in the Budget Papers. The bulk of payments in the Budget Papers are for education or social welfare and these are oriented towards individuals rather than business.

Non-reporting of taxation expenditures is not something that I have just become aware of. Indeed, in 1982 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure, of which I was then Deputy Chairman, produced a report entitled `Taxation Expenditures', which contained information on this matter. The results of the Committee's report indicated that in 1981-82 the indicative cost of taxation expenditures was over $6 billion or more than 15 per cent of direct Budget outlays in 1981-82. If the same proportion holds for 1986-87, that is, 15 per cent of direct Budget outlays-I have no indication that that will not be the case-the indicative cost of taxation expenditure in this Budget would be over $11 billion. It is interesting to note that this is more than the total paid by the Department of Social Security for all age, sick, widows' and supporting parents' benefits; it is twice the expenditure of the Department of Health; it is more than twice the outlays of the Education portfolio; and it is 12 times the outlays of the Primary Industry portfolio.

Changes in taxation deductions allowed since 1981-82 would also ensure that less individual deductions would appear among tax concessions. The major allowances are now those of business. I should add that the Committee's calculations were not significantly affected by those items now the subject of so much anxiety in the Opposition as fringe benefits taxation is implemented. These items, compared to other benefits received by business, accounted for approximately 5 per cent of the indicative cost of tax expenditures for 1986-87. The Expenditure Committee recommended in its 1982 report that comprehensive information should be provided on taxation expenditures by the Government within three years of the tabling of the report. Well, unfortunately it is now four years and I wonder whether we are any closer to finding out the level of assistance provided by government through taxation expenditures and, just as importantly, who gets this assistance-this business welfare. The Expenditure Committee recommended that information on taxation expenditures be provided as part of the Budget process, as a separate statement of the Budget Papers, and that the Government incorporate an explanation as to why the taxation system was preferred to direct outlays as a method of providing assistance.

The Committee was advised that hopefully this information would be available with the 1986-87 Budget. Unfortunately the information has not been provided. I am advised by the Tax Office that no consolidated list of business concession is available and that the list of organisations which have tax exemptions covers over 1,000 pages.

Taking the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust as an example of a body on this list of tax exempt bodies some interesting issues arise. The annual report of the Elizabethan Theatre Trust indicates that through the tax-exempt status of the Trust such diverse organisations as the New Theatre and Quadrant magazine have received tax-exempt donations via the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust, from the Tax Office. These allocations are open-ended. For every dollar contributed the Government gives a dollar deduction. For instance, the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust received $2.9m in donations in 1985. The corporations who made those donations could claim a 49c in the dollar deduction from their taxable profit, and individuals who made donations could claim a deduction of up to 60c in the dollar. Rather than the publicity saying that the Australian Opera, for instance, is sponsored by the Benson and Hedges Company it should say `proudly brought to you by Benson and Hedges and the Australian taxpayer'. As another example, the publicity should say that Quadrant magazine is sponsored by the New Right and the Australian taxpayer. It is interesting to note that this right wing magazine is laundering tax deductible funds through the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust. It is not just the Right that is up to this. The Australian Conservation Foundation is also laundering funds to political organisations by way of its tax exempt capacity. They are just two examples.

The expenditures are also inequitable in the way the deductibility is assessed. Taking the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust and the Australian Conservation Foundation as examples, if a pensioner, a tradesman, a company or a public servant on $36,000 per annum gave a $100 donation to either of these organisations, it is interesting to note how much they personally would have contributed after making their tax claim. Of his $100 the public servant would claim $60 back, thus contributing $40 of his own money; the company would claim $49 as a tax deduction, thus contributing $51 of company funds; the tradesman would claim $46 as a tax deduction, thus contributing $54 of his own money; but the pensioner would contribute $100 of his own money as he has no deductions. That is not very equitable. I therefore argue that the Australian taxpayer is being unjustly treated. He or she does not know how a substantial proportion of the funds available to the Government is spent because those funds become taxation expenditures. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I raise concerns a desperate Government whose desperation is reflected in the stand-over, outrageous and desperate actions of the Australian Taxation Office. It is obvious that this desperate Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his equally desperate and rattled Treasurer (Mr Keating), having mismanaged the economy for more than three years, have issued directions to the Treasury and to the Taxation Office to apply pressure tactics to taxpayers and tax agents with the express purpose of reaping in revenue as quickly as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: For more than 18 months prior to the `banana republic' and `the party's over' revelations, the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and other senior Ministers indulged in misleading the people of Australia by telling them that the economy was great and strong. Their indulgence in reassuring rhetoric was continuing while our balance of payments was worsening and our domestic deficit was blowing out. Finally, the bubble burst and now we are facing a crisis equivalent to war time, to use the Prime Minister's words, or, as Mr Keating so fruitfully put it, we are heading towards being a banana republic.

From the personal complaints that I have received from constituents about the actions and attitudes of the Australian Taxation Office, one can only conclude that the message has been delivered loudly and clearly. That message is: `Get out there and get in as much revenue as you can and do it as quickly as you can'. The get-tough tactics range from caution notes and late payment penalties to the hard line on the issuance of summonses for the late lodgment of income tax returns.

I have even had a recent case in which the Taxation Office, having accepted a procedure and circumstances as being exempt from sales tax, reversed its position and demanded back tax for three years, saying that the business involved was avoiding tax. The businessman who received this letter on 1 October was naturally very distressed. He immediately discussed the matter with me over the telephone and subsequently provided me with copies of the correspondence. Before I received his written response to the Taxation Office's demand, I had a further call from him to say that the Taxation Office in Brisbane had phoned, advising him to ignore its letter of demand. That was on Monday morning, 6 October. This was a letter from the Taxation Office dated 30 September demanding that a further return be lodged within 21 days as sales tax had been avoided over the previous three years. Incidentally, the figure involved was about a mere $600,000 and carried a penalty of a further $600,000-a cool $1.2 million all up. However, the letter did state that the penalty could be waived in the light of a satisfactory explanation from the taxpayer. In effect, the bill ranged from a minimum of $600,000 to a maximum of $1.2m.

I am advised that the taxpayer, whom I designate Mr X, received a visit from an officer of the Taxation Office on 8 October to confirm that he should ignore the contents of the letter. I seek leave to table the letter from the Australian Taxation Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?
—I will have a look at it first.
—I will quote one or two para- graphs from the letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Sir
SALES TAX
Reference is made to the recent examination of your sales tax records by an officer of this department.

You are hereby required to review your transactions and furnish further and fuller returns for the months of September 1983 to August 1986 inclusive bringing to account all goods manufactured by you and sold by you in taxable circumstances. You are required to pay tax on the correct sale value of all such goods.
The letter goes on to state:
It is pointed out that as a result of your failure to account for and pay tax on the sale value of all goods at the proper time, additional tax is imposable . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has given approval for the tabling of the letter.

—I thank the Committee. Three working days after receipt of the letter by the taxpayer, the taxpayer was the subject of a phone call from the Taxation Office to say: `Ignore its contents'. One can imagine the emotional stress suffered by the taxpayer over the five days from receipt of the letter to being told to ignore its contents. Let us remember that this was claimed avoidance amounting to about $600,000 with a maximum penalty of a further $600,000. Such worry and stress could easily have induced a heart attack or a mental breakdown.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr X advised me that in the 14 years in his business he has never attempted to avoid sales tax and in fact in the three-year period under consideration he had paid about $2m in sales tax. Mr X says that he has had a good and close relationship with the Taxation Office and has always complied with its requests. I will quote a few words from Mr X. He said:
Back in the days when you could reason with the tax department we were told by an officer that we had the highest possible honesty rating.

It seems that those days have gone and that the Taxation Office has lost its reasonableness, its compassion and its helpful approach. Those once present qualities have given way to tough, jackboot, gestapo-like methods. The irony of this case is that Mr X, who occasionally does work for the Commonwealth, has to wait up to 90 days before he receives his payment. That is just another case of the Government saying: `Don't do as I do, but do as I say'.

My next examples of the unreasonableness of the Taxation Office are coupled with what I believe is its stupidity and wastefulness of government revenue. Simply, the Taxation Office is squandering the commodity it so desperately wants; that is, money. Taxpayers A, B and C are all in breach of the tax Act in that they have failed, through their tax agent, to lodge their tax returns on time. Their problems were caused by their accountant tax agent in that information was in his hands but he, through office and staff problems, was unable to lodge them on time. I recognise that the taxpayer is ultimately responsible for lodgment and that excuses for non-lodgment on time are generally not acceptable. Summonses were served on all three taxpayers.

I will deal with taxpayers A and B for their cases are very similar and were set down for summons hearing on the same day. On hearing of the cases, I first telegrammed the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation for Queensland, requesting that the prosecutions be withdrawn. The Deputy Commissioner quite fairly adjourned the hearings for 14 days to allow my representations to be considered. A few days later I wrote to the Deputy Commissioner out- lining in detail that the taxpayers' problems were caused by the agent and that the returns had been submitted subsequent to the issue of the summonses. I requested that the summonses be withdrawn and that the taxpayers be penalised for their late lodgment under other sections of the Taxation Administration Act. I pointed out that they were honest people and were in no way involved in any form of devious tax evasion. Additionally, I should point out that I spoke personally on the telephone with the Deputy Commissioner, Mr Scanlan, regarding these cases. I might add that I know him personally and he is always reasonable and helpful. It is interesting to note that at the time of the late lodgment of both of these returns taxpayer A was due for a refund of nearly $1,000 and taxpayer B had already paid the estimated tax of about $6,500. I was subsequently notified by the Deputy Commissioner that he could not agree to the withdrawal of the summonses. The cases proceeded to the Brisbane Magistrates Court and both A and B were fined $500 and costs of court.

In raising this criticism of the Australian Taxation Office I recognise the difficult task it has and the need on occasions for firmness. Both taxpayers A and B had good track records of on-time lodgment of returns and payment of tax. In my view, where taxpayers have an unblemished record the issuance of summonses should be avoided unless the taxpayer stubbornly refuses to co-operate. Additionally, the Taxation Office has the capacity to apply a penalty to the taxpayer without proceeding to court action. Even if a summons has been issued it can be withdrawn and a penalty applied. Two aspects of these cases disturb me. First, the taxpayers had convictions which should, and could, have been avoided. The second is the unnecessary cost of proceeding to summons. There is no way that the Office could be other than out of pocket with these cases. In other words, it is wasting taxpayers' money in the pursuit of prosecutions when it could have, through a penalty, shown a profit. I am advised that in dealing with these cases the magistrate acted as though he were programmed.

Taxpayer C, whose circumstances were slightly different, was convicted and fined a few dollars plus court costs. In his case, the Taxation Office would have been well out of pocket as it would have cost hundreds of dollars to prosecute only to receive a few dollars as a fine. This taxpayer's summons was dated 23 April, although it was not received, he says, until 29 April, five days after he had submitted his return together with his estimated tax payment of $3,700. The day he was convicted and fined in the Brisbane Magistrates Court-22 May 1986-was also the date of issue of his notice of assessment, which said that he was due for a refund of $35. Again, in my view, this taxpayer should not have been put through the expensive summons process but penalised under the Taxation Administration Act.

To sum up, my main criticism of the Taxation Office is that it is cold, hard, callous and uncompassionate. Even worse than that, it is wasting the precious commodity that it has a duty to collect-that is, money. No doubt there are thousands of unnecessary prosecutions costing the nation millions of dollars in staff and legal costs. Most of these dollars could be saved and more gained by applying a penalty under the Taxation Administration Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Estimates before us show quite clearly what a tremendous and excellent Budget this Government has brought down, as I have said in previous debate. The deficit will come down to $3 1/2 billion, which reflects the economic efficiency of this Government. This is particularly the case, considering that in 1983, when we came into government, the projected deficit was $9.6 billion. We have seen since that time a drastic turnaround of the economy from the depression outlook under the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who was then the Treasurer. He had been Treasurer for five years. We have seen this Government turn the domestic economy around quite dramatically under the guidance of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who is in the chamber at present. As I have said, we have seen the Budget deficit come down to $3.5 billion.
