We have seen the floating of the dollar, economic growth such as we have never seen in this country before, unemployment coming down and a whole host of other indicators that show that the economy is on the rails.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of this Budget and the Estimates that are before us, we will see lower interest rates, a prospect which is reflected in the market at present. Lower interest rates will flow through to the housing sector and other sectors in the coming months as we see lower interest rates generally over the next 12 months. We will also see a downward drift in inflation and a further overall improvement in the domestic economy. Again, this shows the guidance that we have seen from the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, which is in contrast to the three decades during which honourable members opposite occupied the treasury bench. They practically destroyed the economy of this country over three decades. They should not point to what has happened now when they occupied the treasury bench for 31 out of 34 years prior to 1983. The economy has been turned around, with the deficit coming down of $3 1/2 billion. Major decisions, such as the floating of the dollar, have seen the economy pick up and will see lower interest rates and a downward trend in inflation. We will see the economy pick up right through 1987. I would like to say a number of other things but I think perhaps I should seek leave to continue my remarks at a later time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 3.15 p.m., in accordance with the resolution agreed to on 9 October 1986, I shall report progress.

—I refer the Prime Minister to Australia's historically high real interest rates and to the falling after tax return on business investment. Against the background of those circumstances, will the Prime Minister assure the House that in no circumstances will his Government, first, impose an additional tax of one per cent on imports; secondly, restrict the level of overseas investment undertaken by superannuation funds to a maximum of 15 per cent; or, thirdly, impose a one per cent corporate surcharge on the gross operating surplus of all companies with profits of over $50,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members will realise that the specific issues to which the Leader of the Opposition has referred in his question are the suggestions that have been put forward by the Australian Council of Trade Unions in its preliminary observations about a possible basis for a new wage fixing approach in 1987. I simply want to say this about the Government's attitude to wage fixing: We stand proudly on our record since we came to government, a record which demonstrates results of which everyone in this country can be proud. Most obviously, with the restraint that has been shown in respect of wages, we have had actual falls in real wages. That contrasts with the 9 per cent increase in real wages which characterised the last year of the conservative Government under the economic stewardship of the present Leader of the Opposition. There was a 9 per cent rise in real wages in the previous Government's last year as opposed to this Government's achievement of a 4 to 5 per cent reduction in real wages in three years which, of course, has been associated with a tremendous increase in employment of 650,000 new jobs. The record of the Leader of the Opposition, in his last year as Treasurer, was a rise in unemployment of over a quarter of a million. Those are the facts about this Government's approach in the area of wage fixation.

ANSWER.PARA: An essential part of achieving that economic success in wages has been the preparedness of this Government to talk with the trade union movement and with business to achieve a sensible and rational outcome. It is quite clear that the trade union movement has now accepted that it is inappropriate in current circumstances to talk about a policy of full wage indexation. As part of the ACTU's approach, which sees the necessity of increased investment by Australian industry, it has put up a number of proposals, including those that have been mentioned by the Leader of the Opposition. What this Government will do-it will start later on this afternoon, as a matter of fact-is this: I and a number of my Ministers will meet with the ACTU to discuss these issues, and tomorrow we will be following that with discussions with representatives of the business community. These will not be final discussions. I have no doubt that in the weeks ahead we will have further discussions with the ACTU and with representatives of the business community. I will not in advance say precisely what the position of the Government will be, because to do so would not do justice to either our friends in the business community or our friends in the trade union movement. They have every right to put their proposals before us. I have no doubt, from the discussions that I have already had with representatives of the business community, that they will put a number of proposals and probably they will have some sort of ambit claim, as I have no doubt will the ACTU. In the outcome the result, this country can be sure, will be a wages policy which will be relevant to our economic needs. Once again, it will stand in stark and successful contrast to the absolute chaos that characterised the stewardship of the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Prime Minister give an outline of the briefing provided to the Government by the President's representative, Kenneth Adelman, Director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, on the recent meeting in Reykjavik between President Reagan and Mr Gorbachev?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, let me put my answer in the context that indeed Mr Adelman put the matter at the outset of the discussions we have just held, in which he spoke with, in addition to myself, my colleagues the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, and the Minister for Defence. In opening his comments Mr Adelman said that the briefing he was giving constituted another part of a successful and ongoing dialogue on arms control and disarmament questions between this Government and the United States of America. He made the point that the President had specifically asked him to come immediately to Australia. It is some measure of the importance attached by the United States Administration to our relations that Mr Adelman, a key figure in the discussions, flew back from Reykjavik to the United States in the early hours of the morning, appeared on a television program, and a few hours later flew directly to have these discussions with us.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Adelman confirmed, as I said yesterday, and I am very pleased to be able to say it again to the House and to the people of Australia, that very significant progress was indeed made in the discussions between the two leaders on a number of important issues; albeit, unfortunately, that those discussions are still at the level of general frameworks and understandings. As Mr Adelman explained, these understandings on the arms control front covered three different areas. They covered testing, START-that is, the strategic arms reduction talks area-and INF, or intermediate nuclear forces. On testing, agreement was reached on the need for work plans covering verification, reduction in the numbers and yields of tests, and agreement that the ultimate objective was a comprehensive test ban treaty. In outlining those features, Mr Adelman referred to Australia's own strong and very well known international position on the need for a comprehensive test ban treaty.

The briefing on strategic weapons confirmed the readiness on both sides to achieve quite severe cuts and foreshadowed new elements of flexibility by the Soviet Union in previous areas of difficulty. On INF, clearly there was a real element of negotiation over the two-day period. This was of considerable significance to Australia because it produced a new mutual position of reductions to 100 Soviet warheads in Asia and a corresponding number of United States warheads on United States territory. I note in passing that much detail on this negotiation has also been given by the Soviet delegation to the United Nations General Assembly. Unfortunately, Mr Adelman's briefing confirmed to us that inability to find agreement in the area of the strategic defence initiative was the obstacle to any agreements being registered in those areas that I have outlined as well as in important areas of human rights and regional questions. It is perhaps fortuitous that the rigidity of the differences over SDI was not confirmed until rather late in the proceedings. That therefore allowed the prospects for broad agreements in those other areas to be established.

It is a matter of concern to this Government that the difference between the two super-powers on the SDI at this stage remains unbridgeable. The Ministers and I explored in the course of the briefing a number of ways in which the difficulties might be accommodated, while permitting progress towards the complete elimination of offensive weapons over the 10-year period, as proposed by President Reagan, to continue. Obviously the Government's reservations on SDI have in no way been diminished. The United States is aware of our policy on this matter and it will clearly become the focus of considerable international attention in the period immediately ahead.

I took the opportunity, as I hope all honourable members would expect me to do, to press strongly on the United States Administration the fact that we want the arms control and disarmament process to continue. I made plain our view that since so much had been achieved to this point it would be a tragedy to see it sacrificed. I expressed the hope, I believe on behalf of all members of the House, that those discussions would proceed at full speed. I also took the opportunity to commend firmly to the United States Administration the protocols of the Treaty of Rarotonga and express our hope that the Administration will see fit to sign them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the common situation where a person buys any property, including commercial goods or a home, and the value of that property increases between the time the contract is entered into and the time the goods are delivered or the contract is completed-which could be some years when legal disputes arise. Is the Treasurer aware that even for exempt principal places of residence-a concept the Treasurer is well aware of-the increase in the value of the property between exchange of contract and settlement is potentially subject to capital gains tax in the hands of the purchaser on the deemed disposal of the contract on its completion by virtue of its then being satisfied or discharged? Is this an intended or unintended consequence of the capital gains tax?

—Let me get this right. The Opposition is opposed to the capital gains tax and thinks that there should not be one. It says it does not believe in a capital gains tax. It thinks that the accretions of wealth that are taking place in the stock exchanges-income taken as capital-ought to go tax free into people's pockets. The Opposition will throw out the capital gains tax lock, stock and barrel, but Opposition members will try to address questions to the Government to improve its administration, is that right? If it is right, we will answer the questions when the Opposition decides to support the tax. In the meantime let me make it quite clear that the intended consequence of the coalition's policy is for a growing disparity in the level of wealth in the community so that the people in a position to gear up their assets who wish to take their income as capital will pay no tax if they can suggest that they are not trading under section 26, or section 25a now. Anyone on a pay as you earn income-someone on $17,000 a year with three kids-ought to pay John Howard's punitive tax rates of 40 and 46 per cent, but if one takes one's income as capital, that is okay with a coalition government. Opposition members are saying `We are not going to have a capital gains tax, we do not believe in any fairness in the tax system, but we will try to drag into disrepute the Government's capital gains tax or we will try to improve it'. I say to Opposition members that when they decide that there is a place for decent tax law in this country they can ask us all the questions they like, but while they are in the position of buttressing wealth, of seeing massive accretions of wealth and watching ordinary working class people paying their full rates of marginal tax, Opposition members will get no support from us.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAX REFORM: EFFECT ON SMALL BUSINESS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Treasurer inform the House how the Government's tax reform initiatives will advantage small business?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a very advantageous way. Let me take the time to reflect upon and give some details of the beneficial impact on small business of the Government's proposed tax changes, particularly as they relate to imputation-a corporate tax revolution in this country. Let us consider the position that existed under the previous Administration. Let us assume that a company makes a pre-tax profit of $100,000. Under the tax regime of the Leader of the Opposition this company would have paid company tax of $46,000 and the remaining $54,000 would have been taxed at the personal income tax rates of up to 60c in the dollar. Thus the company would have paid $46,000 in company tax and the balance would have then been subject to tax of up to 60c in the dollar. As a result the total tax bill of that business would have been $64,000 out of the $100,000 profit. Even more horrendous was the fact that, for each extra dollar this small business person earned, nearly 80c would have gone in tax to the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer. That is, one extra dollar in profit would have been taxed at 46c in the hands of the company and 60c in the hands of the individual, so that 21.6c in the dollar would have gone to the small business person and 78.4c to the Government under the previous Administration. Let me put it another way: If a small business person worked for 10 hours a day, he would have worked eight of them for the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer.

ANSWER.PARA: I now contrast that situation with the massive change of full imputation which makes Australia the second country in the world next to West Germany to adopt such a system. Let us take the same example of a company making a pre-tax profit of $100,000. Under the new system the company pays tax of $49,000 and distributes a dividend of $51,000. The difference now is that the $49,000 tax paid by the company is set off against the total tax liability of the shareholder. As the new tax rates take effect from 1 July 1987, the shareholder will be assessed with tax of $41,800, but he or she will be able to offset against that tax bill the $49,000 paid by way of the principal company tax. This will mean that he or she will have no personal income tax to pay at all and the total tax bill will be no more than $49,000, compared with $64,000 under the policies of the Leader of the Opposition. The marginal tax rate will be 49c on each extra dollar, compared with 80c imposed by the so-called supporters of small business sitting opposite. In this particular example the taxpayer will have a tax credit remaining of $7,151 which he or she will be able to use to earn an extra $14,000 from other sources without paying any extra tax. The bottom line is that the marginal tax on small business under Labor will be 49 per cent while under the Liberals it was 80 per cent. When one is a small business person working in the Australia of the Leader of the Opposition one is working eight hours out of 10 for the Leader of the Opposition and the coalition.

That tax burden diminishes massively under the imputation proposal of the Hawke Labor Government. Imputation is a corporate tax revolution which is just dawning in corporate Australia. Companies will see this pernicious burden of the double tax on dividends-not only the primary company tax but also the personal tax paid twice-is being removed so that, for the first time ever, small business in this country is having the yoke of taxation lifted from its back. The tax bill will be reduced dramatically. Opposition members may giggle and be embarrassed, as well they might because many people are waking up to the fact that their actions and their rhetoric do not match. The Opposition had 30 years running the tax system of this country and for 30 years it punished business with a double tax on dividends. In three years of this Government's administration we have removed the double tax on business, which will dramatically reduce the burden of income tax on small business from $64,000 out of $100,000 to around $41,000. That is the difference between genuine tax reform and the rhetoric of Opposition members, who have never cared for small business people and never will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer and I have a copy of it here in case he needs to read it to understand what it means. I refer him to the exemption criteria of the capital gains tax. If a house is purchased by a taxpayer as his or her sole residential property, but due to the requirement of extensive renovation to make it habitable the purchaser either occupies it for a token period or not at all, and then disposes of the house on the completion of the renovation for a profit, will the Treasurer confirm that the house would be exempt from capital gains tax under section 160zzq of the Income Tax Act on the ground that it was `the principal residence' of the taxpayer? Is this an intended or unintended consequence of the capital gains tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder who wrote that question for the honourable member because even reading it is difficult for him. I repeat myself in case the honourable member did not hear me the first time. For 30 years the Opposition presided over a tax system which allowed many Australians to accrue wealth and not pay tax on it. The aggregation of the great fortunes of this country all have a capital gain underpinning them. This Government has introduced about the fairest capital gains tax in the world and it will not resile from cleaning up this fundamental imbalance in the tax system, where people who choose to take their income as capital need not pay tax on it. I refer to the current highs on the Australian stock exchanges. When this Government came to office the stock exchange indexes were around 600 points. They are now around 1200 points. That massive accretion of wealth, that massive accretion in the capital value of Australian stocks would, unless someone was a recognised trader, have gone straight into the pockets of the owners of those stocks without any capital taxation. But the pay as you earn taxpayer had no such advantage. While the former Treasurer let people escape the tax net by the criminal paper evasion schemes of the 1970s, those same people were loading the tax burden on to the ordinary taxpayers whose marginal tax rates were rising.

ANSWER.PARA: This Government has put an end to that. We have introduced a capital gains tax which is based on the real gain-not the nominal gain-at full marginal rates of tax so that the choice between investment and placing of scarce capital in this economy can be a tax neutral choice and not one that buttresses only people with established assets. That is the basis of our tax. Opposition members are opposed to that concept. They say: `We want this ramp to exist and to continue'. By asking me some pathetic question about the status of some person in relation to this property and the capital gain they demonstrate that they wish to keep the tax system in some sort of sullied condition in the gutter. But they ask me to do them the favour of answering this question which they claim they have put to me because they are not sure that I have this point covered. When the Opposition comes to the point of tax decency we will answer all its questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. In the light of claims that the Medicare benefits budget has been understated by $120m, can the Minister inform the House of the current levels of expenditure on Medicare benefits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am most grateful for the question from the honourable member for Canberra. I am sure that the answer will be of interest to the honourable member for Barker who, having no health policy of his own, devotes his life to exaggerating the cost of Medicare. No sooner had this year's Budget been brought down than the honourable member for Barker suggested that the Budget books had been cooked in relation to Medicare; that in fact we had seriously underestimated utilisation; and that on his calculations we would be out by $120m. Well, the runs are now on the board. We have the figures for the first quarter of Medicare benefit payments and the Government is exactly on target. Indeed, we are $4m under budget. We budgeted $746.3m for July to September and the actual expenditure was $742.1m. Rather than having underestimated the utilisation rates, we have overestimated them and the utilisation rates to date are lower than those predicted in the Budget.

ANSWER.PARA: Even more interesting is that in September, the first clear month after the Budget, more than half of all medical services were direct billed. So that makes nonsense of the Opposition's claims that as direct billing goes up there will be an increase in utilisation rates. What we are getting is an increase in bulk billing and a decline or at least a moderation of the utilisation rates. Moreover, despite this concerted campaign by the Opposition against direct billing, bulk billing is extraordinarily popular among both doctors and patients, particularly in working class areas, and does not lead to overservicing. Indeed, a recent survey of Sydney doctors showed that 94 per cent of doctors direct billed at least some patients; 60 per cent direct billed selectively, that is, card holders and pensioners; and 36 per cent of general practitioners direct billed all consumers. It was interesting that direct billing was most common in the less affluent areas of Sydney; that is, direct billing is being used where it is most needed. As the honourable member for Barker strives to put together some sort of health policy, one of the big questions he will have to answer is why he will deny the direct billing option to hundreds of thousands of working class families.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAPITAL GAINS TAX: SPORTSMEN AND SPORTSWOMEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the situation where an amateur sportsperson receives a payment to give up his or her amateur status to become a professional. Will the Treasurer confirm that such a payment is fully subject to capital gains tax in the hands of the sportsman or sportswoman? Is that an intended or unintended consequence of the capital gains tax? To mark the Treasurer's new classification by the Euromoney magazine as runner-up to the world's worst Treasurer, will the Treasurer come to the steps of Parliament House after Question Time to receive this compensatory wooden spoon, a traditional award within the sporting world for those who have tried and failed, just as he has tried and failed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable gentleman is concerned about a capital payment in between the status of an amateur person becoming a professional, he might tell us what tax treatment he thought was appropriate on the $300,000 he was paid on his transition from amateur to amateur and the $300,000 that was sitting in between. We might hear from him about that. I am interested in his allusion to wooden spoons and Euromoney. I have just had passed to me the latest sovereign credit report of Moody's Investor Services Inc. on the Commonwealth of Australia, which has some very interesting comments in it. I will read a couple. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Given Prime Minister Bob Hawke's high approval rating among the electorate and the middle of the road policies he advocates, the Australian Labor Party will likely win the next general election to be held in late 1987-88. The Opposition Liberal and National parties are likely to be without an issue or a leader to galvanise the public and thus will not make much headway in discrediting or unseating the popular Prime Minister. Bob Hawke could be Prime Minister for another term.
The report goes on to talk about certain farming and mining groups, then states:

These groups support the Liberal and National (formerly Country) Party and profess to believe in free enterprise and a reduced role for government in the economy. In practice they have enthusiastically endorsed government regulations and protectionist measures.

The report goes on to give the Government accolades on its domestic development and structural changes. So if we want to get where it matters, the rating agency responsible for the sovereign debt report on this country in the major capital markets of this world has a very low price on the Opposition, its leader and its policies. So do not worry about the wooden spoon; we will be using that on the Opposition in the next 18 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Will the Government restore full tax write-offs against all income for interest paid on negatively geared investment in the private rental market, as advocated by the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, there will be no return to the tax rorts of the past as tolerated by the previous Government. There will be no return to a situation where no capital gains tax applies on sale of property in the private rental market and where the interest bill on investment in the private rental market is allowed to be written off against all income. Let us examine the situation that would occur in a particular instance if the Opposition were in a position to restore the policies which it tolerated when in government. Let us look at how a full tax write-off against all income, in the absence of a capital gains tax, would apply against a particular situation. Under the position tolerated by the former Government, a borrower could borrow $1m to invest in, say, a block of flats, having an interest bill in the vicinity of $180,000 per year, with an income from that investment of approximately $80,000. That person would be in a position to write off some $100,000 against all other income, from whatever source, at 60c in the dollar probably-thanks very much.

ANSWER.PARA: If the person were to sell the same property after several years for $1.5m-that is, made a gain of $500,000-under the situation tolerated by the former Government no tax whatsoever would be paid on that gain. There would be a $500,000 tax-free gain, made possible by borrowed finance fully subsidised by the ordinary wage and salary earner who pays tax. That is great for the slick financiers of this world, but it is not good for the ordinary, honest wage and salary earner who pays his or her tax and who would be paying higher taxes as a result of the rorts, ramps, write-offs and avoidance measures which were allowed by the former Government and current Leader of the Opposition.

I ask the House to compare that very serious and irresponsible situation with what applies under this Government. That is, there can still be a tax write-off for investment in the private rental market against income from the property, or group of properties, owned by a particular investor. In addition, a depreciation allowance of 4 per cent on new buildings is available. Of course, in the event of a sale after a few years, a capital gains tax applies but it is a fair tax. It does not apply to the family home, it is entirely prospective and it applies only to the real gain, and then only when that real gain is realised. This is a policy that can be supported by investors in the private rental market. It is not a rort. It is a fair policy and it has the added advantage of stimulating investment in new construction rather than stimulating very high prices for existing houses.

The way to expand the private rental market and to increase investment in that market is to act precisely as we are acting; that is, getting interest rates down and relying on measures such as the depreciation allowance and not the rorts, write-offs and tax ramps that were the norm under the former Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Housing and Construction to his answer to the previous question. Does the Minister share the views of the New South Wales Minister for Housing, Frank Walker, who said today in the New South Wales Parliament that there was a crisis in Australia's private rental market and that the Hawke Government's decision to abolish negative gearing provisions had driven private investors out of the housing market? Does the Minister think that Mr Walker is advocating rorts, ramps and write-offs? Is it also a fact that the Minister has recently been advised by the Government's advisory body on the housing industry, the Indicative Planning Council, that the negative gearing changes and capital gains tax have resulted in the deferral and cancellation of previously planned housing developments, thereby creating a chronic shortage in rental accommodation and a dramatic increase in housing rents around Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can say about the comments of my colleague from New South Wales is that I am pleased that we have some opposition, even if it comes only from my mates in New South Wales, because I have had no opposition this session from the Opposition spokesman for housing in this place. I have already explained the reasons why this Government will not return to the tax ramps and rorts of the past which were tolerated by the former Government.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-You won't return.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt in my mind that honourable members opposite will not return to government whilst they advocate the tax rorts that they tolerated when they were in government. I have already explained-and I say this to my colleagues in New South Wales-that we have introduced a depreciation allowance of 4 per cent and that that is a preferable way of stimulating investment in the private rental market rather than allowing the unqualified application of negative gearing against all interest rate bills, as applied in the past. We will not return to a situation where people can invest in the private rental market and receive an income from that investment which is much less than the interest bill and then allow it to be written off against income from all other sources.

ANSWER.PARA: Our performance in housing is on the record. We have given priority to housing measures and policies in the last Budget. I say to my friends in New South Wales that their public housing allocation has risen from $150m in 1982-83 under the former Government to $380m this financial year. Furthermore, we have protected one million households that are now holding pre-April savings bank loans at 13 1/2 per cent. We have protected them by giving the savings banks a subsidy of $145m. Furthermore, we have kept in operation the first home owners scheme, which entails a present pay-out and a future commitment of up to $1,000m. As far as the state of the industry is concerned we expect a return to an annualised rate of approximately 130,000 commencements by the June quarter of 1987.

The future of the housing industry depends upon the future level of interest rates. I point out to the House that over the last few days bank bill rates have been coming down, the 180-day bill and the 90-day bill are now running at 16.4 per cent and the 90-day bill is at 16.8 per cent-the lowest since mid-August. Soon we will see the cash management trust rates come down and, after a lag, we will see less pressure on housing interest rates. I say to the banks that in this situation they should be very much on a watch and hold position regarding the new rate. Overall, the outlook for housing is moderately encouraging in both the home ownership area and the private rental market and most encouraging indeed, as a result of the finances that we have offered to the States, in the area of public housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, concerns taxation. Is the Prime Minister aware of suggestions that the existing Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act be used instead of the Government's fringe benefits tax to combat tax avoidance? Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the effectiveness of the interplay of Part IVa with the old section 26 (e) as an anti-avoidance device?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that on 9 October on the Carleton-Walsh Report the Leader of the Opposition referred to Part IVa as an anti-avoidance device. He boasted in that context that he had introduced the toughest anti-avoidance legislation in memory. My colleague the Treasurer pointed out yesterday that the Leader of the Opposition was blown away in a quite remarkable fashion in a speech by the Commissioner of Taxation in which the Commissioner commented on the effectiveness of the anti-avoidance legislation under the old law which relied on the interplay of Part IVa with section 26 (e). I remind the House again of what the Commissioner of Taxation had to say on this issue yesterday. I quote him:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . anyone who would say that all that is needed is a return to application of the old law is either ignoring history or has a poor memory, not to speak of a lack of appreciation of the technical inadequacies in that law.

There we have the Commissioner of Taxation blowing the Leader of the Opposition out of the water. Speaking of history as he does, it is no wonder that the Leader of the Opposition does not want to look at his history and his record in this area.

I have had occasion before to remind the House of the most damning indictment of the former Treasurer and the previous Government which was made by their own Royal Commissioner. Here we have the Commissioner of Taxation blowing the Leader of the Opposition out of the water, but the previous Government's own Royal Commissioner made the most damning indictment. Of course, I refer to chapter 2 of the December 1981 Interim Report No. 3 of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union. Madam Speaker, you will remember that in the opening sentence in chapter 2, entitled `Slutzkin rides again', the Royal Commissioner referred to the fact that the tax avoidance industry was the fastest growing industry in Australia and identified the period. His report came down in December 1981 and he said that the tax avoidance industry had been the fastest growing industry in the last five years-in other words, in the period from 1976 to 1981.

Let us look at the rest of that paragraph of the Royal Commissioner on these people who are standing here in this House and pretending to be concerned with the interests of the ordinary, poor taxpayer in this country. What was the indictment of their own Royal Commissioner? It was in these terms:

Unfortunately this industry carried with it a serious detriment to the interests of government and the Australian community. The detriment was twofold: in the first place it diverted from the Treasury tax which would prima facie be payable on income of taxpayers; in the second place it diverted the tax payable by those engaged in that industry.
Mr Costigan went on to say:
The amounts involved are very large indeed, amounting to many hundreds of millions of dollars per year or more.
This was the concluding part of their Royal Commissioner's statement, their Royal Commissioner's indictment of that Government:

The impact on the community has been very serious. It has introduced into the community a class of people almost invariably the highest earners, who pay little or no tax and make no contribution in that way as citizens to their fair share of community costs.
He concluded:
In addition it has made more difficult for government the task of providing for the community as a whole a more equitable and reduced taxation burden.

The clear message of indictment by their Royal Commissioner was that they had deliberately protected the privileged and had ensured that hundreds of millions of dollars per year were not being paid. That had the twofold impact of imposing a greater burden on the ordinary taxpayer in this country and ensuring that there was less revenue available to government to do the sorts of things that this community could reasonably expect. What were the consequences? Let us go to the area of the Minister for Housing and Construction, who has just spoken. We inherited a position where in the last year housing starts were down 102,000 because they had not been giving the stimulus to housing. In the area of education, places in the tertiary system were declining. In the area of social security there was a declining real value of social benefits to the people of this country.

Why had that happened? It had happened because of the perverted sense of priority of these people here, who purport to stand up and talk now with some justice about taxation principles. They deliberately decided that those people in this country with the greatest capacity to pay some reasonable share into the revenue of this country should be protected so that they could avoid their liability, and in the process the very people who should have been protected and looked after had a lesser and lesser level of services provided to them. That is why I repeat what I said previously: We will welcome between now and the next election tax being the issue. With each passing month it will become more and more apparent that on the record of those opposite, they were members of the worst, most treacherous Government in the history of this country. It is this Government that is bringing into existence a fair and equitable system which will do two things: It will mean that tax will be fairly distributed and that government will therefore have the capacity to provide the services to the people which they deserve but never got under the previous Government, which was a Government of tax avoidance and protectors of the tax cheats.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to reports in yesterday's newspapers concerning a recommendation by the honourable member for McMillan, the chairman of the Prime Minister's country task force, that employers should be given an option under the fringe benefits tax legislation not to claim deductions for benefits provided to employees and therefore to reduce the amount of paper work involved with the fringe benefits tax. Will this recommendation form part of the review of the fringe benefits tax?

—In the review that is taking place the Treasurer and I and his officials will be listening to representations from the business community and from experts in the tax, accountancy and legal fields. Opportunity will also be provided to members of the Caucus to put their points of view, which will be considered. We have given the opportunity to the purported representative of the farmers of this country, the National Farmers Federation, but it has so much concern with trying to protect the interests of the people whom it purports to represent that it has declined to participate in the review.
—Will the Treasurer inform the House to what extent the tax avoidance activities which were rampant in this country during the 1970s and the 1980s are prevalent today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has been vigilant in the areas of tax evasion and avoidance in introducing legislation the moment any such contrived avoidance scheme has come into view. It has also, in the course of the last three years, introduced changes to the tax laws which would have accumulated costs to revenue of about $3 billion, and that is outside the area of tax reform. This is in marked contrast to the performance of our predecessors, and particularly the honourable member for Bennelong during his period as Treasurer. It is perhaps instructive that in the sixty-third report on taxation statistics, for 1983-84, which was presented to this Parliament and printed on 9 October 1984, the Commissioner of Taxation records the outstanding tax collections of individual trusts and companies under the schemes which were allowed to proliferate in the 1970s. It is very instructive. When the former Treasurer was first advised of these practices the outstanding debts relating to scheme taxpayers was $158m. When finally he was forced to legislate against the schemes the outstanding debts were $1.458 billion. They had increased ninefold.

ANSWER.PARA: This is despite the fact that we heard this plaintive plea from the Leader of the Opposition yesterday making some phoney distinction between Part IVa and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act, as if in some way he had been less than tardy in dealing with Part IVa. We find from the massive telephone book of letters presented by the former Commissioner that the former Treasurer was first advised of the weakness of existing section 260 in February 1978, but the Bill to introduce Part IVa of the tax system was not introduced until May 1981-three years and three months later. The honourable member for Bennelong is nodding; well he might. As I indicated yesterday, in the areas of evasion and avoidance the unconscionable three-year delay saw this massive growth in the statistics of income tax debt outstanding over those three years.

We are now being presented with the views of the Leader of the Opposition as to how he would deal with fringe benefits and the rutted-in variety of tax minimisation as distinct from the total overt evasion schemes, the criminal schemes, of the 1970s. He asks us to believe that in some way in shining up his tax credentials, his tax reform badge, Part IVa would be used by him, as the Prime Minister indicated, in conjunction with other parts of the tax law to try to deal with fringe benefits, which the Commissioner yesterday said is not possible without a fringe benefits-type tax. The fact is that the obfuscation which went on in this period was the sham defence of the former Treasurer. It is instructive, I think, to repeat that when the then Leader of the Opposition moved a censure motion against him on 25 August 1982 he said:
If he-
the Leader of the Opposition-

recalls that experience he will know the nature of the administrative responsibilities of the Australian Taxation Office under the Income Tax Assessment Act. He will know the nature of the secrecy provisions of the Act.
He went on:
He will know the great and proper importance attached . . . to the preservation of confidentiality . . .

So the principle charge of the Leader of the Opposition-that is, that I either knew or ought to have known-is not just contradicted by me or by the Attorney-General; it is also contradicted by Costigan himself. Of course, Costigan did not know about the telephone book of letters which had been presented to the Leader of the Opposition. The fact that he says that I either knew or should have known is not just contradicted by me; he contradicts it knowing the Parliament did not know of the years of memos and pleas by the Taxation Commissioner to do something about the criminal evasion schemes. But of course the Parliament was unaware of all that until much later. He continues:
. . . the Treasurer of the Commonwealth shall be able to gain full access to taxation information . . . as things stand at present that facility is not available.

The fact is that it was entirely available. It was being written. There were almost desperate, shrill pleas by the Taxation Commissioner for something to be done about it as the tax statistics kept piling up. That was the defence, the section 16 provision which went to names, not to the variety or the nature of the schemes. One did not need to know the names; one needed to know just the nature of the scheme and the fact that they existed. One also needed the political authority to legislate and to deal with them administratively. That was being denied the Taxation Office by Treasurer Howard in his period of office. Yet he would have us believe that this Government, which is making the only earnest attempt that has been made to deal not only with the evasion and avoidance schemes but also with the rutted-in variety of fringe benefits, should be attacked daily by an Opposition which, as a government, had such an appalling record on tax that it allowed the unconscionable growth in these outstanding debts from these overt paper criminal evasion schemes.

It is worth reading the record of the former Treasurer. It is worth reading his defence to Costigan. He said he did not know of the information and months later we got the O'Reilly telephone book which says that he knew everything. The defence was a fraud. That is his record. We will never, ever accept from this man any criticism on tax policy. This is a party which, as a government, allowed such an enormous evasion of the scheme to take place. When this Government is in there trying to make the tax system fair and decent for ordinary Australians we will not accept with any basis of veracity, any basis of morality or any basis of virtue that any view members of the Opposition may have as a group about the Government's tax changes should in any way divert the Government from its course of making the Australian tax system decent and fair for all Australians.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH BANKING CORPORATIONCOMMONWEALTH BANK OF AUSTRALIACOMMONWEALTH SAVINGS BANK OF AUSTRALIAANDCOMMONWEALTH DEVELOPMENT BANK OF AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to statute, I present the annual reports and financial statements of the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the Commonwealth Savings Bank of Australia and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, together with the Auditor-General's report thereon, for the year ended 30 June 1986.
—For the information of honourable members, I present the text of a statement on the future administration of the Australian Capital Territory.

—Madam Speaker, with your indulgence, the Opposition did not ask to have this paper noted, but I simply place on the record that we do not accept that it is a proper way of dealing with statements to have them tabled. This is a statement by a Minister who, as I understand it, is a member of this House. There is no reason why he could not ask for leave to make a statement. We would give him that leave. It is not really in the best traditions of the Parliament for the Minister simply to table his written statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—Please proceed.

—I claim to have been misrepresented-it is getting contagious-this time by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as well as by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). When answering a question, I think from his own side-no, I am sorry, it was in answer to a question which I had asked-the Prime Minister--
—Get your facts right.
—I have got all day.
—We haven't.
—The honourable member might have to sit here all day if he does not stop interrupting.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition has the call from the Chair. Those on my right will cease interjecting.
—During his answer the Prime Minister had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Madam Speaker, with the 9 per cent increase in real wages which characterised the last year of the conservative government . . .

In other words, the Prime Minister was alleging falsely, and deliberately so, that real wages rose by 9 per cent in real terms during the last year of the Government. The official statistics available to me, and ones--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! This is not a personal explanation.
—With great respect, Madam Speaker, the figure in the Treasury Round-up is 3.6 per cent and the Prime Minister has been misleading the House--
—Order! The honourable member must show the House how he personally has been misrepresented.
—You have got to be joking. Madam Speaker, the whole context, directly and indirectly, of the Prime Minister's response was that wages grew by a certain level--
—Where is the personal misrepresentation?
—With great respect, Madam Speaker, I find it astonishing that a Prime Minister can come in here and falsely allege that I--
—Order! Will the honourable member get on with his personal explanation?
—I have been misrepresented in that the Prime Minister dishonestly and falsely asserted--

—Order! The honourable member cannot say those things. He will withdraw the comments that he made about the Prime Minister. The honourable member must withdraw the comments. If he wishes to criticise the Prime Minister, he must do so under a substantive motion.
—Madam Speaker, I seek your guidance. The guidance I seek relates to the fact that the Prime Minister has made a totally inaccurate allegation--
—Order! Will the honourable member first withdraw the comments he made about honesty and dishonesty?
—With deference to you, Madam Speaker--
—Not with deference, just withdraw.
—I will be friendly; I will withdraw.
—Will the honourable member please finish his personal explanation?

—The false allegation that was made by the Prime Minister, the incorrect allegation, was that real wages during the last year of the Fraser Government rose by 9 per cent. That was the figure the Prime Minister used. The truth is that they rose by 3.6 per cent. In other words, the Prime Minister has exaggerated to the tune of about 300 per cent.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I remind members of the House that personal explanations are made with the indulgence of the Chair. They are expected to show how they personally have been misrepresented.
—Well--
—No, the honourable member has finished. Honourable members are not expected to debate the issues. I have another personal explanation.

—No, I am sorry, Madam Speaker, I have not finished. There was another misrepresentation by the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister, in answering a question from his own side dealing with the operation of Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act, falsely claimed that I was--
—`Inaccurately claimed' might be better.

—I think `falsely' is more accurate, but I will settle for `inaccurately'. The Prime Minister inaccurately claimed that I had been making assertions about the operation of Part IVa and the interaction with that section of section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. In the course of falsely misrepresenting me, the Prime Minister falsely claimed--

—Order! Will the Leader of the Opposition get to the point of his personal explanation? If he wishes to criticise the Prime Minister he should do so under a substantive motion. The Chair's indulgence is running out.
—Madam Speaker, I will bow to that ruling. The Prime Minister falsely claimed that in his speech yesterday--

—The Leader of the Opposition is doing it again. If he wishes to accuse the Prime Minister or criticise the Prime Minister he will do so under a substantive motion, as he will for any other member of the House.
—Madam Speaker, the situation is that if the Prime Minister says something of me which is incorrect--
—You correct it.
—I correct it. The correction I make is that the Prime Minister falsely alleged--
—No. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. The Chair will no longer hear him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition making forthwith a statement to the House on those issues on which he has been misrepresented.

Madam Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has been seeking to make a personal explanation to the House about misrepresentations made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about the administration of the Leader of the Opposition, as Treasurer of this country. The only way that the Leader of the Opposition can explain where he has been misrepresented seemingly is by my moving for the suspension of so much of Standing Orders as would enable him to make a statement to the House on the matters on which he has been misrepresented. There is a procedure within our Standing Orders which apparently he is to be denied. If he is to be denied that procedure, we must go through the processes of this Parliament so that he may be allowed to make his explanation.

Madam Speaker, it has been the practice of the House to permit personal explanations. The Leader of the Opposition sought to avail himself of that and I suggest to you that, instead of proceeding with this motion, it would be far easier if you were to permit the Leader of the Opposition to make his personal explanation in the normal course. I suggest that that is more appropriate than our proceeding with the suspension of Standing Orders when there is a procedure available which would allow a proper correction of the matters which are are at the moment standing on the record but which are incorrect. The fact that they directly involve the Leader of the Opposition and that they have not been allowed to be corrected has led to my moving for the suspension of Standing Orders.

It is essential that any member of this place, whether he be the Leader of the Opposition or a member holding some other position in this Parliament, have the opportunity to respond if a false statement is made about him. I suggest to you, Madam Speaker that the statements made during Question Time today are such a case. We all heard those statements-the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was calling the administration of the Leader of the Opposition a fraud. There was no suggestion that he had to say that by some type of resolution; it was allowed; he could make those remarks. It was with respect to those remarks and others that the Leader of the Opposition quite properly tried to avail himself of the normal Standing Orders procedure, and I suggest that rather than debate this suspension of Standing Orders motion it would be preferable to permit the Leader of the Opposition to behave as every other member of this House is required to-that is, to seek your leave on the matter of a personal misrepresentation and for you to allow him to make an explanation to the House. He was seeking to do just that when you required him to sit down. If there is no alternative, we will vote on the suspension of Standing Orders to allow the Leader of the Opposition forthwith to make a statement to the House on this very matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not agree to the suspension of Standing Orders. I have never seen the Opposition so rattled, and I have never seen the generous interpretation of `personal explanation' given by you, Madam Speaker, so abused. In relation to the first matter on which the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) sought to make a personal explanation his name was not even mentioned. There was reference to the administration of the Fraser Government. It was called `the former Administration'. I am going on what the Leader of the Opposition said. He said that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) had alleged that there was a certain increase in wages in the last year of the former Government, and now the Leader of the Opposition wants to make a personal explanation on all the mistakes of the Fraser Government. We will be here for 10 years on personal explanations as the Leader of the Opposition explains away all the mistakes of the Fraser Administration. We hear enough of that outside now. Only about two people opposite are prepared still to be loyal to Malcolm Fraser. They all blame Malcolm for their being on the Opposition benches. Now the Leader of the Opposition says that he wants to abuse the right given to him by the Chair, specifically to make a personal explanation, to explain away some difference of opinion as to what the Prime Minister said the wage rise was and what he thinks it was during the last year of the Fraser Administration.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot allow the Parliament to fall into disrepute because of personal explanation of that nature, and the only reason the Opposition raises such matters is that it is totally incompetent. Opposition members cannot ask the questions, they cannot debate the issues, they do not know how to use the Parliament and they have no policies. They have the full trifecta as far as nonsense is concerned. The honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) is always yapping at the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), but where is the Opposition's health policy? The shadow Minister for Industrial Relations is always yapping away about industrial relations, but where is their policy? Where are all the policies they are supposed to have? The most honest person over there is the person who has been told by the Leader of the Opposition to shut up-the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt). What a terrifying phone call that must have been! He was sitting up there at his home at Moree, or somewhere, when someone said that big John was on the phone: `Ralph, shut up; you are saying too much'. That would have terrified him, would it not?

The Deputy Leader of the National Party knows what is right and so do a lot of others over there. So do many members of the farming community. The payment of school fees, the provision of Mercedes-Benz cars and all those things are a rip-off, but where is the Opposition's policy? Members of the Opposition want to criticise the Treasurer (Mr Keating) about the policies brought in by the Labor Government to bring some equity and justice back into the taxation system, but the Opposition's spokesmen get on television shows and are mute; they cannot say a thing. They do not stand for anything. They are hoping to bumble along for the next 18 months and make their way into government without any policies at all.

This attitude was not the policy of the elected Leader of the Opposition in September 1985. We were not going to have any more of that Peacockism of saying nothing and doing nothing and hoping that they could win the next election. Under the new Leader of the Opposition they were to have policies galore. Everyone would know where the Liberal-National Party Opposition stood on all of the great issues in Australia. Can they just tell us, across the table, whether they will tax the free Mercedes? The Leader of the Opposition sits there. No, he does not know whether the Opposition will tax the free Mercedes or school fees or golf club fees or free trips overseas. The Deputy Leader of the National Party knows. He gave an honest opinion to the country folk, and he was being honest about it because that is what his constituents were saying to him. He was listening to his constituents in the bush, and they said that there were too many rip-offs, totalling $700m, by people who were not paying taxes while all the wage and salary earners, whether they lived in the bush or in the city, were being taxed up to 60c in the dollar.

Members of the Opposition talk about initiative in Australian industry. They strangled initiative in our industries. Whether they were rural industries or industries in the city, whatever the industry was the Opposition strangled it. They know that, and now they cannot bring forward a policy to argue for; it can put nothing up against what the Government is doing-it just wants to use personal explanations. The Government will not facilitate the use of the Parliament for such personal explanations. I have never seen such an abuse of the system of personal explanations as that indulged in by the Leader of the Opposition. Why does he not learn to speak in debates and ask questions if he wants to find out some of these things? He should use the Parliament in the way the Parliament ought to be used and not abuse it just because it suits the silly matters he brings forward after Question Time every day. If he wants to apologise for Malcolm Fraser he should do it at Liberal Party headquarters or at his latest find, the $100 dinners of the H. R. Nicholls Society, which he tumbles along to now to apologise for the Liberal Party. The honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) know what they are up to with the H. R. Nicholls Society. He should read the speeches of his colleagues in relation to what the H. R. Nicholls Society is trying to do to the Liberal Party in Australia. That is far more important than apologising for Malcolm Fraser. They are the major issues that the conservatives of Australia will have to sort out. They should listen to the honourable member for Boothby and the honourable member for Goldstein and stop trying to abuse privileges such as that given to the Leader of the Opposition by a very generous Speaker who has given him time to make personal explanations but not to speak on issues in regard to which he is not mentioned. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—In response to a question during Question Time the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) indicated that I had said that the Government's health budget would blow out by $120m. Whilst the Government's health budget has never been in accordance with the Budget Estimates, I did not say that. What I did say during my response to legislation in this House was:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that if increase in the growth of utilisation continues at the same rate as last year, expenditure on medical services and the Budget deficit have both been . . . understated by $120m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ANDREW; BEALE; BRAITHWAITE; CADMAN; CAMERON; DRUMMOND; EDWARDS; HAWKER; MILDREN; ROBINSON; RUDDOCK; SHIPTON; SLIPPER; SMITH
PETITION.NAMEIDS: HE4; OE4; 0F4; SD4; BF4; Y87; 9G4; 8H4; AI4; YI4; 0J4; CJ4; 0V5; GJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many Post Office Agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport.

We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew,Mr Beale,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mr Ian Cameron,Mr Drummond,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hawker,Mr Mildren,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Ruddock,Mr Shipton,Mr Slipper and Mr Smith.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BLUNT; CADMAN; COBB; COLEMAN; CONNOLLY; DOBIE; EDWARDS; HICKS; MOUNTFORD; NEHL; ROBINSON; RUDDOCK; SINCLAIR
PETITION.TITLE: Anzac Rifle Range, Malabar
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That over 67,000 men, women and students enjoy the pursuit of their sport and recreation every year at the Anzac Rifle Range at Malabar and have done so since 1967.

2. The people of Sydney through their membership of 41 clubs headquartered at the Anzac Rifle Range together with a number of other community, school and commercial groups, the police and armed forces will lose this community facility if the Federal Government proceeds to sell the Range to private developers.
3. The Australian Bicentenary Fullbore Rifle Championships are to be conducted at the Anzac Rifle Range in April 1988 as part of the celebration of Australia's Bicentenary.
Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to retain the Anzac Rifle Range for the continued use and enjoyment of the people of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blunt,Mr Cadman,Mr Cobb,Mr Coleman,Mr Connolly,Mr Dobie,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr Hicks,Mr Mountford,Mr Nehl,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Ruddock, and Mr Sinclair.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a Referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Griffiths,Mr McArthur,Ms Mayer and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen,Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs its imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs its imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned at the impact of the new Fringe Benefits Tax on the following grounds:
1. Its severe and damaging effect on business confidence, investment and incentive, especially in the rural, mining and small business sectors.
2. Its capacity to seriously worsen unemployment through the additional costs its imposes.
3. Its extremely negative impact on the competitiveness of export industries at a time when the nation desperately needs to improve its trading performance.

4. In that it may compel many honest and decent citizens to defy the Tax in order to preserve their livelihoods, their businesses and the jobs of their employees, thus causing hardship, the breakdown of respect for the law and discord within the community.
We therefore most earnestly petition you to repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation forthwith.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 is having a detrimental effect on the car industry generally in South Australia, and more particularly, on employment in that industry.

2. The Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Bill 1986 contains many anomalies, inconsistencies and mistakes in drafting and its administrative implementation is an unwarranted burden on Australian business and the Australian taxpayer.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that this House repeal as a matter of utmost urgency this regressive legislation which imposes a disincentive to economic and employment growth, thereby jeopardising the well-being and living standards of all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Fringe Benefits Tax is an iniquitous and unjust impost which will further damage the Australian economy and further increase costs to employers.
The Tax will:
(1) further increase the level of unemployment;
(2) increase the administrative costs and overheads for business and Government;
(3) particularly disadvantage small businesses and farmers; and
(4) act as a disincentive to those who are the most productive and skilled;
and we the undersigned call upon the Government to immediately repeal the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The Fringe Benefits Tax will cause hardship to business throughout Australia, especially in the already severely depressed rural sector and in the motor vehicle industry.
The Fringe Benefits Tax will be a disincentive to employment and worse, will result in additional unemployment.

The economy of this country would best be served by policies that lightened the tax burden, not increased it, that encouraged enterprise, not stifled it, and stimulated growth, development and jobs, not prevented it.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will repeal this legislation, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate;
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Hawker and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned plead that the Parliament implement pro-family policies. In particular we appeal for:
1. the retention of the present graduated assessment system for payment of the Family Allowance;
2. indexation of the Family Allowance in order to keep pace with inflation;

3. an increase of 3.7% in the Family Allowance benefit to return it to 11.5% of the Average Award Wage (making it similar in value to the 11.5% of the Basic Wage when Child Endowment was first introduced by the Chifley Government in 1941).
4. retention of the Dependent Spouse Rebate and the amount of the Dependent Spouse Rebate adjusted so that it is equal in value to the tax-free threshold allowed when calculating taxable income.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances and Spouse Rebate
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
the failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependants who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many larger families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI;
the dependent spouse rebate be retained;
the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker,Ms Mayer and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum. And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Social Justice, Equity and Redistribution of Wealth
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned citizens of Australia, hereby petition the Prime Minister as leader of the Australian Labor Party in Government in Australia and humbly showeth that:

The voting public of Australia did in March 1983 and again in December 1984 vote as a majority for the election of a Labor Government who did claim to stand for social justice, equity and redistribution.
