That the said voters sincerely believed that a contract was entered into in voting for a Labor Government with democratic socialist principles.

That there is an erosion of support for the pensioners, the unemployed, the aged, the sick and the working class of Australia, while the lot of the privileged class, the banks, the oil companies, and the money-changers continues to improve.

Your Petitioners call on the Australian Labor Government to implement those policies and follow those principles of social justice, equity and redistribution which the majority of Australians voted for in 1983 and in 1984, and to adopt an immediate programme that will transfer the current economic burden to those better able to carry it.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Kent,Mr Milton and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforcable rights;
that the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
that the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
that the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you will oppose the Bill of Rights, support Liberal amendments to improve it in case it is passed, and pledge to repeal it should it become law.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron and Mr Hawker.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament Assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

By cutting ESL funding and eliminating funding for community languages and multicultural education you have attacked tens of thousands of Australian children. You have condemned these children with limited English to gross educational inequality and very dim prospects for their future.
On behalf of these children we call on you to remove this new discrimination which your budget has guaranteed by immediately restoring ESL and Multicultural education funding.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Coleman and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the Bill of Rights is not supported by the people of Australia, and calls on the Government to:
Delay proclamation of the Bill until all matters of contention are settled by national referenda, and that:
(1) Matters of States rights, property rights, rights of the newborn, the right not to belong to unions, among other issues, have not been submitted to the people of Australia to decide, and that;
(2) No Australian Bill of Rights should depend on any foreign convention for its basis in Australia law.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
that we the citizens of the Illawarra Region condemn the decision to close the Wollongong office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs
and that we respectfully request that this decision be reversed immediately.
An your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners are gravely concerned about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Mssrs, Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We, the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act as amended in 1985, and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the Government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Government should cancel the Fringe Benefits Tax they intend to impose on businesses throughout Australia because:
1. The tax discriminates against charitable organisations, sports clubs, private schools and religious organisations;
2. The tax will mean employees around Australia will suffer reductions in their renumeration packages;
3. The Bill places another impossible burden of paperwork on small business;
4. The Bill is absurd in its application to Government employees, who now constitute 32% of the workforce.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Bill of Rights is a dangerous piece of legislation which gives us no new legally enforceable rights;
That the Bill of Rights leaves out vital rights such as the right not to belong to a trade union, the right to own private property, the right to a private education;
That the Bill of Rights gives dangerous new powers to a Federal Government Commission to investigate in private, without legal representation and with criminal penalties for refusing to co-operate;
That the Bill of Rights deals with our rights; therefore we, the people, should say whether we want it by a referendum.

Your petitioners humbly pray that you repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Maranoa electorate respectfully showeth that:
The current government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and local governments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:

Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefits Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the Hawke Government should;
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices;
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes, and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's failure to act to correct the many anomalies in the Assets Test on pensions brought to its notice, the Labor Government's legislation should be repealed before it has an unduly unfair impact on pensioners.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of the Labor Government's iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Free Zones
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of Australia shows:

That the people of New Zealand and the New Zealand Government have given an example to the world in their efforts to achieve a nuclear free South Pacific, and such decision being endorsed by the people at a general election.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government support the principled stand taken by the New Zealand Government and urges it to condemn any efforts by the U.S. Government to impose economic or other sanctions on New Zealand in retaliation for their stand on nuclear vessels.
We further urge the Australian Government to urgently implement its policy to promote the development of zones of peace and nuclear free zones in the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 3EA
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia of Albanian back-ground respectfully showeth: We most strongly oppose the use of the ``special broadcasting service'' and the taxpayers funds for nationalist political purposes.

We are deeply concerned that the existing Albanian program on Radio 3EA Melbourne is not meeting the needs of the community. It is being used against its interests, as well as the interests of the broader Australian society.
We respectfully believe that such use of public facilities undermines Australian principles of multi-culturalism and has a damaging effect on community relations.

Your petitioners therefore, strongly urge the Government to take immediate action to ensure that the present announcers of the Albanian program are removed and replaced with community representatives.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Administration Fee
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The introduction of an administrative charge for annual enrolment will restrict access to higher education for a range of disadvantaged groups, particularly women, rural dwellers and some low income earners.
2. Students will be deterred from study because of the probable escalation in the charge in future Budgets, prohibiting students' ability to plan the long term costs of their education.

3. The introduction of an administrative charge is contrary to the education provisions of the ALP/ACTU Accord and ALP policy which states that the party ``will maintain the provision of free tertiary education.''
Your petitioners therefore pray that the annual administrative charge for higher education students not be introduced.
Your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Alternative Multi-channel Television Broadcasting System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of we, the undersigned respectfully showeth that the proposed government plan for aggregation of the regional television services of Australia will have a very destructive effect on the existing local services. Through aggregation the regional broadcasters will be forced into a situation of being merely a relay point for the ponderous networks. This in turn would place an even greater obstacle before the regional population in access to the media for communication, advertising, news, local disaster relief assistance and most importantly employment. The starting point for many young people in this industry has been provided by these regional operators. This avenue would virtually disappear along with a considerable number of existing jobs.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the alternative Multi Channel System as proposed by the majority of the regional operators and endorsed by Mr Duffy and the two Caucus committees be implemented.

This approach to the plan for increased services to the regional areas of Australia would have the very desirable effect of providing a tailored service for the respective areas. Some viewers would receive the added benefit of being able to choose between regional and metropolitan signals.
The ability of the regional operators to provide further employment would be enhanced. We believe that the M.C.S. alternative is by far the better way to proceed.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Obscene Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will re-invoke the blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity proscriptions into the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, by adding those proscriptions to the present Section 4a, sub-regulation 1a (b) (i), for the following reasons;
because there is a flood of obscene publications into the country,
because such publications depict the abnormal as normal
because such publications degrade men and women
because such publications create new, offensive demands on women, with which they do not willingly comply (Eysenck and Nias)
because this causes marriage breakdown
because children easily obtain such publications
because children copy what they see

because the child found in possession of such publications is at risk, facing rejection, and carrying the burden of having altered the relationships in his home for the worse, between parents, and between parent and child
because such a child faces, alone, the loss of trust
because I am a reasonable adult person and I am offended by the obscene books which you have legislated into this community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention, and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant production to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:

Labor's Capital Gains Tax is standing in the way of economic development on the Far North Coast, a region with great potential for further growth and renowned for the enterprise and initiative of its local community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Repeal its anti-business anti-farming and anti-individual Capital Gains Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as is duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine the human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
The Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable taxation deductions;
that the Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is an unwarranted burden on the small business and rural sectors, which will severely affect their long term viability.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government withdraws the Fringe Benefits Tax legislation without delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the certain citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
that all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
that the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long-term viability.
that the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Cambodian Refugees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, electors of the Division Prospect shows the Thai Government recently announced that Khao-I-Dang refugee camp will be closed on 31st December 1986. More than 25,000 Cambodian refugees who survived the ``Killing Fields'' of the Khmer Rouge and entered Thailand after 1979 are still resident in Khao-I-Dang. We hold grave fears for the future and safety of these refugees who will be relocated to camps along the Thai-Cambodian border when Khao-I-Dang is closed.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will uphold its enviable humanitarian record and act with all haste to facilitate the acceptance and resettlement of as many of these refugees as possible, including a proportion of those who have no relatives to sponsor them.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Sales to France
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned, respectfully showeth that we, the people of Victoria would like to remind you of your moral duty in regard to your decision to sell Uranium to France, against ALP policy.
The French are still nuclear testing in the South Pacific, despite world wide protests. We therefore call on you to reverse the decision to sell uranium to France.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair;
It will severely disadvantage both employees and employers;
Employees will clearly lose many fringe benefits as a direct result of the additional heavy taxation burden being imposed upon employers;
Employers will be forced to pay even higher levels of taxation to provide fringe benefits for employees.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:
The legislation to tax fringe benefits is iniquitous, inequitable and unfair;
It will severely disadvantage both employees and employers;
Employees will clearly lose many fringe benefits as a direct result of the additional heavy taxation burden being imposed upon employers;
Employers will be forced to pay even higher levels of taxation to provide fringe benefits for employees.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
that the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Compulsory Unionism
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:

that the actions of trade unions have gone beyond their traditional goals of protecting workers' conditions and rates of pay and have reached the point where they are seriously affecting the economic health of the nation and the people.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
1. That all Governments throughout Australia acknowledge and protect the Right to Work on behalf of all Australians.
2. That the total sovereignty of individual governments be recognised as a fundamental requirement of a workable, balanced Federal system of government.
3. That all necessary steps be taken to protect the citizens of Australia from any inducement, compulsion, threat or intimidation to join any trade unions.
4. That there should be no preference in employment for people who are members of trade unions.
5. That the supremacy of elected governments over the sectional interests of trade unions be recognised, and
6. That the provision of essential services be maintained, free from industrial disruption.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the title deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985.

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner.

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most white and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia.
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Federal Division of Fisher respectfully showeth that:

The proposed capital gains tax penalises small business, discourages long-term investment, hinders capital formation and will freeze existing investment patterns and limits the investors' ability to adjust to changed market conditions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately abandon its ill-considered capital gains tax proposal.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The high cost to the Australian community arising from the intended and unintended consequences of the Hawke Government's Capital Gains Tax.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, the Opposition asked the Treasurer of this nation (Mr Keating) three questions on the capital gains tax. Clearly the Treasurer could not answer those three questions-could not rather than would not. I remind the House that over a period of months I asked the Treasurer a number of questions about tax and he dismissed them all with contempt. The Press Gallery interpreted his failure to answer as some failure of the Opposition in that it asked unduly complicated questions. I actually wrote to the editor of one of those newspapers whose reporter had said that I had asked an unduly complicated question. I gave the editor the text of the question I had asked, which was in fact perfectly simple, and I said that, if the reporter could not understand that question, questions should be asked about the reporter. More seriously, if the Treasurer of Australia could not understand that question the Treasurer of Australia should be fired.

SPEECH.PARA: The cover of this Treasurer is blown on tax. There is no way that he knew the slightest detail of the taxes he introduced into this House in May. It is quite clear that he did not understand anything about the fringe benefits tax and it is also becoming absolutely clear that he does not understand the first thing about the capital gains tax-and he never has. He said that he would not answer any questions put by the Opposition until such time as we agreed with the capital gains tax. I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that hell will freeze over before we agree to a capital gains tax. If the Treasurer thought that getting on to the fringe benefits tax train was going to be a long journey, I can tell the Treasurer that the capital gains tax train will go from here to Darwin and back before the Opposition will drop this matter. I can also say to the Treasurer that he had better do a quick learning course on the capital gains tax because he will be asked question after question on the capital gains tax. If he thinks that the fringe benefits tax is just a raging infection out there in the community, he will find that the capital gains tax is a slow-acting cancer on the community and on the future of this Government.

This tale of infamy on the capital gains tax goes right back to the 1983 policy speech of the current Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Hawke). To his discredit I have to quote these words every time I talk about the capital gains tax-and I will continue to do so. This is what the Prime Minister of Australia said to the Australian people as his solemn pledge before this Government came into office:
And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it, and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion, there will be no new capital gains tax.

That was the pledge of the Prime Minister. In the next election campaign in 1984 the Prime Minister was asked about this matter and he gave no answer. He gave no indication that there would be a capital gains tax. Indeed, the first thing the Government did when it got back into office was to proceed to implement a capital gains tax. The way in which it was put forward was disgraceful. It was announced on 19 September 1985 in the Treasurer's statement on the reform of the Australian taxation system-RATS. It was months and months before the legislation came into the House. In fact, it came into the House on 28 May-all 103 pages of it-breaking one of the most important principles enunciated by the Prime Minister: That any new tax should be simple to understand and operate.

This legislation of 103 pages came into the House after the Government had had eight months to prepare it, but it had no explanatory memorandum. I have it now. I was given the explanatory memorandum on the night that the debate in this House was closing as the Minister opposite at the table, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer (Mr Hurford), was coming in to sum up for the Treasurer. Let us note who is the Minister at the table. The Treasurer has failed to come into the House. He has failed to answer three questions on the capital gains tax, he has failed to come into the House to defend himself and he has sent in the assistant Minister, the Minister who has the task of signing not only the farewell Bob tax letters but also the capital gains tax letters in increasing numbers. I say to honourable members that, since we have the Minister who was the runner-up for the position of the wooden spoon-he did not even get the wooden spoon itself-now that Wooden Spoon is back, Scoop is starting to look good. I prefer the Scoop to the Wooden Spoon, I think. So the Assistant Minister, who is at the table, is welcome to answer the questions. If he does not answer the questions or the arguments, he will be treated in exactly the same way as we shall treat the Treasurer in succeeding months. He will not get away with this tax. The tax will eat away at the Government just as it is eating away at the people of Australia.

It came in with 103 pages of extraordinary complication, with 155 pages of explanatory memorandum. We also got an explanatory booklet of 64 pages. We had 14 pages of rulings and 38 pages of Press releases trying to explain the details of the tax as queries have arisen. So we are building up, but have not quite got to the level of the fringe benefits tax. We are half way there. We still have the video to come and also the replacement video when the first one is found to be faulty, as the fringe benefits tax was found to be faulty. When the Treasurer introduced the matter into the House in September, he misled us. He said in the statement of 19 September:
This tax will affect only a tiny section of the population. Its expected revenue yield in the fifth year of operation is estimated to be only $25m.

That was an incredible statement. It could have been made only by somebody who did not have the slightest understanding of the ramifications of the tax. One has to read through only the first 10 of the 103 pages to know that it affects pretty well everybody, as I shall demonstrate. I will not have time today to demonstrate how it affects everybody; that will take days and days and weeks and weeks. There is example upon example of how this affects people which will be a shock for a whole lot of people.

We are talking today not only about unintended consequences, as we did yesterday on the fringe benefits tax, but also about intended consequences. This is a typical Labor envy tax. It is a tax which penalises the risk takers, the improvers. It penalises new wealth rather than old wealth. That is an interesting concept for the Labor Party to put forward. That Party takes the view that it stands for the little people and wishes to diminish wealth. It brings in a tax that protects wealth to a point before 19 September last year, but penalises young people, risk takers, entrepreneurs, the new people who are to build the new Australia. As usual, the socialist principle of envy carries on its destructive effects on the very people in the community we want to support and encourage.

If a family starts a new small business-the kind of people who give up the security of a fully paid job, workers compensation, annual holidays, leave loadings and all sorts of other benefits-and risks everything it owns to build a business, members of that family are building that business not just for themselves but for Australia. They create wealth and jobs. They are the people who have made this country what it is. I refer to people in small businesses, people who have built up farms, people who have risked their all, people who are prepared to work long hours for very little income, people who want to build something for themselves and their children, their grandchildren and for Australia. They are the people who will be hit by this capital gains tax. Compared with average award-paid workers, with all their privileges and security, many people in farms and small businesses are taking much lower income and they make great sacrifices and take risks. There is nobody to pay them sickness benefits, no company doctor to look after them, no chaplain or anybody provided by a big company. They are there on their own and they take that risk. Under this new government tax together with the fringe benefits tax, those people will be stripped of the fruits of their efforts to an extraordinary degree. The tragedy is that in future many will not even bother to make the effort. We have no idea of the extent of the damage this tax will cause because the damage is there in what has not happened and cannot be measured. That is the damnable aspect of this tax.

Let me deal with what I see as the unintended consequences. In the House today the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) misled the Australian people about the principal residence, which he said was exempt from the tax. People had better be very careful about that statement because it simply is not true. A whole stream of consequences arises from this tax on the family home. Let me give the House some of them. I have not much time, but this will be only the opening of the account in this long saga of the capital gains tax which will be very sad for the Government.

The capital gains tax exemption on the family home is based on the qualification that the family home be not used for income-producing purposes. If a member of the family pays rent or board, the family home will lose its exemption, either in whole or in part. Similarly, if the family home has a study used for work, then a liability may be incurred. So be careful about that. The next item is that the sale of the family garden shed, storeroom or other structure will be subject to capital gains tax. This includes the case where a father gives his son the portable toolshed from the garden. In another case the capital gains tax will apply to a new family home purchased by a young couple while still living with their parents before their marriage. In other words, it is beginning to strike at the very heart of the formation of new families and new homes.

The tax will apply also to a young couple who are renting and who purchase a block for their family home. The young couple will find that the block is subject to capital gains tax. This could occur under conditions I will spell out. The exemption is available only if upon completion of the new home it is occupied for at least 12 months. So if the bank for which the young couple work transfers them somewhere else, they are liable for capital gains tax. Do they know that? They do not. The maximum exemption-free time allowed under this provision is four years. This relates to a couple who are staying at home with their parents and building a home. If because they are building themselves, or are not saving fast enough and the time lapse between acquisition and occupation exceeds four years, then the young couple will have to pay capital gains tax on a pro rata basis. So there are pitfalls here for young people buying their own homes.

Also, if the block is purchased by the young couple prior to their marriage and if one or both of them is during that time dependent on a parent, then for that period the block will not be exempt. If the family home is on more than two hectares-which can happen with hobby farms or in outer areas just outside cities, country towns and so on-it is subject to capital gains tax. Do all the thousands of people who are buying properties over two hectares just outside metropolitan areas know that they are not exempt? I do not think they do. If the family home is in excess of two hectares and one allows a neighbour to put in a drain at the back of the property, then under a quirk of the capital gains tax one is liable for the tax even though one receives no payment from the neighbour. I have no more time to go on with these examples. We have hundreds of them and we will bring them out every day until the tax goes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we have another example in the long line of pathetic matters of public importance brought to this House by this Opposition. If I may say so as kindly as I possibly can, it is another in the long line of pathetic efforts from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). In this debate it is necessary for us to put taxation policy in its proper perspective. The Hawke Labor Government inherited a tax system which was in a mess. It inherited it from these very people who are seeking to criticise us in this debate. It inherited a system which was and still is grossly unfair and inequitable. The Government inherited this system from these conservatives who have brought this pathetic matter of public importance before the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: Our Government has inherited this disastrous situation from a bunch of people whose leader was the Treasurer in the administration which bequeathed us this grossly inequitable taxation system. The little that was done while the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was Treasurer to improve this disgraceful tax system was done too late and, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) so graphically pointed out during Question Time today and yesterday, so grudgingly. The Treasurer absolutely demolished the Leader of the Opposition's weak attempts to claim credibility in the tax area. The Treasurer showed how the then hapless Commissioner of Taxation had to write to the then Treasurer 26 times in increasingly bitter terms before he could get that weak, disastrous Treasurer to come so reluctantly to this House with any semblance of taxation reform legislation. Yet it is these people who have the gall to bring to this House today a matter of public importance on the subject of taxation reform, criticising an inevitable and just reform that the Hawke Labor Government has brought to this country.

The contrast between the two sides in politics is this: We in the Australian Labor Party, true to our Party's traditions which go back uninterrupted to Federation and even earlier, believe in something. We are not just the protectors of the privileged, the better off and the lucky people in this life, as are honourable members opposite; we are not the defenders of the status quo; we are not the proponents of the do-nothing, easy life in politics. We in the Labor Party are proud that we believe in equity and justice and we are proud of the fact that this applies to the taxation system just as much as it does to anything else. We are proud of the fact that we are prepared to get on with the job of reforming our taxation system in order to bring equity and justice to it.

Like other countries, Australia needs a system that is fair, square and equitable. We suffered a terrible period of neglect during the many years of coalition governments in this country. Our country's taxation system has also suffered from the results of poor decisions from conservative judges placed on the benches by the conservatives of this country. Unless we have a system that is fair and square and unless the taxpayers accept that system as being fair and square, the system will go from bad to worse because there will be a poor degree of compliance by those taxpayers. Unless we have a system that is fair and square, we will find non-compliance leading to a lowering of the amount of revenue collected. This will have the consequence not only of increasing the burden of those honest people who do comply, but also of providing a lesser amount of funds for the social objectives of government expenditure when Labor is in government-the creation of a fairer society.

In order to get a fair and equitable system, a system which will gain and keep the respect of taxpayers and lead to their compliance, we must have a form of capital gains tax. Why should one group of people who earn their surpluses through gains on their capital be free of taxation on those surpluses at the expense of another group of people who earn their surpluses through, say, personal exertion at their places of work or by profits from their enterprises? Why should those who get these surpluses from capital gains be exempt from fair taxation? There is no earthly reason whatsoever why this should happen. No other comparable country, even that home of free enterprise, the United States of America, has such an inequity. No group, other than the Liberal and National Party members here in Australia, wants to put this extra burden on the wage, salary and profit earners of this country-that extra burden that is inevitably the result of capital gains not being properly taxed. Yet that is what coalition members want to do-put the burden on those who are not in a position to avoid and evade tax like those who are accumulating capital surpluses.

Honourable members should make no mistake about it: At the heart of most of the tax avoidance in the 1970s and early 1980s was the conversion of what should have been income to capital at the bottom of which was so much effort on the part of smart people who could have been doing Australia a good turn by putting their talents to industry, trade and other such enterprises, but who were scheming to convert income to capital in order to avoid tax. Those in government were at fault-those members opposite who have brought in this matter today. They were at fault not only because they had no capital gains tax and thus they allowed these things to happen, but also because, accordingly, personal tax rates were too high and this led to people spending so much time on tax avoidance. I concede that that is one of the reasons why we have had avoidance-because those personal tax rates were too high.

I am proud to be a member of a government which is doing something about both those issues. We have brought in a modest, sensible capital gains tax and we are reducing personal income tax as well. By our imputation proposal we are also encouraging enterprise within the corporate structures of this country. Along with our modest capital gains tax we are indexing cost values and taxing not nominal money gains but only the real gains at the time of realisation. By so doing we are putting a net under our tax system, so that respect and compliance will be restored. That is the context of this eminently reasonable approach that we have taken by bringing in a capital gains tax in this country.

Let me go into more detail. Apparently the Opposition wants the majority of Australian taxpayers-the honest pay as you earn taxpayers-to pay more tax so that the wealthy pay substantially less. It wants people who are able to accumulate these capital surpluses, and dishonest people as well, to be able to opt out of the tax system. It wants privileged executives and others to be allowed to continue to receive non-cash remuneration free of tax. That is what the fringe benefits tax debate is all about. The Opposition wants people to gain massive incomes through capital gain without paying taxation. The truth is that this Opposition has a secret fringe benefits tax and I have no doubt that it probably has a secret capital gains tax in its locker as well, but it is not prepared to come out with that at this stage. The arguments are overwhelmingly in favour of taxing surpluses on capital.

Let us look again at the consequences of not having capital gains taxes. The revenue lost would have to be gained through increasing taxation in other areas. This means that ordinary Australians would have to pay to support the rich. Opposition members are not prepared to end the rorts and rip-offs. The record of the failed Treasurer who is now the Leader of the Opposition demonstrates that. They are prepared to have the man in the street pay extra to support the luxuries of the rich and dishonest. Yet these are the people who nitpick during Question Time and during this matter of public importance debate about capital gains tax reform. Let me make it quite clear: The capital gains tax is firmly in place, it is here to stay and it is thoroughly fair and equitable. That is not to say that there will not be some fine tuning. All laws are under review all the time. Within the next hour I will bring in another tax reform Bill which contains some minor changes in clauses concerned with the capital gains tax. We will not do that fine tuning or announce changes during Question Time or during a matter of public importance debate such as this. There is no need whatsoever for a general review of this tax, nor have I said that there will be such a general review, in spite of the media comments and beat-ups which took place on Friday evening and in the Saturday newspapers. I have never said that, but I have said in Question Time just what I said to the House again today: We will be looking at certain clauses from time to time.

The Prime Minister said on about the first day we came to government in 1983 that we were not a group of people who considered that all wisdom lies here in Canberra. We are prepared to listen to the community and, if necessary, to improve any section of any Act which needs attention-we will not resile from that. That will be done if representations are properly put to us and are found to have merit. Of course, if one does nothing, as this Opposition did nothing when it was in government-it did not bring in any reforms and it let the rorts and rip-offs continue because it was not interested in reform-it is not difficult not to make mistakes. It is easy not to get things right first time, however, if a party of reform is prepared to make some tax reform changes. But it is incumbent on it then to make any necessary changes. We are a government of reform. We are intent on that reform and we will make changes to any single clause if we find that those changes are necessary. Under the previous Government, the one in which the Leader of the Opposition failed as Treasurer and the one which did too little-and what it did, it had to be dragged into doing-Australia was virtually unique among Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries in having no general capital gains tax.

What is the purpose of a capital gains tax? Let me go over this again in more detail. Real capital gains represent an increase in purchasing power, as do real increases in wages, salaries and other forms of income. The lack of a general capital gains tax led to major breaches of principle, equity and efficiency. Its absence discriminated in favour of people who obtained some or all of their income in the form of capital gains. Because ownership of capital is heavily concentrated among higher income groups, it is they who mainly benefited from the very concessional treatment of capital gains under the previous Government, which led to an inequitable share of the tax burden being borne by other taxpayers, in particular lower income earners. In addition, it enabled non-resident owners of Australian assets to avoid paying their fair share of tax.

A capital gains tax, as well as making the tax system fairer, will improve the performance of the economy. Its absence has distorted the pattern of investment by encouraging speculative activity as against investment in more productive activity. This has reduced the rate of growth of the Australian economy. By contrast, our capital gains tax actually encourages investment in all productive activities. The previous Government's refusal to introduce a general capital gains tax was also at the heart of the explosion of the tax avoidance industry while that Government was in power. It gave rise to all sorts of contrived paper schemes aimed at dressing up income as capital gains and hence avoiding income tax. The failure to introduce a capital gains tax showed just how unwilling the Opposition was to attack tax avoidance and evasion and to ensure that the burden of taxation was spread fairly throughout the community. A capital gains tax is a key element in any serious attack on tax avoidance and evasion. By opposing a capital gains tax the Opposition is showing that it is not dinkum about avoidance and evasion. A capital gains tax is part of the Government's package of reforms, whereas the Opposition has no policies whatsoever.

I end as I began: We on this side of the House, in contrast to our opponents, are people who stand for something-fairness, equity, equality of opportunity and a more just society. We will not be put off gaining our reforms by this Opposition bringing such pathetic matters of public importance to the House as it has today. A capital gains tax is essential for equity and justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first responsibility of the Government at Question Time is to give information. It is the responsibility of the Opposition to elicit information. This Government-I think it even has meetings about this-quite clearly feels that its responsibility is to deny the Parliament information. In denying the Parliament information it is denying the Australian people information which just might help them to understand this Government's new rules of self-assessment so that they can properly declare their tax responsibilities to the Commissioner of Taxation. Today, in the interests of those people, whom the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) has just said the Government is so interested in, we asked some pretty serious questions. We asked one question about how a house would be treated in certain circumstances; something this Government chose to exempt. It was no coincidence that we chose a house very similar to the one the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has, because we wanted to know whether the Treasurer or the Commissioner of Taxation would consider a house to be a principal residence in those circumstances. Of course the Treasurer would not, nor would the Commissioner of Taxation, but the Treasurer wants to consider it a principal residence so that he can give himself $17,000 to $20,000 worth of taxpayers' money tax free by way of travel allowance. That is why we asked the question. We got the usual push off from the Treasurer, who could not answer, even if he wanted to in those circumstances. He is the Treasurer of misinformation, and he has been doing it all his life. He could not lie straight in bed. It is interesting that he has managed to bluff the media for so long that they are now starting to wake up to him. Let us look at what Terry McCrann had to say in the Age of 3 October about the Treasurer and his overseas trip. This is not a matter of opinion; this is a matter of fact. Under the headline `Keating's claim is outrageously risky business', he said:

SPEECH.PARA: One certainly cannot fail to be impressed by the monumental arrogance of the man. But all his home-town trumpet solitaries fade almost into quietude before his performance at the annual IMF meetings this week.

For Paul Keating to stand up in Washington before the world's finance ministers and lecture the United States about economic policy-and hold out his performance down under as the model-takes some beating in the glorious annals of sheer bare-faced gall.

From the man whose sojourn as Treasurer has seen the dollar plummet, our Foreign debt soar, our triple-A disappear, our inflation run at multiples of that in the industrial countries we like to think we are one of, our interest rates stay at punishingly high record levels-etc. etc. etc. . . .
In short, from the man whose brief sojourn as Treasurer has seen Australia take one mighty step from First World towards Third World status, the secret of his ``success'' for all the world to share.
It is difficult to think of one measure of economic health and success in which Hawke-Keating's Australia outranks Reagan's America.
Unemployment 7 per cent in the US, 8 per cent down under; inflation 1.5 per cent there versus 8.5 per cent here-

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order.
—Sit down, you have no point of order. You deal with him, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat.
—This is a frivolous point of order.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will cease interjecting while the Chair is asking him to resume his seat. I call the honourable member for McEwen.

—The debate today, as fixed by the Opposition, refers to the high cost to the Australian community arising from the intended and unintended consequences of the Hawke Government's capital gains tax. The honourable member for O'Connor has yet to go on to the debate and has not yet raised one matter which is relevant to the debate.
—Order! I am hoping that the honourable member for O'Connor is coming to the question of the matter of public importance.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The point I am making is that two questions were asked of the Treasurer on the capital gains tax and he came out with his usual bravado, arrogance and attempts to mislead. I am making the point that while he was overseas he did not want to get out of practice; he tried it on the leading international monetary people of the world. That is a disgrace and a shame for Australia. I could go on, but I will not bother. We had more of that today at Question Time-we had the Minister and the Treasurer telling us all about tax avoidance under the previous Government and about Costigan. I read from page 33 of the Costigan report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ships Painters and Dockers Union, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.24 As I have mentioned, the Australian Taxation Office in Perth detected the operation of these schemes-
that is, the bottom of the harbour schemes-
as early as 1973 . . .

Who was in office in 1973? Certainly not the Liberal Government. If the schemes were detected in 1973, they had started before that, probably in 1972. In its full time the Whitlam Government, under various Treasurers, had an opportunity to correct that problem, which was well known to the Australian Taxation Office, but it did not. The schemes started under the Labor Government. What happened with the Curran scheme? Treasurer Crean knew plenty about that, did he not? If honourable members opposite want a history lesson as to who was pretty crook on tax I will give them one. But that is only half of it. I could go on with some of the things said about Treasurer Keating in that article by Terry McCrann. He identifies how the Treasurer went on and on, rounding out the figures by a few per cent here or something of a per cent somewhere else, telling fibs to people who would know better and would, no doubt, be laughing at him behind his back. All he knows is winning the argument. He does not understand anything but politics. It is a pity that he did not pick his friends a little better too. Some people in this country, such as Warren Anderson, have been reported to be very shonky. Warren Anderson had a tax problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Mr Deputy Speaker, there is nothing wrong with my mentioning Warren Anderson and I will move dissent from your ruling if you try to stop me.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat. First, the Chair will not tolerate threats from the honourable member for O'Connor.
—It is not a threat.

—Secondly, I suggest to the honourable member for O'Connor that, while it is the general practice of this House to allow discussion on matters of public importance, once introduced, to be fairly wide-ranging, he needs to be extremely careful that he is not approaching a matter that, to be considered, needs to be the subject of a substantive motion in the House.
—How can you predict the debate?
—That is outrageous.

—Order! I will not tolerate that from any honourable members. The honourable member for O'Connor needs to be careful that he is not approaching a matter that, to be considered, needs to be the subject of a substantive motion.
—How much time does he have?
—You are using up the speaker's time.

—If honourable members on my left are so discourteous to the Chair as to continue to interrupt-the honourable member for Mackellar or anyone else for that matter-they are taking up the time of their colleague. The honourable member for O'Connor needs to be sure that he is not approaching things in that way.
—You said that once. He can get on with it.
—I will not call the honourable member for O'Connor until his colleagues cease interjecting. I call the honourable member for O'Connor.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I had not mentioned a member of this House when I mentioned Warren Anderson. If you know so much about the links between Warren Anderson and the Treasurer, that is not my fault.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor is getting very close to reflecting on the Chair. The honourable member will resume his seat. I was not calling him to order on that matter; I was calling him to order on things he had referred to earlier.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am talking about a gentleman called Warren Anderson who has declined to deny that he had some $11m worth of bottom of the harbour tax claims against him which were reduced to $4.7m. We are also discussing the matter of capital gains tax. That man has substantial properties all over Australia which, no doubt, are subject to capital gains tax. We wonder whether his problems are the same as those of some other people. We have now discovered that if people who owned a freehold property in an operating business before 20 September now wish to sell a lease for $30,000 or $50,000-they might be in the circumstances that a Labor member mentioned yesterday of having a husband die and they are left with seven kids and have to sell a lease on that operating business-that $30,000 or $50,000 is now subject to a capital gains tax, and it will be reduced by half irrespective of that.

SPEECH.PARA: Warren Anderson is a friend of the Treasurer. It ill becomes the Treasurer to mix with someone who has already had tax avoidance problems, and it ill becomes him to take $300,000 for clocks and to miss the payment of capital gains tax when the clocks were worth only about $10,000. I am talking about the Treasurer. The clocks were not worth that. Getting $300,000 for those clocks was like placing a bet on a horse at the races after it had gone past the post. This is the man who will not come into the House and debate with us. This is the man whom I have got half way--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for McEwen.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I would like to move an extension of time for the honourable member for O'Connor.

—There would need to be a suspension of Standing Orders for the honourable member to do that. Prior to calling the honourable member for Curtin I had called the honourable member for McEwen. The honourable member might be aware of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that this debate is not being televised so that all of Australia could have seen the antics-that is all that they were-of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). As an Australian citizen I am ashamed of the behaviour that I have just witnessed. It does no credit to this Parliament and to this House to have someone behave in such a despicable manner. The Opposition brought on this matter of public importance and it set the terms of the debate. Neither the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) nor the honourable member for O'Connor has actually tackled the terms of the debate. It indicates to me that either they do not know their subject-that does not surprise me because they are deficient on all matters of tax-or they are just using the House for their own weird political machinations.

SPEECH.PARA: This Opposition is also very strange because it purports to be a follower of Thatcherism and Reaganism. Members of the Opposition give very similar lines of argument in this House to that used by the British Prime Minister, Mrs Thatcher, and the American President, Mr Reagan. But when it comes to the matter of the capital gains tax they do not tell this House that the American President, under his so-called tax reform Bill, has just increased the capital gains tax in the United States of America. The Americans have a very solid capital gains tax and have had one for many years. In fact, they have no principal exemption on the family home. It is not a gentle capital gains tax such as this country has; it is a very heavy capital gains tax. Only recently the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said that he was very impressed with the so-called tax reforms of the American Government. He was very impressed with the transferring of $120 billion of tax deductions to wage earners and the imposition of an added $120 billion of taxes on business. I hope that the business people of Australia listen very carefully to what the Leader of the Opposition is saying about his proposed tax reforms because if he follows what Mr Reagan and the Americans have done he will not have very many friends in the business community.

What about Great Britain and the great friends of Mrs Thatcher, the privateers of Australia who will sell off Australian assets if they get half the chance? Britain has had a capital gains tax for years. The conservatives of Great Britain and the conservatives of America at least, to their credit, understand about equity, fairness and the need for a capital gains tax. When the Opposition eventually has a policy on anything, particularly on tax, I will be most interested to see what it comes up with.

In the last few days we have heard the shadow Treasurer and the current Leader of the Opposition-I do not know how long he will be in that position-talking about how they were going to abolish the fringe benefits tax and go back to section 26 (e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) rightly pointed out today, they have been bombed down on that one because the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, has clearly said that that is a joke. If that is what they think they are going to do they are tax illiterates. They learn nothing, they know nothing and they live in rhetoric and in history. They have been unloaded on section 26 (e) and on the fringe benefits tax by the Commissioner of Taxation, and they will be unloaded on the capital gains tax. The reality is that none of those people opposite has ever practised in tax. They know nothing whatsoever about it.

The reason for a capital gains tax is very simple. It was very easy for people, with the proper advice, to buy a series of properties-real estate. Of course, under the former Administration these people could negatively gear. They could transfer income, get a tax deduction and borrow highly on the properties that they had bought for long term gain. There was a wonderful system under the former Government. People could negatively gear. They could buy property to make money-the properties were bought to make a profit-hold the properties for a sufficient period, sell the properties, make a profit and pay no tax at all. Members of the Opposition seem to think that that is a very desirable thing to do. They seem to like the system under which some people-not everyone, but some people, those who have a sufficient capital to do it-have the opportunity to use the scheme I have just mentioned, make a profit, pay no tax and, in the process, get a tax deduction for the investment. They think that is a wonderful thing. They think everyone should be able to do it, but very few people can. That is the sort of thing that they will support as much as they support free holidays, free overseas trips and all those sorts of things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you taxing family homes?

—I think we should ignore the honourable member because, like most members of the Opposition, he does not know anything about tax. It is one of the tragedies of the whole debate in this House: We never debate the real subjects. The honourable member for Mackellar did not once go to the terms of the debate. For 10 of his 20 minutes speaking time he harangued the House on the deficiencies of the Government and did not go to the terms of the debate. It is a really great tragedy that in this House a fourth grader such as I can stand up here and do members of the Opposition one-handed, with one arm tied behind my back. We do not even need notes to debate tax matters with honourable members opposite. They are a joke.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality of a capital gains tax is that under our previous system of taxation there was a distinction between capital and income. The former well-known High Court judge, Chief Justice Sir Owen Dixon, once described capital as a tree and the income as the fruit which grew from the tree. Over many years we have distinguished between those two matters in our tax Act, but the reality has always been that profits are made from both capital and income. If a wage earner puts $5,000 in the bank and gets interest on it, he pays income tax on the interest. To the wage earner that $5,000 is a capital investment, but he is paying tax on the fruit which is coming from that $5,000. The person with the greater wealth or the greater capital base, who has the greater options available and who buys real estate in the manner I have described, would pay no tax under the Opposition's proposal and under the tax system it administered. Again, honourable members opposite are working on those who have the capital base, those who have the ability to use the system which exists to make profits and pay no tax, but they are quite happy to tax the man who has the small amount of $5,000 in the bank. I think that is inequitable and wrong, and I do not support their proposals at all.

I will tell those opposite something they probably do not know. Many, many farmers in this country are supporting a capital gains tax. They have spoken to me and to the country task force, and they have said that the capital gains tax is one of the best things that has happened to Australian farming. I will tell honourable members opposite why because they probably do not know. The reality is that Australian farmers have been overcapitalised for years. Because of a tax Act that was administered by the present Opposition it was easy for a city dweller with a large income to pay excessive amounts of money for a farm and use it as a tax deduction against his income, but a genuine farmer was forced to buy on the market overvalued farming properties. The farmers in Australia realise that the capital gains tax will reduce the capital value of their farms. It will bring farming land back to its real value so that the income they produce from it is commensurate with the value of the land. They understand that; they are supporters of this Government. Many Australian farmers, particularly in my electorate, are very pleased that the value of their farms is coming down. It means that the income they will be able to make will be more profitable, they can buy other farms and improve their properties, and they do not have to compete with the higher earners from the cities. The Opposition does not like this. It would like to see farm values skyrocket again and inflate to the stage at which the income produced from a farm is not commensurate with the value of the farm.

There is another interesting section on capital gains tax which anyone who has practised in tax matters knows damned well. Any tax lawyer or accountant of reasonable note can advise any person with a sufficient capital base on how to transfer a taxable income item to a tax-free capital gain. It is so relatively simple that everyone in this country has been doing it for years. It has been a rort. Professor Russell Mathews identified it in the 1970s in his very well-known report on the Australian taxation system and the Asprey Taxation Review Committee report identified that problem. Every academic report on the Australian taxation system in the last 15 years has identified the ease with which people can transpose an income-producing asset to a capital-producing asset and pay no tax on the profits.

One of the things that members of the Opposition did not do today in the debate was distinguish between, nor could they argue about, the difference between a capital profit and income. They could not come into this House and argue cogently in any way, shape or form why a person who makes a profit from capital should not pay tax while a person who produces income should pay tax. I would like them to come into this House one day and explain to us why that distinction should occur in our Income Tax Assessment Act. I cannot see a difference between a profit from an income source and a profit from a capital source. A profit is a profit and should be subject to tax. Members of the Opposition do not support that. They like their friends, those exclusive few, the people at the top end of the market, to have the opportunity to increase their wealth at the expense of the wage earner. Frankly, I do not know why they want that.
