—The honourable member for Denison will resume his seat.
—No, Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. I had not completed my statement. I was prepared--
—Order! The honourable member knows the procedures. He said he withdrew. He then resumes his seat.
—No, I had not finished. You interrupted me before I completed my remarks. I ask to be heard on the point of order.
—The only remarks necessary were that you withdrew. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—Mr Chairman, I have a further point of order. You have no grounds upon which to ask me to withdraw because I have not breached the Standing Orders. I ask to be heard on that point of order because if you are calling on me to withdraw when you have no grounds so to do, you are acting contrary to the Standing Orders.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison indicated that he was withdrawing. You cannot change your mind half way through.
—I am sorry, sir; with great respect, that is not true.
—The honourable member for Isaacs has the call.

—Mr Chairman, I do not want to detain the Committee but I ask you to hear me on a point of order. You have required me to withdraw something that you had no right to require me to withdraw. I had not breached the Standing Orders; I merely pointed out that, on the basis of facts, the Treasurer appears to have breached two sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act. If that offends you, I will withdraw that statement for the purpose of substituting that if any--
—It does not offend me.

—Would you let me finish, sir? I just want to finish this to conclude the matter. If an ordinary citizen did what the Treasurer has done he would have breached section 51a of the Income Tax Assessment Act and also section 82kt. Two sections would have been breached by an ordinary citizen. Why is the Treasurer of this country above the law?
—Order! The honourable member for Denison knows that you cannot make an allegation such as that against a member.
—It is a fact.
—The honourable member knows you cannot make those sorts of allegations. He should withdraw and let the Committee get on with its business.
—On the point of order, Mr Chairman, as I understand it-
—If there are any points of order, I have been trying to make one for some time.
—Does the honourable member for Denison-
—If I may speak further to the point of order and if you will let me-
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman.
—But you called me, Mr Chairman. Am I to be given a chance to be heard or not?
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will resume his seat. I call the Minister.
—You just called me and now you ask me to resume my seat.

—No, he called me. In support of your ruling, Mr Chairman, I point out that the honourable member for Denison began his speech by saying that he believed that the Treasurer should resign. That is a view that he is entitled to put by way of general argument but, when he gets to the stage of saying against any member of this place that that person has breached the law in the way in which it is contended, that is not a matter to be raised within the forms of the Committee in the way in which it has been raised. The honourable member for Denison, knows the forms well enough, as does the Leader of the National Party, to know that, if the submission is being put forward not as a piece of scuttlebutt but as a genuine and serious argument, the proper form to use is a motion of no confidence which calls upon the honourable member concerned to resign. That is the point being made by the Chairman. But simply to come into a debate of this kind and put forward what is nothing more than a set of assertions-well put, but they are nothing more than a set of assertions-and to finish with the conclusion that a member of the House has breached the law is not allowed. If the honourable gentleman is serious about that, the proper forms of the Committee, have not been used and the ruling of the Chairman is completely right. I suggest that, in that case, in order to allow the debate to proceed, the honourable gentleman should withdraw the substance of this allegation against another member and rely on the forms of the Committee which he knows well. He can do that on another occasion because he is not foreclosed and then the issue can be joined if that is the course followed.

—The honourable member for Denison made a point in his remarks. I understood the honourable member to say that he withdrew the allegation. I think it would be best to pursue the matter from there and allow the honourable member for Isaacs to get on with his speech.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for Denison presented a series of authorities and showed a succession of events. If those events were right, there was an inevitable conclusion. I put to you, Mr Chairman, that if one goes through a series of arguments and reaches a conclusion everything has to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the right honourable gentleman getting to his point of order?

—Order! The right honourable gentleman has no point of order. He should resume his seat.

—Mr Chairman, there is a point of order and that is that there is no basis upon which you can call upon a member to withdraw a conclusion if the arguments that lead to the conclusion are supported even by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Denison will resume his seat also. The right honourable member for New England at times takes great delight in addressing the Chair on matters relating to the Standing Orders. As he would know, standing order 76 provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: All imputations of improper motives and all personal reflections on Members shall be considered highly disorderly.

The honourable member will withdraw so that we can proceed with the business before the Committee. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, can I express it without you asking me to resume my seat? In the interests of the Committee, I accept the commendation by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that I had argued my point well. I contend that I have not breached standing order 76 and I conclude by saying that, if it will suit you, I will adopt these words: If anybody else did what the Treasurer has done, he would be in breach of section 51A and section 82K (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I rest my case.
—I take it that the honourable member has withdrawn. I call the honourable member for Isaacs.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. —There is no point of order. I call the honourable member for Isaacs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are back to dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 and the estimates of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance. These important estimates are being considered today but we have witnessed the ratbaggery of some members of the House, including the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who in his speech did not speak about the estimates or anything to do with the estimates for those departments.
—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. I submit with respect that the honourable member cannot speak on continuation. He was on his feet earlier before progress was reported.
—There is no point of order. We are in the Committee stage. The honourable member for Isaacs has time left.

—When considering the estimates before the Committee, we see that the deficit has been brought down to $3.5 billion, which is a substantial reduction when one looks at the deficit that we inherited in 1983. The projected deficit then was $9.6 billion; it is down to $3.5 billion this year. A number of other economic decisions have been taken such as the floating of the dollar, which has made our manufacturing industries more competitive. Other decisions regarding the economy have strengthened the economy and over the next 12 months we will see a number of things come to fruition, including the lowering of interest rates, which has already started. Interest rates on 90-day bills and in a number of other areas have dropped significantly and that will continue across the board into housing loans gradually over the next few months. Also, we will see a drift downwards in inflation from the measures which are before the House at present.

SPEECH.PARA: Those are all decisions taken by this Government for a resurrection of the economy from what was literally a disaster, a depression economy-the economy that we inherited from the totally incompetent management of the conservatives who now sit opposite us and who, after all, spent 31 of the 34 years prior to 1983 with the stewardship of the economy of this country. What did they do? They left the economy in total depression, in a mess and with a projected deficit of nearly $10 billion. The Hawke Government has drastically reduced that. We have seen record growth, record employment and the lowering of unemployment. Interest rates are dropping now and inflation is getting lower. By the time of the next election inflation will be half what it was when we took over government in 1983.

Looking at some of the estimates and the figures before us, it is interesting to note that it is estimated that only 1.8 per cent of total tax receipts this year will come from crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas excise. That compares with 8.9 per cent in 1980-81. That was the easy money that was obtained by the previous Government. That percentage has come down to 1.8 per cent this year. Yet when they had that massive amount of easy money, what did they do with it? They did nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you moved that to the produce excise.

—Here comes the honourable member for Deakin. What did the honourable member's Government do with that easy money? It did nothing. After three decades of conservative government, honourable members opposite left office leaving the top rate of taxation at 60c in the dollar. Yet the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) pontificates in this House when he, after being Treasurer for five years, left the tax system in complete disarray. The top rate of tax was still 60c in the dollar. Honourable members opposite have no idea whatsoever what they want to do with taxation now. If the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) said one thing, Andrew Hay would say totally the opposite.
—Is Andrew Hay in this place?

—He might be after the next election. One never knows. One keeps hearing certain things. But I am sure that whether he is here or not, he has a number of mates sitting with honourable members opposite. The honourable member for Deakin should not worry about that. What has this Government done? It has restructured the tax system so that we will see next year, as the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) and the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) would know, that the lower tax rates will be 24c and 29c in the dollar and the two top rates will be 40c and 49c in the dollar-a long way from the situation after three decades under the stewardship of honourable members opposite during which we saw 60c in the dollar as the top rate while the previous Government ripped off the people.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also interesting to note that during the Fraser Government years, between 1975 and 1981, we saw the percentage of tax paid by persons on lower incomes significantly increased. The tax for a taxpayer with a dependent spouse and two children who was earning in 1981 $10,700, which is approximately $14,000 in today's values, increased by 381 per cent as a proportion of income. The tax for someone in the same situation on an average wage of around $11,000, which would be worth about $15,000 now, increased by 72 per cent as a proportion of income. For someone on average weekly earnings in 1981, tax as a proportion of income increased by 21.6 per cent. The honourable member for Melbourne would want to hear this: Someone earning in excess of $1,000 a week had his tax decreased by 2.9 per cent. People at one end of the scale, earning the equivalent of around $14,000 a year today, had their tax increased by 381 per cent, and on the other end of the scale people earning more than $1,000 a week had their tax decreased by around 3 per cent. That is what honourable members opposite did to the Australian working people when they ripped them off. Yet they had the money. They did not do anything with the money they received from the petrol excise, which was nearly 9 per cent of the previous Government's receipts. That figure has nearly disappeared today; it is now 1.8 per cent. That is the mess that honourable members opposite left us in after three decades.

Honourable members opposite still do not know what they are doing. They have made $5.9 billion worth of promises from things that they will cut. They say that they will balance the books in their first term; that is another $3.5 billion. They will fiddle with the assets test. They will fiddle with Medicare to disadvantage the poor and the chronically ill. All that adds up to around $11 billion. How are they going to do it? Where will they find the money? That amount is practically the entire education and defence budgets put together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get it from the honourable member for Deakin.

—They probably could if he has enough money. Where will the Opposition get the money? The Opposition has not one policy. That is shown by the 30 years of incompetence when honourable members opposite were in government. Honourable members opposite did not have any policies then, either. Look at the mess that they left the country in-the biggest depression since the 1930s and a tax system totally distorted and up the proverbial creek. It was left to this Government to fix things up. This Government has done wonders in regard to the economy and the taxation system in general. Over the next 12 months as things progressively get better and better and as the things I have mentioned regarding interest rates occur and they come down-this will affect and assist everyone-and as the housing industry, which completely stopped under the previous Government, gets going again and as people receive the genuine tax cuts, we will see a country that will thrive as it has begun to thrive over the last four years under this Government. The country will continue to thrive and the people, seeing that, will put us back at the next election because they will not want the nonsense, the lack of management and the incompetence that they copped from honourable members opposite for 30 years.

Proposed expenditure, $818,629,000.

Proposed expenditure, $353,853,000.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), who is trying to interject, for his encouragement. I would like to make a few remarks about the Estimates for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. I would like to refer first to item 6.1, Labour market and economic analysis and to express concern about the future of the Bureau of Labour Market Research. The Department is to establish, I understand, a program assessment branch to strengthen the capacity of the Department to assess the labour market. It is therefore of great concern that the Bureau of Labour Market Research may in fact be closed down by this Government. I believe the BLMR has much to offer the Government and Australians in general in terms of labour market analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bureau of Labour Market Research has had a history of producing papers that, because of their independence and integrity, have often been critical of policies of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) and his Department's analyses of the labour market. Possibly because of its honest analyses and the fact that the Bureau of Labour Market Research is not under union or government control, it now faces the axe. It is my personal view that the Minister should banish from his mind any thoughts of scrapping the Bureau. One should really ask why it is being closed. If one looks back to some of the previous reports and sees the objective and critical analysis that has been brought to bear on some of the issues in the labour market area, one can see why the Minister perhaps does not want to accept them. Be that as it may, I wish that the Minister would reconsider-although probably the day that that could actually happen has now passed. I think it is a tragedy that the people who have put in such a lot of good work for the Bureau of Labour Market Research have now been subsumed into the Department, where their independence will not be as easily accessible to the wider community. There are many people in the wider community who have taken a long interest in the excellent reports produced by this Bureau.

I would like also to refer to item 5.5, Working Environment. That item covers funding to increase the awareness and practice of industrial democracy. This seems to be something of a buzz-phrase within the Australian Labor Party these days, following from its commitment contained in the accord. Grants are now made available to employers, employer groups and trade unions. The research grants scheme is part of this area. Eleven grants totalling $180,000 were made in 1985-86. Industrial democracy grants totalled $757,737 in 1985-86. That is estimated to increase this year by 30.3 per cent to $987,000. It is interesting to note some of the types of organisations receiving funding under this program.

Page 127 of the explanatory document states that there is to be an evaluation of the research scheme later this year. It will be interesting to see whether that review is made public. I ask the Minister to make that public so that one may see the results. One of the recipients of a grant has been the Trade Union Community Research Centre situated in Hobart. During 1985-86 the centre received considerable financial support from the Federal Government including, believe it or not, two $11,000 grants from the Australia Council. Taxpayers' money is being spent on the Centre, so on 30 April this year I wrote to a Mr Dallas, the Director of the Centre, seeking information. I quote from that letter:

. . . I would very much appreciate gaining a greater knowledge of the operations of the centre, and particularly the papers you may have prepared in the area of industrial democracy. It may also be possible to meet with you at some future date, to discuss further the role of the centre.

I would have thought that was a reasonable request written in moderate tones. The response came from a Mr Dain Bolwell, Secretary to the Centre and, I believe, a senior union official in Hobart. On 10 June 1986 I received from him a letter stating:
Under the circumstances this organisation is not prepared to further entertain your request . . .

Apparently a Press statement I issued on 4 May 1986 warning the business community that it should lift its game was considered offensive. I find that hard to believe. I question the motives and open-mindedness of associations who say that unless one is in agreement with them 100 per cent they will not entertain discussions. I certainly question whether taxpayers are receiving value for money if this is the attitude exhibited by such union associations, and in particular by the individual concerned. I think he had the bull by the horns. I question the justification for increasing funding for such centres by a massive 30 per cent. Why the Government believes that it must finance union-sponsored ideological binges is beyond comprehension. Perhaps the Minister has some debts to repay to his friends in the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

What does a member do if he seeks to find out about such funding? He has a right to pursue the matter and the only access left to him is through the Freedom of Information Act. Surely that is not conducive to the good relations we all seem to want to impress on the community as between employers and employees in seeking to deal with some of this country's problems. What steps can the Minister take to facilitate my access to the activities of this Centre in Tasmania to find out what is being done in research with grants that have been paid and approved by this Parliament? I would have thought that to be a reasonable request, and it saddens me to see union officials taking such a stance.

I wish also to refer to item 5.6 concerning the Trade Union Training Authority, which this year will be funded to the tune of $8.5m. It represents an increase of $600,000, or 8.3 per cent, on funding last year. Funding last year exceeded the estimate by $630,000. It will be interesting to see whether the Minister's friends overspend their budget again this year. The Government now finances training of union leaders to an enormous degree. In fact, there are now nearly 16,000 participants in Trade Union Training Authority programs. At a time when the assets of Australia's 20 largest unions total $118m, one questions the necessity for the Government to underwrite the training of such union leaders. The Authority's headquarters are at the Clyde Cameron College in Wodonga. It is estimated that up to $1.5m will be spent this year-$200,000 more than actual expenditure last year. The Clyde Cameron College is supplemented by a number of centres in other States, with centres in Hobart, Adelaide, Perth and so on. One hopes that the understanding by the graduates, or trainees, or however one describes them, of these colleges of the absolute damage done by the 17.5 per cent leave loading permitted by Clyde Cameron as a Minister in the Whitlam Government will not be lost on those attending the courses.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does he regret it?

—It is interesting that the honourable member for Gippsland interposes to ask whether he regrets it. Page 8 of the Melbourne Sun of 26 June 1986 contained a leading article by Ken Merrigan entitled `Loading founder wants massive rort examined' from which I quote the following passage:

SPEECH.PARA: Still there's no mistaking the tone of regret as Mr Cameron describes how his aim of being fair to holidaying employees was distorted to the state of producing a massive rort.

There we have use of the word `rort' that we seem to be hearing a lot about in regard to taxes at the moment. He said that Mr Cameron `never expected the holiday loading to emerge as a universal benefit'. The man who created it felt that he was conned by his union friends and now regrets it. I hope that his words are not lost on the union movement. This is a time when the Government is telling us that it is about time we tightened our belts and tried to get greater productivity into industry. The honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) has been saying consistently that we should be improving manufacturing industry, and I agree with him. One way of going about that process is to get rid of these types of rorts in holiday leave loadings that employers cannot afford to pay-loadings that keep young people, about whom the honourable member for Melbourne professes to be concerned, out of jobs.

For the information of the public, the Trade Union Training Authority is a statutory authority whose functions are to co-ordinate trade union training in Australia and to do anything conducive to the performance of such training. Once again I question the validity of spending $8.5m of taxpayers' money to promote the training of the Minister's friends. What funds are being used by the Minister's Department to assist management training or the industrial training of management? There has been recent criticism that this has all been management's fault. I do not think that is the case. Certainly management is not the beneficiary of $8.5m a year in training assistance, as is the union movement. I conclude my remarks on that note.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer one of the criticisms made by the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith). I place on record my congratulations, as I did last year after the Budget, to the men and women who work in trade union training under the national directorship of Ken Stone, former Trades Hall Secretary in Victoria. The Victorian director is Geoff Fary, a man I have known for many years, and there are many other hard-working men and women who provide excellent training for trade unionists, both at Albury-Wodonga and in the State branches. Anybody who has ever taken the time to visit Albury-Wodonga and the Clyde Cameron College will see there a unique building designed by Australians and built by Australian workers. The people who are turned out of those courses are excellent and are making a contribution to Australia's welfare, particularly in the manufacturing sector. When I was in Warrnambool in the electorate of Wannon I was involved in the running of courses with the Trades and Labour Council in that area. The first Victorian trade union training course in rural Victoria was held following a request I made to the centre in Melbourne.
—Congratulations.

—I thank the honourable member very much. I am always glad to have a bit of praise. It was an excellent course and we were able to make a contribution to a number of issues in western Victoria. Tonight I want to speak on the portfolio of Industry, Technology and Commerce and, if I have sufficient time, to canvass four main aspects of the Budget allocation. First, on a point of clarification it is important to note that overall expenditure in this portfolio is expected to rise by 7.6 per cent to $380m. This figure varies somewhat from estimates given in Budget Paper No. 1, where it is stated that there will be a decrease in expenditure of 21.1 per cent in total assistance to manufacturing industry. The discrepancy arises because the figure of $124.8m given to the oil refineries is a one-off payment to offset losses in February liftings of crude oil at the prevailing parity price artificially inflated in 1985-86 actual expenditure. It is difficult to cover a lot of ground in 10 minutes. One of the highlights of this Government's many successes has been our industry plans. If one looks at those plans one will see that a lot of work has been put into them by government, management and employees. It would be a good thing if Opposition members, particularly the honourable member for Bass, who referred to my concern about manufacturing industry, were to take a bit more time to talk to the people involved in these industries, both at management level and in the work force. As chairman of the Government's caucus industry committee I have had the opportunity to meet people from both these sectors and the spirit of co-operation that has been developed through the industry councils set up by the Government in the various industries has been quite an eye opener to me. It would be much more to the point if Opposition members went out and talked to people on the ground instead of coming in here with biased views about industry and the involvement of trade unionists.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, through our Caucus committee, we have been examining the question of the textile, clothing and footwear industries which have often been mentioned by Opposition members in adjournment speeches. As a former textile worker, I found it very pleasing to visit these plants and hear the glowing terms in which the management talked about the quality of Australian workers. To use their words, those workers are second to none anywhere in the world and their level of productivity is second to none. That is quite pleasing to hear.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is if they are allowed to do the job.

—The honourable member, with his wealth and background, makes a typical comment. Australian workers are better than any others and it is about time Opposition members who profess to talk on behalf of Australia from time to time, got up off their backsides and stopped knocking the country. Every time they open their mouths they shaft us. I believe that Australian workers are sick and tired of the negative approach that Opposition members take. It is about time they started to praise a few people instead of knocking Australian men and women who are, after all, trying to earn a living in this country. The problem with Opposition members is that they have to have someone to bash and unionists are the flavour of the month. Opposition members get behind people such as Copeman from Peko-Wallsend Limited who have been proved to be bloody minded and who are set to drag down industrial relations in this country. When such people went to court they were proved to be wrong and they will be proved wrong again. If people such as the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) want to hide behind the Copemans and the Stones and the H. R. Nicholls Society and if they want to be associated with people such as Sir Phillip Lynch's broken-down research officer who now heads the H. R. Nicholls Society and the Melbourne Chamber of Commerce, then good luck to them. The Australian community will reject them.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention the bounty decision because that decision to cut all bounties by 20 per cent, except in shipbuilding, has caused some problems particularly in the industries to which I have just referred. This measure is expected to save about $43m on estimated bounty payments for 1986-87. Total expenditure on bounties in 1986-87 is estimated at $213m, compared with $209.6m in 1985-86. These payments constitute about 56 per cent of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce budget and about 80 per cent of the industry development allocation. Since 1980-81 bounty payments have increased by 394.4 per cent, reflecting in part a shift away from tariff-related measures towards bounties as a means of providing assistance for particular industries.

I raise this because in my electorate I have in excess of 20,000 jobs in the textile, clothing and footwear industries. I believe that the Government's decision on bounties could well have waited until we had determined our findings on the Industries Assistance Commission report. I think the decision came out of the blue and it has caused some problems for those particular industries. However, I am hopeful that the sorts of discussions that the Government is holding with those industries will overcome the difficulty. Nevertheless I make the point that it would have been better not to make that decision until we had settled on our position on the IAC report. It might have been better if that had been done another way.

We have a responsibility as a government to take note of the comments being made by the textile, clothing and footwear industries. As I said, our Caucus committee has been touring the country. Tonight the Textile Council of Australia is having its annual dinner and I understand that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) is making a speech at that dinner, giving his views on those three industries. I believe that these industries are now capable of moving into exports in a significant way. When one visits these plants, one finds that most of these companies are now gearing themselves to exports. There is great potential for these industries in the export business. In the past they have not even considered exports because they have not been able to do so. I was a textile worker before I came here and I have been amazed at the changes that have taken place in these three industries-changes in management, technology and the trade union movement affecting workers on the floor. I was astounded by the level of competence that I saw and the developments in machinery and equipment in those industries. I believe that these industries are worth saving, and that the jobs of the workers in those industries are worth protecting. I will do everything that I can to ensure that no decision made by the Government brings about job losses. As the Minister said to me recently, the Government will not rush into a decision; it will think things through and make a decision that is sound, in the best interests of those three industries and in the best interests of Australia. I am quite confident that that will be of great benefit--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have spent five minutes saying absolutely nothing.
—Of course the honourable member never worries about anything concerning jobs. He is not worried about jobs or anything to do with workers.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired; he will resume his seat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks tonight are directed towards the community training program, the details of which appear on page 81 of the explanatory notes for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. My remarks will also be within the context of the Budget estimates which detail the payments to be made by the Commonwealth for unemployment benefits. The Budget estimates for 1986-87 are $3.5 billion, which represents a 14 per cent increase over last year. The Budget also proposes certain minor changes to the criteria for the benefit and of course includes some funding for the voluntary community program.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposals do not go nearly far enough. Some people like to criticise the Opposition as simply reacting to events, rather than putting up constructive proposals for consideration. I am sure that the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) will agree that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has led the intellectual debate on industrial relations and has been very much the man to set the agenda. The Government, judging by its rhetoric, is now attempting to take on board some of the views of the Leader of the Opposition. Honourable members should also remember that it was the Leader of the Opposition who established the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System, which set the tone for the debate in this country which led eventually to considerable financial deregulation, which has been good for Australia. On the concept of the work-for-the dole proposals, the Leader of the Opposition has again been way out in front. A lot of people have been talking about this in the community but the Leader of the Opposition started the debate in his address to the National Press Club in August 1985. On this issue, as with the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax-it is a pretty long list-the Government quite frankly does not know what it is doing. In the middle of the year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) mentioned a possible scheme which was to be voluntary. When the Leader of the Opposition, in his reply the following week, said that it ought to be compulsory, the Australian Labor Party backed off on the instructions of its ex-communist Senate candidate for Victoria, Mr Halfpenny.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish!
—It is quite true. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), in an address in Queensland on 3 September 1986, tipped a bucket on the scheme.
—Oh!
—This is what he said. It is on the public record. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The most savage impact of the proposal is that it promotes a grossly unfair dole bludger mentality.

Those were his words. He then went on to say that the cost would be prohibitive and the whole idea was impractical. His figures, quite frankly, were shonky to say the least. He was certainly not prepared to release them. I hope that the Minister might release those documents, as I have asked him to do, under the Freedom of Information Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was all before Kelty and Crean went to Sweden.

—That was before the Australian Council of Trade Unions went off on its free trip to Sweden. The interesting thing is that I rang and talked to a member of the Minister's staff about how he had worked out this cost which he said was prohibitive. The member of staff did reveal something-he let something out of the bag. What he said was that the costings were prepared on the assumption that there was no fraud, cheating or bludging in the current dole system. The Minister has assumed that not one cent will be saved by the introduction of a compulsory system. That is plainly ludicrous. Other Federal Ministers have acknowledged that there are widespread abuses. The anecdotal evidence of cheating is everywhere. Blind Freddie knows that people are cheating on the dole. The Melbourne Herald of 6 October referred to a case where a person was convicted for his part in a $200,000 dole fraud. The convicted person was charged with 62 counts of forging and uttering and used 15 fictitious names. I am even told that there are books available in Europe on how to go to Australia and have an extended holiday on the dole.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has no idea of the extent of cheating in the system and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and people such as the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) think that all dole recipients are simply victims of the nasty capitalist system. One result of a compulsory scheme will be to cut back on fraud and the Government ought to support that objective. I suggest that some other objectives could be to provide a system that helps the genuinely needy-the Government should support that; a system to promote financial independence; provide the community with some benefit in exchange for expenditure of taxes on benefits for the unemployed; provide a deterrent or disincentive to those who are otherwise capable of work and who are not genuine; discourage the situation where the dole payment encourages dependency on the State; and provide work experience and introduce work disciplines such as punctuality so as to improve the prospects of the participants to return to the work force on a permanent basis. I would have thought that on a bipartisan basis most of those objectives ought to be agreed between both sides of the House. The public's attitude to these proposals generally is very favourable because they see them as a means to help the unemployed.

One municipality in my electorate has responded very positively to the concept. The Phillip Island Council has decided to proceed with a scheme. I compliment the Shire President, Councillor John Bailey, Councillor Greg Price and their fellow councillors, Shire Secretary Barry Hayes and Shire Engineer Jock McKechnie on their initiative to help Phillip Island residents overcome the problems of unemployment. I particularly compliment the people receiving the unemployment benefit who have been prepared to come forward and participate. They have taken a positive attitude, which is something I cannot say about honourable gentlemen opposite. The Shire has advertised the scheme using its own funds and it has received some preliminary responses. Next week it will be the first shire in Australia to commence a scheme. Instead of knocking it, those opposite ought to give the Shire some encouragement because its primary motive is to help those who are unemployed. The scheme will start next week. A professionally qualified person has come forward and volunteered to supervise the work and the first project is to beautify the grounds of the information centre. I honestly cannot see how honourable members opposite can somehow find a basis for criticism of the initiative taken by this municipality. The scheme will be for two days a week. The Shire is seeking some financial assistance from the Government and I hope that the Minister will favourably consider its request. Whether one likes it or not, I believe it is a subject which is very much on the political agenda. If we have a municipality which is prepared to take the initiative with a pilot project in a semi-rural area, it ought to be encouraged so that we can see how it gets along.

The Government has adopted a very negative attitude to the proposal. A more positive attitude would offer some hope of assistance from the Government for the unemployed. The Government's Budget this year predicts increasing levels of unemployment. Surely it is a matter of bipartisan agreement between us that constructive efforts to help those people who will find themselves unemployed or who are currently unemployed ought to be adopted by both sides of this House. An imaginative scheme, heavily reliant on volunteers, could be of great help to many unemployed persons and should be embraced by the Government.

The fact is that the Government is being left behind. The Opposition has outlined its scheme. We are working on the details, but we have been quite forthright as to the direction in which we should be going. Just last Sunday we saw in the National Times on Sunday a headline which said `ACTU wants to end youth dole'. The article went on to say:
The ACTU has endorsed a radical youth policy based on the premise that young people should not receive the dole unless they are engaged in work, training or education.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The point of order is that the honourable member is misleading the House. The ACTU has not advocated a work for the dole scheme for young people. That is my point of order, so I am demanding that he tells the truth.
—Order! The honourable member's point of order may be well taken. I was not aware of the remarks of the honourable member for Flinders.
—Tell the truth if you're going to come in here.
—I was simply quoting from a national newspaper which is quite readily available to everybody.

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I am not aware of the remarks that the honourable member may have made that were the subject of the point of order. I ask him to stick strictly to the subject before the Committee.
—The sensitivity of the honourable member for Melbourne is that I have read from a newspaper which thousands of Australians read on Sunday. The point I simply make, before he uses up my time--
—I raise a point of order.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.
—I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Melbourne accused my colleague the honourable member for Flinders of not telling the truth. I ask that it be withdrawn.
—If the honourable member for Melbourne made that accusation, I ask him to withdraw.
—If I can just have a moment to get some clarification.
—Withdraw.
—Just a minute. I just want some clarification.
—Did the honourable member for Melbourne--
—If I can just ask a question of you, Mr Deputy Chairman, in responding to the point of order.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman.
—I am hearing the honourable member for Melbourne.
—I rise on a point of order. You have asked the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw. That does not give him an opportunity to debate the issue. Are you going to enforce your ruling or not?
—The honourable member for Barker will resume his seat. I have asked the honourable member for Melbourne, if he made that remark, to withdraw it.
—What I said is that the honourable member was not saying what was true. The ACTU is not advocating that and therefore--
—He is debating the question.

—Just a moment and I will answer your question over there. For God's sake be quiet. What I am saying is that, therefore, what he was saying was in fact not true, and that is a fact. What you were saying was not true. If you want me to withdraw something that happens to be true because it offends you, I do not think I can do that, because what you are saying isn't true.
—The honourable member for Melbourne has indicated to the Chair that in his opinion he does not believe that the remarks made by the honourable member for Flinders were correct. I take it as fact.
—Mr Deputy Chairman--
—I have ruled on the point of order.

—I take another point of order. My point of order is that the honourable member for Melbourne has himself told an untruth in claiming that he did not accuse my colleague of not telling the truth. I heard the matter clearly and it will be recorded in Hansard. You have asked the honourable member to withdraw if he said that and he has refused to withdraw. Are you going to enforce your ruling or not?
—The honourable member for Curtin is taking the same point of order that I have just ruled on.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, on a point of order: You might find it useful if I clarify the statement that I made. The statement that I made was quite simple. I have in my hand a photostat copy of a newspaper article. I simply made the assertion, which is provable by the piece of paper in my hand, that certain things were said in a national newspaper. It is not--

—The honourable member has made his point. I have not required the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw. There is a difference of opinion between the two honourable members. The Chair will not be involved in holding up the proceedings of this Committee to determine which opinion is correct and which is not.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I raise a point of order. The honourable member for Melbourne said: `You should tell the truth when you come in here'. When you came to the chair you said that you had not heard what the honourable member for Melbourne had said. In those circumstances, with the requirement being that proper parliamentary conduct be carried out, and you having asked the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw any comment in view of the fact that he had said `You should tell the truth when you come in here', I ask again that you require the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw his remark.
—The point of order that has been taken by the honourable member for Deakin simply goes over the ground that has already been covered.
—With great respect, Mr Deputy Chairman--

—Order! The honourable member for Deakin will resume his seat. He is going over the ground that has already been covered. I allowed the honourable member for Melbourne to explain the situation. He did not repeat, as had been suggested, the particular words that he was alleged to have said. It is not my intention to allow the matter to proceed any further.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, I take a further point of order. I accept what you say about the fact that you were not in the chair or that you were taking the chair when the honourable member for Melbourne made those remarks. In those circumstances would you then require the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw the words `You should tell the truth when you come in here', if he made those remarks?

—The honourable member for Deakin will resume his seat. If the honourable member for Melbourne uttered words that were offensive to the honourable member for Flinders I ask him to withdraw those offensive words.
—Just a moment. Mr Deputy Chairman. I have some difficulty-
—Order! I have requested the honourable member for Melbourne-
—Mr Deputy Chairman, you are asking me to withdraw something-

—Order! If the honourable member for Melbourne has made an offensive remark concerning the honourable member for Flinders, I ask him to withdraw the remark that is considered by the honourable member for Flinders to be offensive.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, on a point of order: If what you say is what I said-I questioned something that the honourable member said which was untrue-and I am bound by the rules of this chamber to withdraw something like that, God help us. I withdraw.
—Let me explain the situation quite clearly to the honourable member for Melbourne. He is not helping the Chair in this circumstance. I have suggested to the honourable member for Melbourne-

—Mr Deputy Chairman, with deference to you, I withdraw if it offends. I have questioned what the honourable member said. I have to point out to him that he is making a terrible mistake by saying that. If it is offensive to him, I will withdraw.
—Order! The honourable member will not debate the issue.
—I withdraw it for the third time.
—The honourable member for Melbourne has withdrawn.

—Mr Deputy Chairman, on a point of order, I just want to thank you on behalf of the Committee for requiring the honourable member for Melbourne to withdraw those offensive remarks when you were in the difficult situation of changing the occupancy of the chair.
—I do not consider that to be a point of order. I think the honourable member for Deakin knows that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I doubt whether the Committee will thank the Opposition for its behaviour during the last five minutes. All too often after dinner the wanderers and the strayers find their way into the chamber and spend the rest of the evening provoking honourable members, disputing facts and disturbing the proceedings. I find that a bit distasteful and I am sure that it does the Opposition no credit. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) indicated the difficulty that we as a government have when we come to grappling with the intellectual logic of the Opposition. In fact, having started his speech by talking about working for the dole which his Leader purports to espouse, he ended up supporting a voluntary youth employment program which the Government has had running for some years, and which it is extending.

SPEECH.PARA: I found it very difficult to work out just what the honourable member was on about. Of course, the scheme that he put forward is identical to the scheme that is currently running in many parts of Australia, including my electorate. It is running very successfully and has done for some years. In fact, it was initiated originally by the previous Government and it is one which we have extended, supported, and are extending further. If that is what the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) calls working for the dole there is no argument at all-we all agree with that. If that is what the honourable member means, let there be no argument and let us get rid of that nonsense. If the scheme is the voluntary youth program I am sure that there is no dispute on this side of the House.

Tonight I came into the chamber to speak to the appropriations for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. In doing so, I want to focus on what I believe to be the major problem facing the country-that is, the tendency of Australians to buy more from overseas than they can afford. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) once referred to Australians as import junkies, meaning that we had an unhealthy addiction to imported goods to the extent that our whole economy had become vulnerable. One can argue about this or blame individual segments of the community or anybody else, but the fact is that eventually we as a nation must face up to the fact that we all have a responsibility for the problems.

In looking at the massive imbalance in our export trade between manufactured goods and primary industry and raw materials it becomes obvious that this imbalance has always left us vulnerable to shifts in world demand and prices. In recent years a downward trend in world commodity prices has been occurring but the dramatic change in the last 18 months was not predictable, nor can it be absorbed by the economy without significant impact. The reduction in the past year, equivalent to about $1,000 per taxpayer or $20 per week, has to flow through the economy. The task facing the Government in framing this Budget was to ensure that this flow on was equitable. Despite efforts to ensure that, there is no doubt that pockets of the community will bear a disproportionate share of the responsibility. I urge all Ministers to treat such occurrences, as and when they occur, with sensitivity and compassion.

This Budget has been framed in circumstances in which we as a nation are required to import an additional $14 billion of capital from overseas merely to balance our current account. Since we will spend $14 billion more than we earn as a nation we cannot pretend that, at the same time as we import the $14 billion, we can dictate the terms of that capital inflow. The obvious question that arises is: Who is this Budget aimed at? Is it designed for the world finance markets or the Australian community? The answer is simple-it is designed for both. The Government seeks to secure for Australia a high level of economic independence. To achieve this in the short term we need to attract the $14 billion that we as a country have overspent. More importantly, we have to address the core problem, which is the excessive importation of consumer goods and the lack of export of products of Australian manufacture. In doing that, we should ask ourselves: Why is it that we have a problem? Why is it that Australians do not readily buy Australian goods? For months now we have watched Australian goods reduce relatively in price and yet still not sell. Many Australian products are either equivalently priced to, or cheaper than, imported products, yet we are still buying imports. For some reason, a significant number of Australians do not want to buy Australian goods. While ever this is the case, our economy will be vulnerable and dependent upon capital inflow.

To achieve economic independence we need to pay our way in the world by buying less and selling more. While we have a massive trade deficit we will be a hostage to world financial forces. Australian businessmen can blame the Government and they can even blame the consumers, but eventually they have to face up to the fact that in so many cases what they are producing is either unattractive or irrelevant to significant sections of the Australian public. The Government can encourage the public to buy Australian, and this is a worthwhile effort, but we cannot pass laws to force people to buy Australian made goods. My advice to those businessmen who complain so much and who want to blame the Government for the lack of appeal of their products is to spend a lot more time talking to the public about what it wants and then set about producing those products. If the devaluation, which represents a doubling or even tripling of the effective rate of tariff, does not help them it is obvious that nothing ever will.

I recently spent some time looking at various industries in Europe. I went to factories in Sweden, Germany, Belgium, Holland and England. I came back committed to trying to rectify what I perceived to be the major deficiency in our manufacturing sector, namely, the lack of attention to, and concentration on, quality. In Europe I observed workers using similar equipment and displaying similar skills to their Australian counterparts. I saw little evidence of significant difference in skill or application. I did see a massive concentration on quality throughout all the European organisations. In Europe `quality' is not a trendy word but a fundamental aspect of manufacturing. It does not consist alone of the checking of final product but is paramount at all stages of product development from design through to final assembly.

My concern with the quality of Australian manufacturing was heightened by this inspection. Since returning I have made a submission to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) proposing a method of accelerating quality consciousness in Australian manufacturing. This suggests the development of a joint government-industry mechanism to develop and monitor quality standards and with the capacity to verify the quality of individual companies' products. Companies that are able to meet appropriately high standards would be able to use a badge on their products to indicate this. The Government would provide industry assistance to companies wishing to upgrade the quality of their manufacturing and would also promote public awareness of the badge and its verification procedures. Companies in turn would extend their guarantee period; in other words, they would put faith in their own products. Such a program could be introduced industry by industry. It would obviously require State and trade union involvement. It would also indicate to public servants that a justification for not buying Australian goods would not exist.

Perhaps nothing better demonstrates the betrayal of the Australian business community by those who sit opposite than the appalling conclusion of all their years in office since 1949-a public service and a community not committed to buying products from Australian industry. The disaster that this Government has had to face in virtually every area of industry policy is a stark reminder of the sheer incompetence of Liberal-National Party coalition governments for most of the last 37 years. These supposed supporters of free enterprise sold out their supporters year by year. This Government has gone a long way towards creating a climate of industry policy that is conducive to improving Australian industry competitiveness, particularly in the export field. The introduction of export bounties on computer assemblies and shipbuilding was a significant first step in integrating our domestic and export markets. The recent announcement of a bounty on export ship repair work is a logical extension of these initiatives. Other initiatives of the Government which are visible include the tax write-off for research and development, the management investment companies, and the extension of the Australian Industry Development Corporation's financial capacity and growing industry involvement.

The initiatives are in place; the policy framework that was for so long deficient is now appropriate; and the currency that was for so long overvalued is now at a suitable level. We have put our money where our mouth is. As a government we have made a significant national investment in the development of industry. Business and industry leaders and management now face the challenge. There has never been a better opportunity to invest in Australian manufacturing, but it must be better directed and better managed than previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shipton Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The outstanding feature of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce estimates in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 is the way they fail to recognise the importance of the small firm and the small business sector in the Australian economy. I believe they are negligent in so doing. The estimates do not mention in any substantial way the importance of the small firm, the small enterprise or the family business in the Australian economy and the importance of the small business sector to growth and the availability of jobs in the future. There is no mention of the proper place of the small or medium size firm in economic recovery which is so important in Australia today. In the estimates not even lip service or tokenism is given. I am willing to stand corrected, but the only reference I can find in the estimates to small business is a throw-away mention on page 17 of the explanatory notes in relation to the industry policy and development program. On page 34 there is a throw-away line in relation to the industry policy and development program, but in none of the other major sections of the estimates-industry policy and development and industry development-is there recognition of the role of the small firm. In relation to industry infrastructure there is no mention to the importance of small business, and in relation to industry research, which comes under industry policy and development on page 77, again there is no recognition of the role of the small firm and the small enterprise in the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not arguing that the estimates should have special subsidy programs or that small business should have any special treatment. All the small business sector needs today is breathing space and a fair go. It does not want to be subsidised; it does not want government hand- outs, but it does want a climate so that it can invest, grow, work and create jobs. Small business is the major employer. Small business is big business and has the potential to be even bigger business in the Australian economy. I think it is outrageous and negligent of the Government not even to mention the importance of that sector, with its employment capacity and employment potential. Nowhere in this estimates document, which is a far-reaching policy document that discusses industry development, technology and business efficiency, industry infrastructure, industry research, corporate strategy and services, is there any recognition or acknowledgment of the importance and the role of the small firm.

The Government should be asking itself: What is good for small business? The answer is that what is good for small business is good for Australia. If one asks what is good for Australia, what is good for small business and what policies have to be put in place to encourage the growth of small business, one gets the right policies for Australia. The industry policies of this Government are a failure. Obviously, industry has no voice in the Cabinet. Small business and large business alike are neglected because the Government has failed to create the proper climate for investment in the Australian economy.

The role of government should be to create the proper climate, environment or framework through economic and industry policies for investment, growth, profit and jobs. That has not happened. In fact, the reverse has happened. The climate being created by the Government through its industry and economic policies is a climate that discourages investment, discourages jobs and is a positive disincentive to investment and growth in the Australian economy. The Government's industry policies have created uncertainty and instability and there is an outflow of investment from Australia overseas. Daily we see another Australian businessman or entrepreneur investing outside the country. They are doing that because the industry policies of this Government are encouraging Australian entrepreneurs and firms to invest outside Australia and not inside the country. The Government's policies are creating uncertainty and instability. Who would invest in Australia today when one can go and buy a bank bill, the interest on which varies from time to time, from week to week-it ranged from 17 per cent to 20 per cent in the last two months? What businessman will invest in productivity capacity when he could let his money sit on deposit and get a return of that nature? It is accepted that business will not invest until there is a climate of certainty for investment. We need stability. What we have is instability and uncertainty because of the failure of the Government's industry policies and particularly the failure of the Government to recognise the role and importance of the small firm and the small business in the Australian economy.

I would like to focus on the question of technology transfer, which is also a subject of the portfolio we are discussing. Obviously, technology transfer to Australian enterprise and business is vital. I support offset programs. I think that the large corporate sector has an advantage because of its capacity to deal with companies overseas and the small firm suffers a particular disadvantage. We have to concentrate on high technology industries in the areas where we have skills. We have areas of great skill across the board in Australia. We have them in medicine, in engineering and in bio-technology and plant technology. Australians have made great inventions over the years. The photocopier was invented in Australia. Our problem in the past has been that we have not developed those inventions.

I think there has been too much emphasis on high technology. High technology has its place. We must encourage technology transfer at both the small and the large firm level. We must concentrate on low technology and what I might call mid-technology. I do not mean old fashioned low technology; I mean modern low technology that can be carried on particularly by small firms and small enterprises. I would have thought it would be much better to encourage people in the nation to create their own firm and their own enterprise rather than to encourage the large business sector. The reality is that the large business sector is rationalising. Because of the unfavourable climate that I mentioned previously, it is not investing in Australia; it is disinvesting in Australia and investing overseas. We have to encourage small people, individuals, to create their own enterprises.

High technology generally requires a massive investment which is beyond the reach of individuals or small groups of individuals. I believe that Australia has the potential in the manufacturing sector to have thousands of new generation mid- or low technology factories that are innovative and productive. We could have thousands of secondary small businesses if only we had the policies, the climate and the environment for them to grow and prosper. To do that we do not need increases in company taxation such as we have; we do not need fringe benefits taxation such as we have and we do not need a capital gains tax. In fact, we need the reverse of those taxes. We need lower business taxation to encourage the investment I talked about, to encourage thousands of individuals throughout the nation to invest in their own small enterprise or their own small firm. Not only are the estimates deficient; the Government's policies are totally deficient because they fail to recognise the role and the importance of the individual small firm in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe in Australian manufacturing and I believe in Australian manufactured products because I am one myself, made and assembled in Australia and delivered on time on 16 November 1938. I am very proud once again to say that every item of clothing I am wearing in this House tonight has been made in Australia.
—Order! I point out to the honourable member for Denison that it might be disorderly to prove that.

—I will not prove it in that sense, but I will just expose the facts. I am wearing an Anthony Squires suit made in Australia; I am wearing a Van Heusen shirt made in Australia; I am wearing an Austico tie; I am wearing John Brown socks; I am wearing Flor- sheim shoes; and, if honourable members want to know, I am wearing Jockey underwear made in Australia.
—Where was the flower grown?

—It was grown here in the national capital. I am particularly proud that the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) is in the chamber tonight, as are my very good and long-standing friend the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) and my very good friend the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay).
—What about your friends over here?

—They are here, together with the packed benches of my Liberal and National Party colleagues. I remember with some very great affection speaking in this House on the Australian steel industry plan, brought in by the Hawke socialist Government and in particular by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), supported by the Minister for Science. I applaud that plan. I believe it is a good plan and it is working. On that occasion, for whatever reason, I was applauded in the chamber by a number of members who occupied that part of the chamber which I refer to as Moscow corner. However, it is possible for persons of good will on both sides of the House to reach agreement on issues and to find, as I think I do find, that there is a feeling in Australia-I am particularly grateful for the presence of my friend the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) because we have jousted on this issue-that perhaps we have been moving too fast to dismantle a system of protection which I believe is essential if Australian manufacturing is to survive.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe Australia is like a 17-year-old youth-strong, virile and having all the potential in the world, but requiring protection, particularly against those with whom he has to compete who are older, more cunning and more powerful. I feel there has been too much of a rush towards a unilateral withdrawal of protection of Australian manufacturing. It is fashionable today to say that everybody agrees that protection must be reduced. People assume that point; the only argument concerns the speed at which it is done. To draw crude analogy, to me it is like the difference between being raped quickly and raped slowly.

As I speak there are in this chamber the ghosts of 250,000 Australians who were employed in the manufacturing sector just a few short years ago but who are no longer so employed. In the late 1960s, 25 per cent of the Australian work force was employed in the Australian manufacturing sector. What is the position in 1986? The figure is 14 per cent. Five years ago 1.25 million Australians were employed in the manufacturing sector; today the figure is one million. So 250,000 Australian ghosts float in this chamber as we talk tonight. We have before us a critical report of the Industries Assistance Commission with respect to textiles, clothing and footwear. If the preferred option of the IAC is implemented by this Government, on the IAC's own figures a further 20,000 Australian jobs will be lost. The industry says that we can treble that figure-it is closer to 60,000.

I have been chastised for talking in terms of wet and dry, but I worked under one of the greatest Australians this country has ever seen-the late Sir Phillip Lynch. Rightly or wrongly I still espouse the basic philosophies that he implemented during his term as Minister for Industry and Commerce. I have to say with great passion, because I feel about this passionately, that the dry mania pervading Australian political and economic discussion in this country has gone too far and the thought that Australia should lead the world, when just 20 years ago we were in the top six nations and now find ourselves at position number 32, is nothing more nor less than economic madness, suicide and the genocide of our manufacturing sector. I say: Halt, enough, we have gone too damned far down this track. I feel this strongly.

I never could understand why, when we were in Government and when Australian steel was being exported and 49 per cent of the steel being used in Australia was imported back from Korea and Japan, we were paying Korea a developing country preference. It just did not make sense to me. My colleague the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), who is in the chamber, took over as Minister for Industry and Commerce and with great distinction served in that portfolio in the last months of the Fraser Government. He decided to tackle something which, frankly, I do not think has been properly tackled since-certainly not with the same effect. He directed me to have brought into my office every anti-dumping file in the Department of Industry and Commerce, and he directed that a decision was to be made as to whether anti-dumping notices were to be issued. The record shows that under his direction I, as the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce, issued some 89 anti-dumping notices in January of 1983, two days before Australia Day. One would have thought that it was the end of the world. The Japanese Ambassador called on the Prime Minister and the Korean Ambassador called. A great friend of mine, the late Ken Caldicott, who was the No. 1 boss of Hitachi Australia Limited, told me at Wrest Point at the time of the Sydney-Hobart yacht race that we would be dragged through every court in the land. The plain fact was that every one of those anti-dumping notices stuck and every one was complied with. I give full marks to the honourable member for Kooyong for having had the guts to do it.

In my concluding minute I say to the Government: Before you decide that Australian manufacturing industry is so strong that you can tear away its protection and leave it standing naked against a ruthless and cruel competing world, just think a little about the jobs of Australians that depend on the decisions of this Parliament. I find wisdom in some of the remarks of the honourable member for Charlton and-I will surprise the Committee-I find wisdom in some of the remarks of the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). There are people on both sides of the chamber who approach this problem in the right way; that is, we should not stand by and cut the throat of the Australian manufacturing sector so that we get ten out of ten for economic purity but put another 100,000 Australians out of work. I appeal for a rational and proper approach and for genuine and rational protection of real Australian manufacturing and the thousands and thousands of Australians who depend on it for their jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to follow my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). Many of the points he made at the start of his contribution, including his concern for the future of Australian manufacturing industry, are valid and worth having regard to. But towards the end of his contribution he moved once again into the humbug and what has been regarded elsewhere as the carpetbaggery espoused by those on the other side of the chamber. These are not my words; I am just quoting from the editorial of the National Times on Sunday, 7 September. The editorial, headed `This is the wall the Right built', referred to protection, including the carpetbaggery that has been built up over the years under the guise of protection. The editorial states:

SPEECH.PARA: This is particularly so of the Liberal Party. True, there has long been a free-market faction in the Liberal Party: for many years, its name was Bert Kelly.
He is known as the Modest Farmer. The editorial further states:
His party colleagues regarded him with amusement; his political career went nowhere.
And the stifling of trade-
I repeat: `The stifling of trade'-

which Liberal-Country Party governments fought for, achieved and defended was not an isolated thing: its effects spread throughout the economy, fattening profits, adding to wage increases and helping to foster the very work practices that today's Liberals so angrily denounce.
That is an interesting analysis. The editorial concludes:
It is fairly pointless identifying humbug in politics, since without humbug few politicians would be left with much to say.
I suggest that the honourable member for Denison could gather much from that. However, it ought to be remembered, as the editorial states:

But as they arrive at the free market battlefield and unpack all those glittering `New Right' gee-gaws from their carpetbags, you might have hoped that even politicians could make some concession to history and acknowledge their part in creating the evil they now so rail against.

This Government has many initiatives which will continue under the Budget provisions contained in the Appropriation Bill we are debating tonight. Something which we do not speak about much in this chamber but which ought to be drawn to the attention of honourable members, and be commended, within the employment and industrial relations sector is the initiative of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) in the field of industrial democracy and employee participation. We have a situation in which our manufacturing sector, and in fact most parts of the business sector, have developed on the structure of saying: `We own it; you work for us and you do what you are told'. We are one of the few nations in the world that have yet to learn the message that, if we go to those who do the job, we may find out that they know a hell of a lot more about doing it than do those who profess to know. As we move down the path of more and more industrial democracy and more and more employee participation, we will find the answers for increased productivity; increased quality control; and increased industrial co-operation and consensus in the market-place.

I remember that before I came to this place I attended a seminar one day. The fellow who was delivering the speech to us made the point that Australian workers are amongst the most innovative and capable people in the world. He made the point that between 5 o'clock on Friday night and 9 o'clock on Monday morning they are capable of running local committees, running local sporting clubs, renovating houses, rebuilding cars and doing all sorts of magical things in the community and in the local area. The skills and the talents are there. So one turns around and asks oneself what happens in the work place. I point to the management of the work place. Nobody goes to work to do a poor day's work. Everybody goes to work to try to do the best he can. If we cannot manage the work environment in order to create the opportunity for people to do their best, we should not point to the unions or to the Government; we should not wave our fingers looking for someone to blame. We should point to ourselves and ask: `Why are we not managing it properly?' That is the real issue.

I welcome the points made by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). He mentioned that every single piece of apparel that he is wearing is made in Australia. I congratulate him and I join him, as do my colleagues on this side of the House. We did not ask him prove it. But this leads me to the issue of the `Buy Australia' campaign. I cannot help taking this opportunity to boast about a great initiative by one of my local regional newspapers. It has a supplement this week which urges people to buy Australian products. Throughout the advertisement is the new Skippy logo, as I call it-the easily identifiable Australian kangaroo which identifies Australian made products-in the colours of the true blue. That is really great and I commend that newspaper for taking the initiative in picking up the marketing thrust.

I also make the point that people are picking up on this Australian made thrust. Today at one of our meetings we heard evidence from a major group of retailers to the effect that in just the few weeks that this campaign has been running, there has been a 15 per cent shift in consumer preference for Australian made products. Every member of this House--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—A major retailing group. Every member of this House should be out in the community pointing out that message-not preaching doom and gloom pointing out that Australians are prepared to buy Australian made products if they are offered then and if they are given the initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: I came across the example of a product which is dressed up to look like an import but which is really made in Australia. It is a cheese product which purports to be a French import, but written on the packet is: `Product of Australia'. I congratulate the manufacturer. The point I make is: How did this come to be bought? The person who brought this sample to me said: `Look, this is crazy. I went into the shop looking for Australian cheese. I picked up products, I looked at them all and I saw this one made in Australia'. Why on earth a manufacturer would pretend that it was a French product was beyond this person because he was looking for an Australian made cheese. That sort of message has to get through. Dressing up a product as some sort of fancy import is not the way to go in the market-place any more.

I also want to make one final point about the budget for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations deserves a very big commendation for his efforts with the community employment program and his efforts in job generation. The 670,000 new jobs in Australia cannot be acknowledged as anything but a major achievement. The creation of the 400,000-I repeat, 400,000-new jobs for new participants in the work place, many of them females and many of them women re-entering the work force, is to be commended.
