It is a measure of the true commitment of this Government to getting people back into the work place, getting a fair taxation system, getting a fair go for employees in the work place and, most of all, doing something genuine to get Australian manufacturing industry back on to its feet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not come as any surprise to the Committee that I always put the interests of my nation before anything else. One of the objectives that I have for building up this nation-I share this view with the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman)-is that we must do what we can to build up our manufacturing industry. Parts of our manufacturing industry have enormous potential. That is one of many areas of agreement that I share with the honourable member for Denison. In talking of building up Australian industry, I want to say something about Australia's automotive industry. As a South Australian, it is obviously of direct importance to me, but also it is an industry with tremendous potential in this nation, if it is given opportunities. At the moment, even though the industry is extremely visible on the roads, it represents only 6.6 per cent of employment in manufacturing industry and only 7 per cent of the turnover of the manufacturing sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the appropriations for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, it is interesting to see that some $29m is being devoted to the automotive industry. That figure is very much underestimated because it does not take into consideration things from which the industry would benefit, such as the 150 per cent research and development tax concession. Nevertheless, if one looks at it within the totality of the Budget, the automotive industry receives a fairly small amount-indeed an almost negligible proportion-of Budget funds. I am not arguing that it should receive more; I am just observing that the industry is not one of the major beneficiaries of budgetary expenditure, although it is assisted by a number of other Government policies such as protection.

Turning to budgetary expenditure, about $3.5m is spent on the bounty for commercial motor vehicles and $25.9m is to be spent on the Automotive Industry Authority, representing an increase of over 21 per cent on that Authority. If people are objective about this, it is probably true to say that over the last decade or so there has been a changing mood in the automotive industry in spite of the vicissitudes that it has inevitably gone through as the economy has gone up and down. There has been a steadily growing confidence as new products have been developed and they have been found in some ways to be a little more competitive than some of their predecessors. For example, one can see the way that General Motors-Holden's Ltd has built its engine plants and now has substantial capacity to export to countries such as Germany and Britain. Mitsubishi Australia Ltd, as it has now become, having taken over from Chrysler at Tonsley Park in Adelaide, has turned a very inefficient Chrysler plant into an extremely efficient Mitsubishi plant. I congratulate the South Australian Tonkin Government on all of the help it provided in making that transition smooth and successful.

The industry very clearly recognises the objective of a lean, efficient and dynamic industry. It also recognises that that can be achieved by four basic means. I want to say something about each of those means of achieving that objective.

First of all, it is recognised in the industry-and, I would have to say, recognised in the Government's car plan, as it is recognised also by the Opposition-that some degree of rationalisation in the car industry has been and still is absolutely necessary. It is fairly absurd in a country of Australia's size that we have five manufacturers manufacturing a vast array of models. We have 14 heavy commercial vehicle assemblers in this country, and anybody who has been to the city of Adelaide knows that component manufacturers are very thick on the ground. There are component manufacturers galore in Adelaide.

One of the principles of the car plan has clearly been to rationalise the Australian automotive industry in order to try to make it more efficient. I want to pick up one point about rationalisation, though, because it has been brought to my attention very recently that part of the Government's rationalisation plan apparently is to impose some penalties on manufacturers who are producing low volume models. The definition of low volume is perhaps 20,000 or 30,000 units a year, but we are not quite sure of that. The car plan did stipulate-and quite rightly so-that there would be certainty and predictability for the industry until at least 1992, when the plan comes up for review. But this new rumour which is circulating-and it has been confirmed by Senator Button-about penalties for low volume manufacturers creates new uncertainty in the industry, and that uncertainty has very strongly been brought to my attention. I would like to say more about that but time does not permit. But I would certainly appreciate some response from the Minister on that particular issue.

The second means of achieving the greater objectives of an efficient industry is that Australia must get into export markets. The industry has a total turnover of $6.2 billion; yet only 6 per cent of that turnover comes from exports. The Government has its export facilitation scheme, which I support. I think that is a reasonable way to try to assist and encourage the industry not only to import components but to export as well. These incentives through the export facilitation scheme have been successful, as I have already mentioned, in the case of General Motors-Holden's, with its export of car engines. GMH will also build a new plant, I understand, very soon. Mitsubishi has also, I understand, made some attempt to get into the export market and has been moderately successful in doing so. I do not think, therefore, that the Government's policy, insofar as its car plan is concerned, is misdirected in terms of what it is doing for exports in the industry. It is misdirected in a lot of other ways, but not in terms of the car plan.

The third means of achieving the objective of a strong industry is to improve quality in the industry. I think we have gone a long way towards improving quality in the car industry, but there is still a long way to go. The responsibility for improved quality does not rest just on the major manufacturers; it also rests with that myriad of component manufacturers, because one of the common complaints we get from manufacturers is that the quality of components is too low and that that directly affects their products. I would like to feel that that is an issue which the automotive authority-I have forgotten precisely what it is called-will look at over the next year, because I think that quality control, whilst difficult to quantify, is a vastly important issue for that industry. One of the reasons the industry in Sweden-to take a country of a similar size to Australia-has been so successful is that it has concentrated on very high quality products. In contrast, we have not.

Of course, the fourth means of achieving our objective is to make the industry much more competitive internationally. One of the ways we must do that is clearly to improve the quality of management. I think that has been a problem in manufacturing industry generally in Australia and there are cultural reasons for it. We see the same problem in the United Kingdom, which has the same sort of cultural pressures. I would like to feel that some effort within tertiary institutions-not necessarily effort by the Government, but effort within the institutions-could be made to improve that cultural climate. I notice that the Government is spending some $30,000 on management training schemes in the automotive industry under the car plan. I notice that one of those programs has apparently been described as inventory control. I do not have time to talk about that. I think accelerating inventory turnovers is not a very fashionable thing to talk about, but is an extremely important aspect of industry policy. Rather than spreading that $30,000 all around the place, I would have thought that inventory control was one area that the Government could target on, because that is what a lot of other countries and a lot of other industries are doing very successfully.

Finally, of course, the Government has to try to get the macroeconomic climate right. A whole lot of issues are involved there. Interest rates, which everyone in the industry would say are far too high and are inhibiting investment; restrictive work practices; wages rates; and inflexibility of the labour market are all inhibiting factors. The tax system is the factor above all others which in the last 12 months has really savaged the motor industry. Sales have been collapsing. The latest figures show a 15 per cent fall in registrations year on year to August 1985 and a 22 per cent decline in the eight months to 1986. That master of mendacity the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is responsible for these policies which he railroaded through against the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mayo should withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw that remark. These policies were railroaded through over the dead political body of Senator Button, who realised that the fringe benefits tax would do untold damage to the industry. The Treasurer said that the industry had had it `too good for too long'. He said that in this place. If he thinks it has had it too good for too long, he has to understand that 4,500 jobs will be lost in my State of South Australia thanks to his tax policy and 10,000 jobs will be lost nationally. The Government is trying to do the right thing through the car industry plan. I have supported that, but why undo it all with the fringe benefits tax?
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the estimates for the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations I would like to offer some comments on the question of employment. I was interested to note that in the debate that we have had tonight the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) received a good deal of support from both sides of the chamber as he spoke about the consequences of unemployment in his very excellent speech on industry matters. We also heard similar comments from another honourable member on this side, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer). I think it is important that it be recognised that members of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have a real concern about the unemployed and unemployment in this country. It is not a matter upon which one can score cheap points; it is a matter upon which there ought to be a constructive approach to finding reasonable ways of addressing unemployment over the longer term.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been over time a change in community attitudes on the question of work for unemployment benefits and the impact that might have, if it were introduced, on the way in which the unemployed see their position in our society. It is interesting that over a period we have had operating in Australia a program whereby some people are required to work for moneys that they receive in substitution for unemployment benefits. That program, which has been in place for a long time, operates in Aboriginal communities in Australia. It is known as the community development employment program. Under that program an amount of money equivalent to the unemployment benefit is paid to a community council to enable the community to put in place arrangements to employ Aboriginals within the community for an appropriate amount of time relative to the money that is available for the substitution of unemployment benefits. They are then able to work on constructive tasks in the community. They are able to do a lot of the repair and maintenance work that is so essential, and this program ensures that the Aboriginal community is not placed at greater risk through having people with time on their hands and money in their pockets which could often be spent in a frivolous way and is often seen as not being very important. In fact, one of the rather novel ways in which Aborigines often describe the money that is paid in the form of social services is as `sit-down money'. I think that puts into perspective the way in which money that comes into people's hands very easily is sometimes construed.

It is not a new issue for members of Parliament to take up the question whether it is unreasonable to ask people who receive unemployment benefits to undertake some form of community service or employment for the moneys they receive. I have been surprised at the extent to which there has been widespread support for the view that some effort is required to develop a program along these lines. What has surprised me even more is the extent to which Labor members, and members of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, have now come to the view that this is the time to think about ways and means of ensuring that some form of community service is achieved.

We all know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) intended to speak about a compulsory scheme for people to undertake work for unemployment benefits. He changed his address to the nation and indicated that a more voluntary, and perhaps more relaxed, program would develop. We all sat on the edge of our seats waiting to see how those proposals would be developed by this Government. In recent weeks the ACTU has suggested that the unemployed should have available training programs in which they would have to participate or unemployment benefits would no longer be available to them. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) indicated that he saw nothing wrong with a scheme of that sort. He saw such training as being no different from the imposition of a work test, as we have long understood it, in the provision of unemployment benefits.

What is so interesting about this change of Government attitude is that there was a good deal of castigation of the Opposition for suggesting that programs of this sort would be desirable. There was also a significant condemnation of the Sydney Channel 9 program covering a range of interviews on the American program known as Workfare. A vigorous debate took place at Mount Druitt when discussing some of the American proposals. Viewers saw a group of people in that audience at Mount Druitt seeking unfairly to limit the freedom of speech of a lady who came to Australia to tell us a little more about the Workfare arrangements in the USA. In the context of that program comments were made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) to the effect that the development of any schemes that would require people to undertake some form of employment for unemployment benefits would be administratively so costly that such programs could not be reasonably put in place.

The Minister also used a report from the Department of Social Security review staff, a background and discussion paper No. 6 entitled `Workfare in America: An initial guide to the debate', as a basis for suggesting that American schemes were not relevant to Australia and could not be reasonably undertaken in this country. It is important that honourable members read that paper because my reading of it suggests that it does not condemn the American schemes out of hand. The following paragraph is worth reading:

Whether or not overseas schemes, such as any of the versions of Workfare, are worth importing to Australia depends in part on value judgments as to whether their objectives are desirable, and in part on judgments as to whether they would actually work in a different context.

That writer was not rejecting Workfare out of hand. She was correctly diagnosing that one would need to develop programs of this sort specifically for Australia to take into account the different circumstances in this country, the different contexts, and to put in place somewhat different programs. She drew attention to one important aspect of which all honourable members should take note. That was that the American schemes themselves, because they were not available to every participant, had certain shortcomings. He said:
This aspect is particularly important when schemes do not even offer everybody the opportunity to participate.
It seems to me that if we are going to develop programs of this sort in Australia, they need to be available so that everybody who wants to participate can do so.

I watched the debate at Mount Druitt with a great deal of interest because I thought certain people were working to denigrate certain types of work. One person there, an Australian Labor Party Senate candidate in prospect, Mr Halfpenny--

TALK.START.PARA: —In prospect.

—A candidate in prospect. He indicated that there were certain types of work that he saw as being more in the form of mickey mouse jobs and jobs that some people could not reasonably be asked to undertake. I think that is a very cavalier and unfortunate attitude, because I think any form of work that people are able to undertake ought to be respected and ought not to be condemned out of hand. I think there are many people in the community who see the prospect of being able to work in any field at all as being very desirable, and who, if it is at all achievable, would welcome the opportunity to undertake it. I regret very much that people are critical of the sort of work that might be available in the community when looking at schemes of this sort. I think the proposals before us are realistic and should be developed in the nation's interest.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable members who have contributed to this debate on the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. I will pass on to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) the observations that have been made about that area of Government administration. But I want to make a few observations of my own and also to respond to some questions that were raised in the course of the debate. I will do these as briefly as I can and not necessarily in the order in which the points were raised.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) asked specifically about whether small production runs were going to lead to some kind of penalty, in effect, through the reorganised car plan. The Automotive Industry Authority has circulated a discussion paper within the industry on the question of the need to reduce the number of models produced here. There has been no Government consideration of the issue and there will not be any until there has been a full discussion on all the elements which will be concerned, and I know this is of particular concern in South Australia. It will be discussed within the industry and generally, and that process may continue for some time.

There was a debate earlier, I think, about protection and free trade. I think it is fair to say that much of that debate has been conducted at a fairly primitive, almost instinctive, level. The partisans of each position argue dogmatically and there is no common ground, and each of the partisan views tends to overstate it. One sees the solution to every problem as being the imposition of free trade and the operation of market forces alone. The others see extraordinary life-giving qualities to industry in the imposition of protection. I listened with some sympathy to what the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) was saying in his advocacy of protection, but I listened in vain for a single example of an industry which had begun as a weakly infant and then by the judicious application of protection had in fact turned into a vigorous adult. The Canberra economist Gerry Gutman once wrote savagely, but with an element of truth:

Protection policy is aimed at nurturing . . . infant industries until able to stand on their own feet. It rarely happened that way. With the passage of the years, aging infants merely exchanged the crib for the wheelchair. Their growing debility presented their bureaucratic godparents with endless problems of devising increasingly complex life-support systems for their stricken offspring.

The experience in Australia has been that the most heavily protected industries-motor vehicles, metals, textiles, footwear and clothing-have been the greatest shedders of labour for 15 years, while the non-protected industries in large part, such as the service industries and tourism, have been the major areas of growth.

The problem about protection, mostly by tariff but also by quotas, is that it has had the impact of imposing isolation, encouraging insularity and distancing local producers from the realities and opportunities of world trade. When we talk about having internationally competitive industries in Australia we use the term in a very odd way. We mean that we hope that goods made in Sydney may be competitive in Sydney with goods made in Stockholm or Singapore. With very rare exceptions we rarely contemplate the possibility that Sydney made goods might compete on equal terms in Stockholm, Singapore or more neutral markets. The problem for us has been that, in the last few years, the countries that have overtaken us as world traders, particularly in brand names or packaged goods, have been countries that have generally had considerably lower protection levels than we have.

A few days ago I was examining supermarkets in Tokyo and I was very disturbed that, with the exception of beer and wine, in major supermarkets the only packaged food from Australia was that familiar item, Vegemite. In one supermarket I found two containers of Vegemite. If one looks at all the products that are made in Australia under brandnames such as Kelloggs in which one would think we had good export potential, one finds instead that these products are supplied from Europe or North America. There are all sorts of things, such as nuts and tinned fruits, which we should be able to export but somehow we have not succeeded in doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Queensland nut, the macadamia?

—I did not see macadamia nuts on display. The sad thing is that Australian wines, which were a major selling item in Japan a few years ago, have now been completely outstripped by Californian wines. In one large supermarket I saw about 80 bottles of Australian wine and perhaps 2,000 or 3,000 bottles of Californian wine. Five or six years ago that proportion would have been reversed. Our problem is-and the honourable member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) and some Opposition members were absolutely correct in this-that we have to get that emphasis on quality. The emphasis on quality has not been there. We have never developed that international reputation for quality.
—How do you get it though?

—That is the most difficult question of all. How does one develop a reputation in an area where one does not have one? I hope that in connection with the Australian-made campaign, which I think we all support very strongly, there will be a greater, growing and recurring emphasis on the need for quality. We cannot just produce the begging bowl, put on the dark glasses, take out the white cane and say: `Please buy our goods, we call on you for sympathy'. We can only do it if we are producing a worthwhile product. In a number of areas we have very able people, but a lot of our management is not terribly adventurous and not really concerned about the long term.

SPEECH.PARA: The point that worried me about the speech of the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton)-and I am glad he is gracing us with his presence again-is that when he talked about the problems of small business he said that too much emphasis was placed upon high-tech and not enough on low and medium-tech. The difficulty there is that his case would have been stronger if he had given an illustration of the kind of products with export potential that are based on low-tech.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can do that later.

—The point that needs to be made is that much of the new high-tech, particularly the new high-tech of micro-electronics, permeates so many products now that we cannot do without it. For hundreds of years Britain sold slide rules, but the development of the pocket calculator that sells for a few dollars has made all that obsolete. It is difficult to say: `We will go back to making the slide rules even better and we will make them genuine products of craftsmanship'. It is too late.
—You should not tax software. Why are you taxing software?

—I think the honourable member misunderstood what we are doing about the software. That is not the anomaly it is held out to be. In Australia we persist in applying our 40-watt lightbulb minds to problems that need the operation of a searchlight or a laser. The situation is desperately serious and we do not have the luxury of a great deal of time. It is an immensely serious problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditures agreed to.
Progress reported.
House adjourned at 10.57 p.m.

QUESTION.PARA: 1. Does the Minister's Department, or any statutory authority responsible to the Minister, provide grants to organisations operating in the ACT.

2. Do such grants have a requirement that any organisation so funded be registered under the ACT Associations Incorporation Ordinance 1953; if so, what steps are taken by the Minister's Department to ensure that the funded organisation has complied with the Ordinance before any grant is made.

4. If the search discloses a failure to comply with the ACT Associations Incorporation Ordinance, what steps are taken to ensure that the matter is remedied by those responsible for administration of the Ordinance, or the incorporated association.

5. Have all incorporated associations within the ACT funded by the Minister's Department or statutory authority complied with the Ordinance requirements for lodging particulars of financial affairs or balance sheets annually.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Grants are provided to the following organisations and individuals operating in the ACT:
(A) Human Rights Commission
Community Education Grants
Foundry Association Inc.
Women and Development Network of Australia, Inc.
ACT Association for Mental Health.
(B) Special Services Branch Marriage and Grants Section
Grants under the Family Law Act & Marriage Act

(c) The Canberra Welfare Rights and Legal Centre must supply to the ACT Legal Aid Commission copies of its audited financial statements as soon as possible after the end of the previous funding period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the report of the British Fraud Trials Committee, chaired by Lord Roskill, which recommended changes to the laws in order to deal with fraud trials and investigations more effectively.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a proposed alternative to jury trial in complex fraud cases whereby a fraud trial tribunal composed of a judge and 2 lay members with experience of complex business transactions would conduct cases.

(3) Will he investigate whether the need for judges to understand complex business transactions and scientific and technological evidence will make it essential for them to have readily at hand appropriate technical advice.

(4) Is there widespread public concern that juries are no longer appropriate to try cases of `pin-stripe crime'; if so, will he give consideration to (a) summary trial by judges in appropriate cases sitting with assessors and (b) substitution of pre-trial procedures for committal proceedings to ensure that accused persons are adequately informed of the case against them.
(5) If changes are not made to the existing structure of dealing with complex commercial fraud cases might the system break down.
(6) Will he investigate whether there is a need for judges who have special expertise in commercial law.
(7) Will he take steps to set up a body of review to investigate the applicability in Australia of the recommendations of the British Fraud Trials Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) and (6) The Commonwealth has a long standing policy of investing State courts with federal criminal jurisdiction. Thus most federal criminal cases are tried by State courts. As regards the trial of criminal cases by the Federal Court of Australia and the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory, the Government is of the view that there are judges of these Courts with appropriate expertise to try cases involving complex business transactions.

(4) and (5) I am not aware of widespread public concern that juries are no longer appropriate to try cases of commercial crime involving complex business transactions. Nor do I consider that there is any likelihood that the criminal justice system will break down if changes are not made to the existing structures for dealing with complex commercial fraud cases. However, that is not to say that consideration should not be given to improving the present system. Work is being done at State level with a view to improving the functioning of the jury system. The Commonwealth is monitoring these developments closely.
(7) The establishment of such a review could not be justified at this time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Proceedings against Mr R. Holmes a Court

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports in the West Australian of 10 January 1986 and the Age of 11 January 1986 dealing with proceedings involving companies associated with Mr Robert Holmes a Court and the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Act 1984.
(2) What is the (a) background to, (b) state of and (c) position of the Government on the substance of those proceedings and any related foreign proceedings.

(3) Has Mr Holmes a Court made any representations to the Government concerning investigations by the US Department of Justice; if so, what was the (a) nature and (b) outcome of those representations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) and (3): In August 1985, following investigations by the United States Federal Trade Commission, the United States Department of Justice instituted proceedings against Mr Robert Holmes a Court, Bell Resources Ltd, and Weeks Petroleum Ltd, alleging violation of the United States pre-merger notification laws.
The allegations related to the acquisition of shares in a U.S. company, ASARCO Inc., by Weeks Petroleum Ltd, a subsidiary of Bell Resources Ltd of which Mr Holmes a Court is Chairman.

In March 1986 the proceedings against all defendants were settled without going to trial and without any admissions by the defendants, on the basis of a payment by Weeks Petroleum Ltd of a civil penalty of US$450,000. The proceedings against the other defendants were dismissed.

During the course of those proceedings, Bell Resources representatives made representations to the Australian Government, asking that it hold consultations with the U.S. Government pursuant to the Australia/U.S. Antitrust Co-operation Agreement. The Australian Government did not initiate such consultations. However, the Government had been kept fully informed by the U.S. Government of developments in the proceedings pursuant to the notification provisions (Article 1.2 and 1.3) of the Antitrust Co-operation Agreement, and was closely monitoring the matter.

Subsequently, representations were made asking me to exercise my powers, pursuant to section 7 of the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Act 1984, to prohibit certain Australian residents from giving evidence or information to the U.S. authorities. At that time Mr Holmes a Court and Bell Resources Ltd had obtained an injunction from the Western Australian Supreme Court which restrained various persons from disclosing, without the applicants' consent, information concerning the matters in question. In light of all the circumstances of the matter, I was not prepared at that stage to consider the exercise of my powers under section 7 of the Foreign Proceedings (Excess of Jurisdiction) Act 1984 or to make any decision on the exercise of those powers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that 1063 workers at 4 defence sites (Williamstown Dockyard, Melbourne, the Government Aircraft Factories, Melbourne and Avalon, Garden Island Dockyard, Sydney) will be retrenched in the next year: if so, are there any plans for the placing of these workers in alternative employment.
(2) What will be the saving to his Department in decreasing the workforce by this number.
(3) In what areas is efficiency expected to increase in line with the proposed retrenchments.
(4) Is there any provision for the re-employment of retrenched workers if efficiency increases to such an extent to warrant the employment of additional staff.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In my news release of 18 July 1986 I indicated that the workforce at Williamstown Dockyard, Garden Island Dockyard and the Government Aircraft Factories would be reduced by 1063 based on February staffing levels.

The Federal Government's intention to cut the workforce at the three establishments was made in an announcement on 21 March 1986, and was followed by extensive discussions with the ACTU and all relevant unions.

Where possible redeployment and retraining opportunities have been pursued for staff in affected areas. However given the magnitude of the reductions a voluntary retrenchment package, negotiated with the ACTU, was offered to staff.

(2) A total of 806 workers chose to leave under the conditions of the voluntary retrenchment process which concluded on 31 August 1986. When combined with natural attrition and redeployment since February 1986, a total of 1162 workers have chosen to leave. This overachievement is due primarily to natural attrition occurring in non-surplus areas.

In wages and administrative costs alone it is estimated that the current staffing levels indicate an annual saving of $30m based on February 1986 staffing levels. The cost of the severance package (excluding superannuation) is estimated at $18.5m. This includes $7.5m paid out in accrued recreation and long service leave entitlements.
(3) The reductions in the workforce are part of a program of restructuring and reforms to work practices which have been implemented within the Office of Defence Production.
Overall the achievements to date amount to significant improvements in productivity and reduction of the subsidy needed to operate these establishments.
(4) Increases in efficiency would not justify the recruitment of staff.

Should additional staff be required to replace staff lost by natural attrition, or should Defence work increase significantly, those staff retrenched will be able to apply. The choice of workers would be based solely on the operational needs of the establishment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 22 September 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Merino rams were exported during 1985-86.
(2) How did the price of those rams compare to the average price paid by Australian buyers at auction sales.
(3) Is Merino ram semen being exported from Australia; if so, to what extent.
(4) How many Merino rams have been sold to overseas buyers at auction sales since 1 July 1986 and at what price.
(5) What has been the average price of rams sold at Australian stud Merino auctions since 1 July 1986.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There were 737 Merino rams exported from Australia in 1985-86.
(2) Average price paid for rams exported in 1985-86 was approximately $1400. Average price paid at auction by Australian buyers is unknown.
(3) 1167 pellets (approximately 3500 doses) of Merino ram semen were exported to New Zealand in April this year. Exports of semen to countries other than New Zealand is not permitted.
(4) There have been 506 Merino rams sold to overseas buyers at auction sales from 1 July 1986 to 27 September 1986. Prices have ranged from $500 to $102,000.
(5) Information on average price of rams sold at auction since 1 July 1986 is unavailable.
